reviews.review: Wow - i wish we had this transport system in Oz. This is an outstanding transport system, the best that i have exopeinced anywhere in the world!We had a JR Pass, but bought a 72 hour pass to use the metro and subway lines and as a visitor, was best utilised with a transport "app" - i used the city rail app, which was excellent, and allowed me to confidently navigate around the city. The trains themselves all had destination and current location advice. No train that we travelled on was dirty. There was no grafitti. No violence. No drunkedness. No bad behaviour. Awesome. Australians public transport managers need to learn from the japanese!

Excellent mass transit. The Pasmo Card is a good bet if you want to spend any time getting around in Tokyo. The system is extensive and will get you to anywhere you want to go. The cars are clean as are the stations. We were lucky to have a personal guide to help us maneuver this vast system. Even he had to seek help a few times to get us where we needed to be. This is an excellent transit system.

AWESOME METRO SYSTEM!. It was very difficult to understand at first, but actually is very simple.Very complex underground system, very clean and crowded. Pricing depends on the distance traveled and also on the subway company used. Get SUICA card to make things more easier for you.

Efficient Transport. There are many different train lines run by various companies. All the metro lines are color coded with a station number, so long as you know the train line you need to get on and the station number you would be fine. With some very large stations, make sure you get the correct exit number, otherwise, it could be a very long walk. If you need any assistance at the station, there are plenty of people who are willing to go out of their way to help despite the language barrier. Just make sure you have the metro map handy so you can point to people on the map.

Best subway in the World. we traveled from 10/5/16-10/14/16 by Metro found the cars to be on time, very very clean and with excellent temperature control, the prices were excellent a great way to get around Tokyo, we did use a cab twice it was expensive but had no choice be sure to download the Tokyo subway map and talking Japanese app, it is hard to get wifi but if you do you can make phone calls thru sms facebook chat, we rented wifi for the trip and found with that we never got lost
Complex but awesome. The Tokyo Metro specially the Shinjuku station is an experience itself that one should experience at least once in his lifetime.

Excellent metro system. Difficult to understand at first, and not enough English, but actually quite simple, and it's the fastest and cheapest way around Tokyo. There is more than one company. JR seems to be above ground, while the metro is underground. Each one seems to have its own ticket machine. Above the machines are maps, with station names and prices. Unlike NYC, each destination has a different price. Once you know the price, press the language button, and select English. Then choose the number of riders, and select the price. Pay, and then take the ticket. You need it to get to the train. If the ticket doesn't work then you bought the ticket for the wrong company... They'll give you the money back at the ticket office. Keep the ticket! You'll need it to get out of the station.
Excellent way to travel in Tokyo. I don't know how it has become "a thing to do"!!!!This is the best mode of transportation in Tokyo and thats it!

Can Be Confusing, But It Is Excellent. It is an overwhelming system at first, and sometimes it can be daunting if no one around you speaks English, but once you get it- Wow! An amazing transit system that will get you anywhere relatively CHEAP!! And it is very clean.Don't quote me on the exact numbers, but the are a bunch of public subway lines, something 3-5 private subway lines, and 5 private local rail lines that in the gaps.I highly recommend downloading one of the apps on iPhone/Android that lets you put in two stations and then gives you your route with transfers.

Super . Tokyo metropolitan rail took a little time to understand (there are surface JR trains and metro trains running on separate overlapping networks) but it doesn't take long with gps or maps. The subway is clean, the trains are air-conditioned and frequent. Either train system is excellent, if you have a JR pass you can ride their metropolitan trains for free but when I used the metro line it was reasonably priced

So easy to use. Get a metro map from TI or your hotel and explore this amazing city.The metro lines are colour coded, stations are numbered. Platform signs show name of station , colour of line and station number plus an arrow to indicate direction up or down the numbers the line is going could not be easier.Buy a 24 or 48 hour ticket, it is validated for use the first time you put it through the barrier machine. Carriages are clean, some are women only at certain times. Gets very busy during the rush hour. Always a friendly local to help you. All platforms have a station master, many speak English so if in doubt you can ask for help. A brilliant and efficient way to get around Tokyo. Safe at night.
5 days in Tokyo. Japan has the most efficient transport network I have ever used. Some stations are difficult to navigate but just ask a member of staff for help.

expensive and confusing. Tokyo has good network of subway but it is operated by many companies which is bit confusing. One pass is not enough for all routs within circle. You need need to be careful while choosing line

the only way to move in tokyo. move in Tokyo with or without metro its not a question. the reality is that you need to move in the metro, very easy to understand and people in the metro are very kind so dont hesitate take the metro

Amazing system!. The Tokyo subway is clean, efficient, modern and safe.Everything is in Japanese and English, so it is easy to understand navigate. It is clean, updated and comfortable. The other passengers are friendly and polite.

Clean and confusing!. It's confusing, for the first two or so days, then it becomes amazing. I still have the map with me to make sure I don't lose my knowledge I gathered while I was there on the train lines. If you're going on the metro a lot, read about it if you're depending on it when you land because as I said it's confusing at first.

Don't be Confused with JR or Toei Lines!. Taking millions of commuters around a day, the Tokyo Metro is very convenient for tourists as well, with ticket machines a-plenty and extremely helpful ticket booth staff should you get lost or need help with a fare adjustment. Note though, that Tokyo Metro and the Toei lines are operated by different entities, so the tickets are NOT the same! I made this mistake by purchasing a Toei ticket at a Tokyo Metro ticket machine, not knowing the the two systems different. Thankfully the fare adjustment booth was very kind and offered me a refund. Have fun!

Once you figure out routes and how to buy tickets, it's relatively easy. You know the saying, every country has a different way of flushing toilets. What us overwhelming at first about the metro system is its enormity. It crosses rail lines, reaches into other cities and prefectures, and there is a mass of humanity passing through during peak hours. But it is safe, clean, and the tickets run 170 yen to 240 close in, and 980 yen if you are traveling 60-70 minutes away. Most cars have digital signage and announcements of next stop in Japanese and English, so you can't really get lost. Notice the yellow rubber tracks that are imbedded in the tile. That is to guide the seeing impaired. Another proof of the dignity and independence extended to all in this culture.

Clean, efficient and not too expensive . Having seen pictures of people getting crammed into subway cars by "pushers" I was expecting madness, but no matter what time of day or where I was, I always found a seat. It was much more frantic in Beijing. The trains are of course spotless (this is Japan!), frequent and tickets are cheaper than in other places eg Osaka. At first it's a little confusing to understand which lines are run by which company but a Suica/Pasmo removes that headache.

Metro with too many options. Personally I do agree that it is best way to travel in Tokyo. I got a Suica card from our last trip to Osaka. At least this is better than checking the ticket prices on each trip.However sometimes you have few options from one station to another, it becomes time consuming to check. There are far too many platforms in larger stations.Well, limited mobile phone usage inside the metro cabinet which is very good.People are often quite polite and well mannered inside the cabinet as well!I don't think that Metro fares are cheap.

On time - access everywhere - quick. Best way how to get around the city. The transport network is huge. We used a card with credit on it to get around. I strongly recommend this as it is really easy to use. You will also be able to recharge your card at most/every station. There are 2 cards : Passmo and Suica. That said when traveling on a budget this can become quite pricy to travel around by metro compared to European cities.

Nice & Easy. Very efficient way to travel between the main areas within Tokyo city. Even if your are not familiar with using the metro don't worry, it is so systematic and organized you just need to know their system and how it works.

It is a normal subway system. What to say.... it is just a normal subway system.It is clean and not too crowded when I was there.However for me as tourist it is very difficult to know what is the charges from one place to another place because it can be different and it is not that straight forward to know.For transportation in Tokyo, definitely this is the best means to get around.

Clean, modern and very efficient!. If you go to Japan and worried about how to get to your destination, worry no more. The JR Lines and other Tokyo rail are really the best go to transportation. If you're not used to public transportation like I am (from LA) it might be a little intimidating. Luckily, if you can read English you can definitely find out where you need to go with ease. You have to get the SUICA Card if you (found near most station entrances) and it cost about 2000 Yen (500 Yen refundable deposit). Then you can reload your SUICA Card depending on your fare needs.

best way to travel in tokyo. maybe one of the busiest metro in the world, but so efficient, so orgnized and easy to use. it was a great experience to get around in the metro. always crowded, every few minutes you have a train, clean, every station has information and guide. cheap and safein my opinion, dont use anything but the metro for transport, you always will find a station close enough to the destination.

Ride the rails. Tip: if in doubt that the train about to leave us yours, just miss it. Another will be along in a few minutes. Have been using JR pass for local and day trips and it has been hassle free and efficient. Also great theatre. So many people glued to the phone games. But no one talking on them (so good that phones must go on silent and talking on phones a no no). So many people sleeping on trains, waking up in time to get off. Do you look a little lost there's a good chance someone will offer to help. Tip 2: get a Japan rail app that will show you how to get from one station to another. Been a Godsend. You could easily spend days just riding the rails getting a feel for this city and its people.

Best way to get around. Get a Suica or Pasmo card and load it up. Day passes are an option as well but that will depend on how much you travel in a day. TIP: you can use your Suica or Pasmo card at select vending machines around the city to get drinks. You can also use the card at the airport to pay for things. Look for the logo at the cash register. A good way to finish using up all the money on your card and then keep the card as a souvenir...or save it to use on your next trip (just load it with more money!)

Best Means of Transportation. Japan is popular for its metro and trains which are always on schedule.It's the most convenient and cheap way of traveling across Tokyo as it goes everywhere. The names of stations and announcements are also done in English , so no need to worry. But, due to multiple train lines, the inter connectivity might be confusing for first timers.But do carry maps if you do not have internet access. Google maps are wonderfully connected with JR and Tokyo Metro for inter connectivity and timings.

Great Way to Get Around Tokyo. Subway is the best method of getting around Tokyo.It's the cheapest mode of trasnsportation around Tokyo, especially if you compare to taxi. Please do a research before taking a taxi, or you can get broke easily. It has wide coverarge. You can easily reach any touristy spot easily. It's rather overwhelming when you take a look at Tokyo subway map at first, but I can assure you it's very easy to do.It has escalator almost in every station, so you can save energy for your trip. And the transfer between line is short, unless you're in the big station like Shinjuku.It's punctual, and train comes under 10 minutes, so you don't have to wait for long time.

best and cheap to go around tokyo. sometimes when u ask someone about japan u get this answer  JAPAN IS VERY EXPANSIVE .....the reason for that is , some people don't know how to plan how to go from pint a to b in Tokyo plan right and do many research and u wont spend as much as u thought

Efficient way to get around. Have been using the metro during summer time. Very clean and modern with AC. At peak hours, there are lady only carriages. Make sure you get in the right carriage. Also check you exits. Some big stations have in excess of 10 exits.

Great transport network, making it easy for visitors!. Good value (we got a Suica card, so easy to beep in and out of stations without worrying about fares too much, and you can also use Suica to pay for things in the convenience stores around the city!), easy to navigate, extremely helpful staff, clean trains...Tokyo showing the world how to run a metro system!

One of the BEST in the world. We have visited Tokyo several times in the past few years and have made extensive use of the metro system.It is EXTREMELY reasonable in cost. English signage is available and there are plenty of staff to provide directions. The trains are always on time and very clean.You may want to avoid rush hours as trains get REALLY crowded and the 'pushers' pack you in pretty tight.All in all a pretty painless way to get around Tokyo.

Best Metro in the world . Tokyo Metro is always on time and the connections are great and easy to navigate. Riding the subway anytime of the day is easy. The sheer technology invested on the metro will amaze you!
best way to travel in Tokyo. Trains are clean and on time. When were I are confused just asked station masters. they always helped. Its perfect!

Perfect metro service!. The metro of Tokyo is the best of the world! You can go everywhere from the city center to suburban areas. It works perfect, without delays. Just grab a city map from the numerous metro kiosks (almost in every metro station) and discover the city!

Affordable, clean and reliable. On paper (the metro maps look like a spilled bowl of spaghetti!) this looks to be a daunting experience but actually the reality is this is a very efficient, cheap and easy way of getting around Tokyo. All the machines to buy your tickets from can be navigated in English, and help is on hand from metro staff who we found eager to lend a hand if you get stuck.Follow the metro line colours (station signs and directions are well marked in Japanese and English) and station numbers (stops are announced on the trains as well) and personally I think if you can navigate the London tube you'll have no problems in Tokyo.Tip : Make sure you adhere to metro etiquette (mobiles on silent, no eating/drinking).

Convenient and easy to follow directions. Tokyo metro is one of the more complicated ones in the world. You can see that by just looking at the metro map lol. However, it takes you everywhere you need to go. It is quite easy to follow by using APP on the phone. All the exits are well labelled and easy to follow. Be sure you get the 24hr/48hr/72hr metro pass if you are visiting Tokyo. It's worth it.

The Best Metro Anywhere. The trains are clean and run very much on time and go essentially anywhere you need to go in Tokyo. Signage in the inner stations are in Japanese and English although it can be difficult further out. If you make a mistake you can always correct the fare as you exit.

Convenient & More!. During our 5+plus days in Tokyo we did not use a taxi once due to the great Tokyo Metro! We also had a Japan Rail pass so it was easy to combine both if necessary. But Tokyo Metro ( little weird"M" logo) stops almost anywhere in Tokyo you want to go to. For some destinations you will have to enjoy walking a little. We did not buy any type of pass, it is fairly inexpensive. You will have to make sure its the right ticket for the right line and not the competing Toei line (buy ticket as close to the gate you need to board or check point you need to go through). Metro staff is really helpful as well. You will need to be patient since their English is not great. We relaxed and enjoyed our experience even when we made a mistake.
Perfect....like clockwork. Nothing bad to say about this. It's fast, punctual and professionally ran. Never known a train be a second late and rarely do you not get a seat. First class!
Always on time. Never late. Recommend getting a Pasmo or Oyster card. Look for the Green or Pink registers to get one.

Fast, clean and safe. We used the metro for most of our travel. The ticket machines are pretty easy to use, but you need cash (note if you have an foreign ATM, you can only use some machines - the 7-11 machines in the Metro stations work). The trains run very frequently and were not overly crowded.

東京メトロ. The Tokyo metro. I think the Tokyo metro is so so. Because Tokyo is such a big city.and the trains are very crowded. And there is a lot of people in the train stations because everybody rushes. Especially in the morning.

Very Comprehensive Network. The Tokyo Metro comprises of a very comprehensive network which connects all parts of this mega city. Had good experience. You can get train time tables online and plan your trips within the city. Might be crowded over the weekends.

Reliable and Quick!. Cheap and very reliable, It's probably one of the best metro's in the world, due to it's always on time but the map is a bit confusing.
However do not travel in rush hours.

Worth every penny . Some say that the Tokyo Metro is expensive which I would agree on partially, yes it is more expensive than other Asian cities, however the fact that it is air conditioned, always runs on time and is clean, smooth and quiet is worth it for me!

Efficient but can be confusing. The Tokyo subway system is one of the most efficient and cleanest systems in the world. There are trains running to almost any destination you want. A Pasmo or Suica card will make your travels much easier if you will be using the system a lot. Just load your card and you are ready to swipe in and out like a pro. But be warned, the system can be confusing, here's why: 1. You pay for each leg traveled, so it can cost a lot more than you realize.2. Some times of the day and some particular stations can be really busy. so expect to be squeezed right up against another passenger with nothing to hang onto.3. A lot of Japanese have mastered the art of standing and sleeping on the trains. It's amazing how every person on the morning train has their eyes closed.4. The larger stations like Shinjuku or Tokyo can be confusing to exit or change trains. You need to follow the signs above or on the floor. But sometimes they disappear and you are left to your own defenses. There are up to 20 or more exits from certain stations.5. Tourist attractions are not listed on the exits. You need to know where you are going and googlemap it to find the correct exit.6.Late at night, certain platforms close and you are directed to use a different one. Unfortunately the announcements are in Japanese. We followed the direction for the destination we wanted but after 3 trains on an opposing platform came and nothing came on ours we knew something was wrong. We switched to the other platform and even though the sign said it was going somewhere else, we got to our destination.7. Stations connected to shopping malls become even more confusing. Expect to walk along way before you get to your next connection or destination. They can be deceiving. It might be better to exit to the street and walk directly there.8. A one day pass is for One Day, not 24 hours. Don't buy one at 6:00 PM and expect it to still work tomorrow morning.9. Connecting to a JR line will cost you more.

Cost effective, comfortable and run to a timetable. The Tokyo Metro works well. Trains arrive on time and your wait is rarely more that a few minutes. Your J R Rail Pass will get you around, and once that expires get a PASMO CARD - charge it with 1000 to 2000 yen and you are set. Any spare yen on your PASMO CARD can be redeemed at the major stations, with Shibuya and Shinjuku stations the ones we most frequented. The subway system is complex, has lots of lines, so a map of the subway system is necessary, and available free at most stations and Tourist Information Centers. Given my dyslexia getting around required a little focus, pre-trip research, but I also found that station staff were generally very happy to help with directions. The other thing I quite liked about the subway was the great posters used by the local authorities to warn against drunkenness, selfie sticks, all manner of stuff, and the advertisement within the carriages. Commuters on the subway are quiet, polite, don't chat on their mobile phones - in fact as subway around the world go the Tokyo Metro is ace - convenient, clean, and very cost effective.

The best metro in the world. I think the Tokyo's metro is the best metro in the world. The train comes frequently and the time are always correct. Also they have a wide network so it is easy to get around Tokyo.

Can be very confusing. . Having lived in Tokyo for over three years I find the Metro still very confusing. I have found that taking your time and finding a station map is a necessity. Google maps often doesn't work deep underground and doesn't give you any idea what exit to take. Matching a station map to google maps is very important. I can say if the train is scheduled for 12:03 it shows up at 12:03 every day.

Efficient, inexpensive & gets you everywhere. This is the cheapest and fastest way to get around Tokyo. So if you are on a budget this is the way to go. Tickets are 170Yen per trip & you can easily buy at machines in each station which have displays in English & other languages. But if there are two or three of you and you are not on a strict budget, take a taxi. The fares in town run about CD$15 to $20 per trip, the traffic is good, & it will be faster & easier as it gets you right to the door. The drivers rarely speak English so either get the destination written in Japanese in advance or show him your map. They are very honest generally.

Clean, Efficient, Quiet and Reliable. The Tokyo Metro is extremely punctual and has regular trains arriving less than five minutes apart most of the day and night. It is clean, efficient, quiet, and reliable. Quiet, packed carriages at times but no talking on phones.If a station is conveniently located near to your hotel it a great inexpensive way to get around town. However, it does not run 24 hours a day. While through service with other companies complicates this somewhat, the last train generally starts at midnight and completes its service by 01:00, and the first train generally starts at 05:00.A good high-speed connection to and from the Narita Airport is the Keisei Skyliner which runs to Ueno or Nippori Metro Stations. A ticket for the fast and comfortable Skyliner limited express, connecting Narita Airport to the heart of Tokyo in as little as 36 minutes, and the "Tokyo Subway Ticket", which allows users to freely ride any Tokyo subway line for 24, 48 or 72 hours, can be purchased online at a specially low priced set and picked up at the Narita Airport when you arrive. Note: The Tokyo Subway Ticket does not work on the JR Lines. In addition, taking luggage on the subway during commute hours may be difficult due to the crowds of people.A good tip is to look at the vicinity map when you exit the gates. Look at where you are and where you want to go and identify the corresponding exit (i.e. A1,A2). Then follow the signs to that exit.

pushing and mask. avoid the rush time but take a moment to enjoy how the people get into the train when you are sure that no one can get in.It is very efficient, the anime music and the manga add Make you feel like in a childhood city.

Great way to get around, purchase a JR rail card to use most of the lines.. Perfect way to travel around Tokyo for our back packing, my partner persuaded me to get a JR Rail pass although it was pretty expensive (£200 I think for two weeks) it was worth it as you could use bullet trains as well. For JR you could use most of the train lines ones you couldn't use had no JR symbol, they were only busy in peak times but when it was peak times you will be pushed in however this ensures all passengers get to where they want to be on time. I think you can only buy JR pass from your country of origin.It is very rude to eat or drink on the train I read so we didn't do this and also never saw anyone doing this, I think it is also rude to talk so there was very limited speech of anyone, when we whispered we were looked at like we just started dancing however if you look different to the Japanese people they find us interesting anyway. Trains were always clean and tidy and ALWAYS on time and frequent but do shut for the night or there is less of trains so watch out.

Efficient, clean, fast, modern. First of all: purchase a SUICA or PASMO IC card and charge it with - let's say 2000 JPY although this may depend how long you plan to stay in Japan. I say "Japan" - not only Tokyo, because it can be used in other cities too. I've been to Hakone, Osaka and Kyoto too and my PASMO card worked there too what is extremely convenient. On JR lines the IC cards can be used too. It doesn't matter which IC card you use: PASMO or SUICA.To enter/leave the tracks you just swipe your IC card over the area that is marked with "IC" at the gates. They are normally open but close immediately if something went wrong during the reading of the IC card. The fare is calculated depending on the distance of your trip.Tokyo Metro itself is fast, clean and trains run frequently. Be prepared of crowded trains during rush hour. So don't travel with heavy and large luggage during rush hour.Stations are announced automatically in English too and it tells you in advance on which side doors will open at the next station. There are also monitors indicating the next station as well as an overview of all stations (always switching between Japanese and Latin characters).To calculate a route I would recommend using Google Maps as it seems to know all timetables and fares.

Best in the World. Feel compelled to write this having travelled on my local metro system and the Tokyo Metro in the same week. Not even in the same league the Tokyo Metro is everything my local metro is not, clean, efficient, quiet, reliable, when I say reliable I mean you can set your watch by them to the second. Clean and when you consider the footfall in one day is the footfall for the whole year on my local system, its like every train was brand new that day. Polite staff always eager to help despite the language barriers. Quiet, packed carriages at times but no talking on phones. Simply the best transportation system in the world. Message to my local metro send some staff to Tokyo to see how its done.

Perfect Metro. Even you dont speak English well you will not have any Troubles finding your way in the Tokyo Metro. Everything is clear discribed and everybody is willing to help you when you ask friendly. Enjoy the ride..

Absolutely Fantastic. We used the metro all the time. We had a JR Pass and were able to use this on quite a few of the lines and on the others we just paid - quite cheap and so easy and quick. Excellent service.

Clean and efficient . The best way to get around Tokyo. I highly recommend that you get a Pasmo card instead of the single use tickets. The pasmo card will be good for 10 years and you can reload it when you get low. The turnstile tells you the balance on your card-----pay attention. You can also use it for taxis and vending machines.

Efficient and cheap!. Subways are very easy to use and very reasonably priced. Definitely buy a Suica or Pasmo card so you can swipe your way in and out of the stations; you can top them off anytime. You can get the card very easily at any subway station. We only used the JR line and walked to places as needed but I understand that other lines may be even cheaper to use. Subway cars snd stations are very clean.

used only this transportation for the whole stay? use it with a Suica to make it easier .. let be honest : i was a bit confused before trying to understand the whole thing. multiple companies , subway,train, yamanote , other trains. at the end , was way easy, way fun and way everything. get a map, get a Suica ( a card that you charge with money available at airport when you arrive), top it up and then no need to struggle buying tickets. it will work on every line including the monorail from Haneda airport . Bonus : the Suica can be used to pay at vending machine, , 7eleven and even some museums.then you are good for your stay. for connections sometimes you will need to get out: get in, walk a lot. no worry it is always well indicated - just follow your line color. abd of course local staff way helpful. if you want to play it geek : download the apps tokyosubway to help you localize nearest station etc.

On time every time all the time. Not just on time, frequent. I don't think we ever waited 10 minutes for the next train. The cars are clean and air conditioned. And you get the feeling of complete safety because the Japanese people are so well-mannered. There are several subway companies. So you have to pay attention to which one goes to which station. Buying tickets is a bit intimidating at first. But there are helpful staff at every station. They speak enough English to help you get a ticket or to find a track.Once we got used to it, we thought nothing of going anywhere on these trains.
Cheap, easy and fast . The metro system in Tokyo is great. It's very reliable and as a non Japanese speaker I didn't have any problems. Best thing about it: it's very cheap!!

Good transportation system. When I travel I liked to go out on my own rather than group tours so I like towns which after compact such as time or Athens or those with good public transportation at reasonable prices. Tokyo USD to larger to walk everywhere but there public transportation system is well maintained and can get you anywhere. Prices are higher than in the new York or London metro system but not unreasonable. This is an odd system in that there lines address not run by one central authority but rather multiple companies so that transfer can be difficult requiring several hundred yard walls and moving in and out of security areas. Two lines may run through the same area but may need in completely different buildings. There's address many lines so there subway map can be confusing. We found apps which claim to tell you how to get from one place to another inconsistent and sometimes outright wrong. So travel takes some g and willingness to ask questions which can new difficult if you do not speak Japanese. There are many who speak some English but translation s can be complicated again even when using languages apps. Despite these frustrations the system is good. Dinner of the station's offer fabulous on the go food and great architecture so a tour of them is itself interesting. One of the passes like the suica pass is useful. you put money on it and are billed as you go and just tap the turnstile to move through as most residents do. Despite these frustrations the system offered great coverages and freedom.
The best metro in the world, period!. As noted in the title the best, most efficient, cleanest and cheapest metro of all we have visited (and we have seen almost all). It is a joy to use.

It is easy to understand. inalways find that the Tokyo Metro is easy to navigate. I have used the system 17 times now but even in the beginning it was clear what the system was. Often, there are helpful people who speak English and this can help if you want to buy a train ticket in an automatic machine. Whatever your question you can usually find help. Just be aware that there are the slow trains and the fast trains and this can make a difference if you are going to Narita airport.

Excellent, efficient and safe. I love taking public transportation in foreign and domestic cities. In tokyo its not even a challenge, its a flipping breeze and so safe and clean feeling. If you have trepidation about using public transportation, let it loose and use it here. Its a great place to people watch as well. Even if you screw up, big deal, there arent many places safer in the world than tokyo.

Always on time. I have traveled the Tokyo Metro many times in the past and always had my mom and family members to help out. This time I was able to navigate much more independently with the help of the Tokyo Metro Map which was very accurate and efficient. This is a very confusing metro system and it would probably take at least a year to truly master. However, I found the app to be wonderful. The subways are all very clean and trains are always running efficiently and on time. I would not advice traveling during rush hour as it is pure madness and if you struggle with social phobia you will be overwhelmed. It is a mass of humanity packed into the subway cars and people literally fit as many people as possible on. They even have subway employees that "assist" in mashing people in. Youtube it, it is pretty amazing how they are still polite when they are trying to cram you in.

Unbelivable effective metro system and easy to find your way. Tokyo's metro system is huge - you can reach almost any point in this big city via the metro net by one or two train changes at the most!The trains are clean, but crowded. always filled with people, and very few seats available - most people stand up. The trains runs on time, the fare is cheap, and you buy tickets in the maschine found at any entrance. Several languages available, and the maps on the stations as well as signs of directions are superb!In the train the information is fantastic: You can follow your train on a screen, where are you where do you go. Which side does the doors open. And the speaker always announce next station.Many other cities could learn a lot from Japan - they can run a metro!

Easy and so clean. Don't be afraid!!! My wife insists we use the public transportation wherever we go and people told us how complicated the Tokyo metro would be. Not at all! It's the easiest way to span this huge city and because of the upcoming Olympic Games, the signage is also in English. If you have trouble walking, be careful as some stations require quite a bit of moving from floor to floor. And don't be shy, the help desks really help!! Great experience.

Take a pass if you are a tourist!. I must admit I was a bit confused between JR lines and metro lines, but as my boyfriend and I had taken passes for both, we did not pay too much attention to it. Be careful if you have only the metro pass.The metro gives access to pretty much everything in the city, it is clean and fast. Do keep a map with you at all times as there are many lines. Even if you don't speak Japanese it is relatively easy to find your way there.

Confusing & complicated, but fun!!. Tokyo has mainly 2 suburban train systems. One is JR urban line and the other is subway (TokyoMetro and Toei). JR urban line is mostly overground and operated by JR. Tokyo Metropolitan District Pass (Tokunai Pass) is available for unlimited travel within central Tokyo areas. You will be able to visit Shibuya, Shinjuku, Akihabara, Shinagawa,.... Note this pass is NOT valid on subway.Cost: 750 yen for a day. On the other hand, subway are mostly underground and operated by 2 operators, TokyoMetro (9 lines) and Toei (4 lines). Subway lines are color coded and an app is available to find the route between stations. Subway let you visit majority of the attractions, but a few will need a combination of JR + subway! Day pass valid on individual subway operator is available. Day pass valid on both TokyoMetro & Toei is also available. JR pass is NOT valid on subway! If your travel is limited, it's better to buy individual tickets for your journey. Else get an prepaid IC card. Automatic Ticket vending machines are available & have option to use English menu.The trains run on time, are frequent, and clean. Station masters are very helpful. They get "very" crowded during peak hours!!
Don't use anything but metro. Tokyo metro is really very easy to use. Just spend a few minutes in front of the map, you will eaisly understand how to use it.

Best I've Seen Worldwide. The Tokyo Metro is an essential way of getting around in this metropolis. Its not nearly as intimidating as it first looks. I printed off a color Metro map a few weeks before I arrived in Japan so I could plot my routes. The trains are very clean and never late in our experience. The are very frequent and we thoroughly enjoyed navigating around Tokyo via the Metro. It was fun watched the salary men sat in their suits playing Candy Crush and other such games on their phones or iPad's! Its amazing how courteous the passengers are. They are either looking at their phones or sleeping. Nobody talks on their phone and very few talk.

an experience. The Tokyo subway receives my award for cleanest subway in the world!! It is truly unbelievable how clean it is considering the traffic it gets. It can get confusing to find your way at some main station, but it is part of the adventure and station attendants are always ready to help. I took it once during rush hours and I felt like a sardine, twice if not more the amount of traffic that we get in the subway during rush hours in NY, but still a good experience and something to see (I only resisted a couple of stops so it was not bad)

Everything is on time and you can get to just about anywhere in Tokyo. If you’ve never been on the Tokyo Metro, you are missing a major point of travel. You can get a subway card for a foreigner in a 1 day “all you can travel” version or a 3 day or simply a card with a money deposit loaded into it. For a short time visit – get the “all you can travel” version and for up to 72 hours – you can go wherever you want and not worry about running out of money on the card. The metro runs virtually flawlessly and you can easily catch a subway ride or switch lines at stations. There is even an iPhone App now that tells you the fastest way to get from point A to point B. The subway lines are color coded and easy to remember. The App makes it even easier. In the old days, I carried a subway map to be sure I knew how to best travel. There will still be plenty of walking because when you get to your destination, you’ll need to determine which exit to take to get to your spot. We look up the destination beforehand and it’ll usually tell us what subway exit to take and how to get there. Everyone is very friendly in a subway station and you’ll get plenty of help from local Japanese who want to use their English or the staff. Take the metro – you won’t regret it.

Best Metro System I've Used. Of all the subway systems I've used around the world, this one was probably the easiest. Between the English signs, the smart numbering system they use which makes it so you don't have to remember all the hard to remember station names, the free wifi at every single Metro stop, and finally the companion smartphone app which tells you exactly which stops to use and which transfers to make to get to your destination, it was all just a breeze and a wonderful experience.One thing to note: if you buy a day pass for the Metro, it doesn't apply to the JR line (above ground train system in Tokyo) or the Teio line, which is a separate subway system in Tokyo! The Teio line is much smaller. I just bought the Metro day pass and had no issues; if you need to ride the Teio line it might cost you a few hundred more yen, but it's no big deal. The only thing I needed the Teio line for the entire two days of riding around town was when I went to the Edo Tokyo Museum. Otherwise, the Metro took me everywhere I needed to go, and I didn't need to use the JR line at all.

Amazing. Very efficient and easy way to traverse the city. We always used it to get around and the PASMO card is very easy to use. I thought overall I spent less on travel in Tokyo than in most cities I've been in.

Efficiency in the extreme. It looks complicated and it is as millions travel on the Tokyo Metro every day but it is so clean and well organised that even someone like me with no Japanese and first day in Japan, could cope! The Metro map is well planned, colour coded and every station is numbered so you can track you progress but in addition announcements are made in clear English. If all else fails, ask a local and they are incredibly kind and helpful going out of their way to help even in the rush hour, on their way to work - cannot fault them or their Metro system.Once you have achieved your planned route, you do feel proud and ready for the next adventurous journey but do buy a PASMO card.

Buy the PASMO card!. Don't even fart around with tickets or day passes, buy the PASMO card and be done with it. 500 yen deposit and then throw 2000-3000 on the thing, don't waste your time any other way.Shockingly, the system is not as nice as I expected it to be.With multiple companies running multiple lines, it is very easy to get confused and difficult to figure out your way. Your map may not have all the stations listed on it, and you may need to leave your station, walk outside and across the street to get to the same station for a different line. I was in Tokyo for three days and was only just understanding how it all worked. Tokyo station, is absolutely insane!! Some of the stations, while clean, are showing their age and can use some TLC. Oh, and it is expensive compared to other metro's in the world, I spent more than I intended just bouncing around Tokyo for a few days.Shanghai metro I understood in a few minutes, London a few minutes, Toronto a few minutes, the only people who think the Tokyo system is easy and the locals and tourists who have been there for a few days/weeks. Hence if you use the PASMO card, you don't have to worry about making a mistake. All that being said, use the Metro, get a map, get an app, and use it. You will make mistakes, you will have to back track, you will make wrong turns, but there is no better way around Tokyo.

Expensieve!!! and generaly nothing more to say about.... Well. Stations are ok. Nothing speciall or different. I never seen them as more nice or cleaner. Just the same like other cities, like in Toronto or in Berlin. But I find every single ride super expensieve - so I generally don't like this experience.

Punctual to d second !!. One of d most clean stations I've seen in d world.. Much better than ones in Europe Nd us.. Trains are too good.. On time.. Everything is so easy and nice..Get d daily pass.for 750 yen if u gonna travel a lot . Otherwise one way ticket to any destinations is around 170 yen.. Pretty decent...

Japanese efficiency . I am giving full marks to Tokyo metro. And I have a reason for the same. This perhaps would be the best as well as the most efficient public transport system in the world. Used the metro system for whole 3 days. Efficient, effective and very very cost effective as compared to a taxi. All signage is in English too, so not knowing the language is not a handicap. Cheers

Can Buy 24 Hr. Tourist Ticket At Hotel. I purchased a 24 hour Tokyo subway pass at my hotel for 800 yen that gave me unlimited travel. Of course as a one way trip could be 170 yen you need a few trips in the period to made it worthwhile. Ticket machines and visual signs in cars are in English. Stations are numbered so you just need to figure what number station you need to get off of on what line. There is also smartphone app that is in English that is helpful.

Best metro in the world. A child from Sweden with very moderate English could find its way forward more easily in Tokyo than in Stockholm. Extremely clear signs, both above and under ground (in both Japanese and English of course) and very clear route maps that are impossible to misunderstand, even if you consider the enormous size of the network. You'll never have to wait more than 2-3 minutes and the trains are not more packed than in Europe. Watch and learn, world.

Convenient to visit Tokyo. I wanted to write a short recommendation about the metro tokyo for travellers who will go to Tokyo but read that there are already so many reviews on this topic, then I will keep mine short. Generally speaking, the metro in Tokyo is the best way to visit the city. There are 2 companies, JR and M, and there are totally separated and you will have to purchase different tickets depending where you want to go to. I was in the Prince hotel Shinagawa and had to purchase a JR single ticket at 140 yens to go to the next station where the M metro is, and then use my daily M ticket (fare=1000 yens). Both metros are very clean and crowdy. It takes a bit of time to understand how it works, let's say a couple of hours, and when you are familiar with it, you like it very much as it allows to go and visit conveniently any nice place in Tokyo.

Easy to use - get a PASMO. The Tokyo Metro system is so easy to use. Highly recommend getting a PASMO. It is a prepaid train ticket - so no need to calculate train fares. Just swipe and enter. PASMO is accepted on JR lines and even the Disney monorail.

must try!. tokyo metro has many line. Remember to check carefully the places that you wants to visit. Best is check the color and platform that you wants to go! it never go late,the train is very puncture!

Can't fault it. It's getting a little old, but the Tokyo Metro is insanely efficient, and one of the best in the world. I'd just recommend to travelers to know which exit to take! Once you get off the train, it's a bit disorientating to know which direction to leave - so find a map and walk towards the right exit - because the labyrinth of some of these metro stations could take you a few kilometres in the wrong direction! Particularly Shinjuku, Shibuya and Tokyo stations. I got lost a few times in train stations, gave up trying to find my exit and had some great food! There are hundreds, if not thousands of underground restaurants in Tokyo, and they're all delicious!

Efficient, but here are some tips!. I an't be the only person who finds it hilarious that the subway system is the #5 thing to do in Tokyo; you really don't have a choice in using it because it's the best way to get around! But here are some tips and insight I picked up during my recent (and first!) trip to Tokyo:-Tokyo has 2 separate subway companies. Yes, you read that right. It's not like in the States where it's one city-run system. In Japan, there's two, and they're completely separate: the first one is Japan Rail (abbreviated JR) that runs throughout the entire country, and the second is Tokyo Metro (their logo looks like a weird letter M) that runs only throughout Tokyo.-If you have the Japan Rail Pass, it ONLY works with JR lines. I got around fine with just the JR lines; they are plenty and run to most places in the city.-If you don't have the Japan Rail Pass, or have the pass and find a Tokyo Metro line to be more convenient, fares are surprisingly affordable, so have no fears!Purchasing tickets:-If you have the Japan Rail Pass, simply show your pass to the Gate Attendant either to the far left or right of the turnstiles/entry points. That's it!-Otherwise, you have to purchase a ticket from one of the automated machines. Everyone machine I've used has a button that says 'English' on it. Otherwise, just input your money, press the button that states the correct amount you want for your ticket (ex: press the 140 button if you want a ticket with a fare of 140 yen), and your change and ticket will be dispensed.-To find our your fare, you have to look at the map that's usually above the ticket machine. I found the map to be pretty tricky to understand, so here's a tip: use Google Maps! Most stations have free wifi you can use, so punch in where you want to go with Google Maps, find the train line and transfers you want to use, and Google Maps will display a 'fare' at the bottom of the page. They ALWAYS display the correct fare, surprisingly! -If you're paranoid like me, I recommend finding a wifi spot early in the day and looking up your routes and fares. Then, either screenshot or write down the lines and fares you want to use. That way, in case you're in a station that doesn't have wifi, you're plenty prepared!-I would suggest avoiding taking the subway between 8-9AM and 5-6PM. That is Tokyo rush hour, and things go BERSERK. Rush hour and spill over into 10AM and 7PM, but it won't be as bad as those key pre/post-work hours. If you get caught in rush hour, don't panic, it's not a horrible situation. But be prepared to get real close to strangers. There's also a problem in Japan of men groping women on packed trains, so please be weary of that if you're riding a train in rush hour. It's not common or prevalent by any means, but it is an issue, so please do watch out. Some trains have women-only cars to mitigate this problem if you're truly worried or encounter a strange situation.Some pointers of Japanese society I thought I'd share because I wasn't warned about them before I went:-Japanese society is very orderly. So orderly, that to properly board a train/subway, you must fine your train line on the floor of the platform (they're usually color-coordinated, so match the colored line with the color of your train), and line up behind it. You'll see others doing the same. This way, it's not a mad rush to board the train; people enter in a nice and orderly line! If there's a big crowd exiting the train onto your platform, the lines will usually move out of the way towards the side of the train doors (while still maintaining line order), and wait for everyone to disembark before embarking themselves. The orderliness will astound you.-If you're a "foreigner," meaning not of Japanese decent and not speaking in Japanese, people WILL stare at you. It's not a matter of 'if they stare at me'. No. They will stare. My friend told me this was more prevalent in the countryside than in Tokyo, but no, Tokyo subway riders were pretty obvious about their staring as well. Don't think of it at rudeness; it's just a different culture who likes to stare I guess. There's no malice. I suppose they're just fascinated by foreigners. And they show their fascination by staring.-Another thing about subway riders: If you get a seat, and you're sitting next to a Japanese person, they will likely switch seats away from you. Not sure why, but it's happened enough for me to notice that the Japanese don't like sitting on the train next to foreigners. You can see it as a positive (more room!) or negative (how rude!), but how you take it is up to you; just take it as it is.-It's considered 'rude' to eat or drink while riding public transportation! You will rarely see someone drinking a soda or taking a bite of something on the train. My friend explained that it's to avoid possibly spilling someone on someone's nice business suit/dress, which makes sense. So beware of even more staring if you're consuming something on board!I hope this helps, and gives you a nice run down of what to expect on the subway system. Happy travels!

Best in the world. Over the past year I have traveled on the Tokyo Metro several times a week. It is clean, safe, vast, and punctual - far better than any other city on earth. Trust me, I have been on most of them over the years. Any route within the greater Tokyo area can be figured out by asking Google Maps. You will be told what stations, what routes, what platforms, time duration, and how to get from exactly where you are now. Get a Pasmo card at any of the stations and use it effortlessly to enter and exit. All stations have both escalators and elevators so accessibility is no problem. Almost all have clean, safe restrooms.
Very easy to use. We used the metro for all our sightseeing and found it very easy and efficient to use. The instructions are in English. We used a sucia card and it was easy to charge and use.

Efficient and easy!. I have never used public transport to this degree before, but I found myself quickly getting used to the maps and Metro procedures. I really appreciate how well handled and efficient it all is! Do not be scared if you are new to traveling on public transportation, you'll get used to it and it'll be great. Also, suica and pasmo cards are phenomenal. Get one if you're going to be using public transportation often.

Confusing but great fun! . Went on a quest to find the legendary Pokemon centre in sunshine city ,ikebururo , after catching the Wrong line and looking very confused ,we were approach by ,possibly the most helpful lady I have every met, not only did she give us direction but went out of her way to take us to the straight to the mall , this is just one of many experience of extreme politeness I've encountered on this trip. Could not thank her enough!

Really easy to use - highly recommend!. Best way to get round the city, it's quick, less crowded than you would expect and good value for money. The machines let you choose your language and then choose the destination and off you go!

The best way to get around. The map for the metro system in Tokyo can be incredibly overwhelming! I downloaded an app called City Rail Map that let you select where you want to go and it'll tell you which trains to get on.If your not familiar with the trains and the stations, buy tickets at the kiosk instead of using your passmo or suica cards so you can verify that you can get to your desired station from where you are.The trains are sometimes incredibly packed, but if you avoid rush hour you'll have no problem finding a seat. It's clean and quiet. Station attendants are also very helpful, but I found few who could speak English.

Best Train system!. The trains are very clean and efficient. they have enough signage to guide you through changing of lines. it is almost impossible to get lost as long as you follow the signage. Our group were able to tour Tokyo prefecture by just using Japan's railway.
Efficient. Very efficient train system! We can go to different places in Tokyo in just a nick of time. We have covered many touristy spots in just 5 days.

complete novice's opion. My partner is English and very well traveled, i on the other hand have never been on a train or subway.We traveled all over southern Japan and Tokyo by rail without a word of language , never at any stage was there a problem the ease of understanding and color coding was amazing (and we are both well over 60) even my partner was highly impressed the people of Japan were outstanding , as soon as we pulled out a map or book some-one would come up and offer help ( not officials, just especially young people) embarrassed me for my own people. Just look up at the wall ever-where and you know what to do and wham you are there.

Clean and Reliable. There are two types of train transport. The JR and Subway. The subway is for a quick way to any place in Tokyo while JR (According to my Lonely Planet) is a cross Japan rail. JR Yamanote is the top with top sights near it's stations. JR also offers other cities and nearby places like Nikko, Yokohama or Mt. Fuji.

Clean, efficient, reliable. The Tokyo metro is the best way to get around town, certainly the cheapest compared to taxis.There are a lot of lines, including non-metro lines run by JR. This can make getting from A to B a bit more complicated as you cannot always get a single ticket. The best way around this is to get a PASMO card which is a smartcard you can charge up and it does the working out of fares, which will save you money and time as well as confusion!The metro stations are well signposted but you do need to keep your wits about you as at times the line interchanges can involve quite long walks.Definitely the only way to get around the city.
Great way of transport in Tokyo.. Incredibly efficient way of transport in Tokyo. The best way is to buy 72 hours ticket for 1500 yen. Of course sometimes in rush hours it can be very crowded.

72 hour pass. Once arrived at the airport in Tokyo we bought a 72 hour subway pass. The subway is super clean and there were a lot less people than I expected. However I am glad my friend kept track of the places we were going as the metro is super confusing. When you have to change trains you have to walk a lot and I never understood anything. But with that said the metro will take you anywhere.

So clean, so simple. We had a guide on day one of our visit to Tokyo who helped us to orientate... But the system is so well organised it was easy to get the hang of it.We were there in "Golden Week" - a national holiday when many of Tokyo's workers take a few days off... So the tube was less busy than normal. Immaculately clean, feels completely safe. Get a "Manaca" card (like a London Oyster card) and travel with complete ease!

Easy to use!. I think the metro in Tokyo is really easy to use as long as you know where you're going. I had used an online tube planner before going and whilst I was in Tokyo everything was so well laid out and sign posted there was never a problem getting about.

A good easy to use Metro. If you are from a place where there is not an extensive metro network then I can see the attraction in using the Tokyo Metro, otherwise its just a way of getting around.Before going to Tokyo I watched on Youtube and read blogs about it being difficult to use the Metro. I found it very easy to use, a few arrows pointing in confusing directions as a previous reviewer mentioned (same as on overground train stations in Japan), but overall a great way to get around the city.Theres a pre-paid card you can buy to save buying a ticket every journey, but we just paid at a machine each time. Above the machines there should be a map in English, find your station and the cost you have to pay will be next to it. Most machines have English option too.2 apps to download which helped us loads:Hyperdia - For journey planner / times / platforms / bullet trainTokyosubway - For network map and displays route info on map

Complicated but convenient. I was impressed with how complicated the metro system. However, there is an app for this and it's very convenient. The trains are generally punctual but they get really crowded during rush hours. It's pretty worth the experience unless you are claustrophobic.

Not too complicated to use, but crowded. The signs everywhere and organization make it not too hard to use the metro, and the trains are quite timely. People stand in lines to get on the train, and it's usually not too difficult to find your way around...though I've gotten temporarily lost before. It's just really big, and there's the occasional sign that points in an awkward direction. Overall, though, the main negative is how crowded it is; during rush hour, the Tokyo metro can get pretty packed. I hope you like being packed into a sardine can. :D

chaotic. If you are new to this city, the metro stations can be very chaotic during peak hours, when you stand in the train, you really do not need to hold anything, because there are lots of people already squeezed to you.

Convenient but chaotic. Tokyo public transportation is really great and efficient, but it's usually super crowded. If you are claustrophobic, you should figure on another type of transportation. The videos and pictures of Tokyo are true. You will prob not have your own space/personal bubble

A MUST. One of the biggest most organised metros I've ever been to...its massive but easy to use...lots of helpful signs everywhere...and the workers there are very helpful...in two days you will find out that you automatically turned into an organised japanese citizen...it teaches discipline...respect...and practicality...one of the best experiences while in tokyo

Pretty good. The trains were always on time and the trains and stations are relatively clean (they get a bit worse on the outskirts stations) The signs can be a bit of a pain for exits, they sometimes just stop and there are multiple ways to go....... But other than that, tickets are easy to buy (Just get a passmo) and the lines are simple to work out.

Best metro system in the world. What more can I say? Trains are always on time, efficiency is impeccable and there really isn't a better way to get around Tokyo. A day pass for all zones in Tokyo is around 900 yen which is a steal. The train stations themselves are a great place to shop and eat as most the big ones are practically malls. I was traveling with a 10 month old in a stroller and the fact that they have stroller priority cars was an absolute blessing, it would have been impossible to get around if it weren't for them as the it can get REALLY crowded. It goes pretty much every in Tokyo and you are never more then 30 min away from your destination. The maps are easy to read and signs are very helpful in directing you. IF you get lost, ask one of the employees at any station, they usually speak good english and can tell you exactly where to go. We barely ever got lost and always managed to get where we want to go. Highly recommended form of transportation, don't even think about getting cabs as they are slower and extremely over priced. Only case to take a cab is if you are traveling with luggage and need to get to one of the Shinkansen (bullet train) stations to travel to other cities.

Convenient network to go everywhere just by it!. They have convenient, complicated, and great transportation network.You can go everywhere you want to go in Tokyo.Btw, they have some nice tickets for tourists now!I bought the 3-day pass for subway this time. It help me the save lots of money
Very easy to use. Great system with all signs in english. If you get fares wrong you can adjust them at any station when you leave. Staff at all stations to help

Easy to get around. The entire Tokyo public transportation system is easy to use and efficient. Most subway and train cars have English translations for stops and there are English directions in the stations---not detailed but enough to get by. There is almost always someone who you can ask directions of in English and get help.The system is also incredibly clean; no trash and no graffiti.

Fast efficient service. Tokyo Metro is one of the main players after JR-East in Tokyo for your transportation needs. Numerous line to many attractions or just exploring. I find the Ginza line offers the most attraction that are within walking distance from their stations. Saves on transfers between train lines; some stops of interest is Shibuya, Nihombashi, Ginza, Ueno and Asakusa for attractions.
An eye opener!. You must use the metro if you are in Tokyo! I was so amazed with how their system works. The train are almost always on time. It also very clean....

Amazingly efficient subway . Before our trip, we have read reports of how efficient the system is. Now that we have witnessed it ourselves, it is not hard to understand why. There are so many lines and every place is so well connected. Every train arrives on time. You can always expect the train to be clean and quiet (there's a sign to discourage making calls on hand phone while in the train). A suggestion here, if you don't take many rides in a day, I would suggest getting the normal PASMO card that locals use instead of the various day pass for tourists. Not that the day pass is not good, but you would need to take many rides in a single day to make it worthwhile, and it's normally restricted to certain lines.

Works well and is inexpensive. The ticket machines have an English language option and accept cards, or cash. Announcements are in English as well as Japanese and the tube map is also in both languages. Gets crowded in the rush hour, but no worse than London.
An Experience in the Rush. Fast and efficient, travelling the Metro is easy when you understand it. Not as well sign posted as Singapore's MRT but still navigatable. Try to avoid the rush hour.

The subway system takes you everywhere in Tokyo.. Believe me! You need to learn how to take this metro system. I sill don't know how to take the bus system very clearly, but the metro system is easy to learn.

Trains that run everywhere - on time.. You really don't need a car in Tokyo - the subway, busses, and trains will take you everywhere. Even though they may be crowded, people are polite and - surprisingly - don't push.

Super uber efficient . The metro system is definitely daunting. It can be quite intimidating but after a few days, it is very easy to navigate. Your system is quite efficient. Getting from point a to point B can be somewhat complicated but there are many helpful people who speak English.

Easy to use and very efficient. With a map and knowing the station and line you are going to makes the metro really cheap and an easy way to get around Tokyo. The one time I got confused a lovely local gentleman helped. You do need to know both the line and the station. Google is also very helpful as it tells you where you need to change but the maps on their own we're fine and easy to understand. It looks daunting but really isn't.
Amazing network. The best way to go almost everywhere in Tokyo. Just expend some time learning the maps and how it works. It is worth buying a day pass.

Don't try to understand the metro map by yourself. If you try to understand the metro map of Tokyo you'll be confused so it's better to ask somebody before boarding the train.If there is a change in your final Journey then ask which platform to take for first journey, and where to get off.After getting off, now ask someone for your final destination, which platform and time of train

Daunting but an absolute must to use.. You simply can visit Tokyo and not use the metro...it is the best I have been on anywhere in the world. Reliable, efficient and comprehensive.Yes it is daunting at first...but take your time..look for the signs and utilise a map. One suggestion. Take the address you are heading towards..written in Japanese.

Complicated but very efficient. I have been on many subway systems throughout the world and I found Tokyo's is the most complicated. After commuting three days I am still lost even at right station, right line, and right lane lol. I do not dare to look at the maps it so complex. However equipped with Google map it will help provided you make sure you board the train at Exact time as earlier or later might not stop at your station.  The trains in Tokyo are expensive as well. Trains are clean , very crowded at peak hours but commuter are very discipline. They que, if the que is too long there are another line for queuing. No body talk on the phone or eating.

Efficient and Widely Used. You could set a watch by the metro timetable. They seem to arrive often and on time. Yes they do become crowded and that is actually a good thing as it means less car traffic. The train cars and stations are always spotless and boarding is always orderly. Passengers tend to be quiet, polite and considerate. Signage is provided in English too.

Craziness!. I'm from Texas, where personal space isn't given a second thought, so this experience for me was eye opening. I've ridden many metro systems around the world, but this was by far the busiest. The stations are all spotless, most of them have tasty restaurants and shopping, and they're practically cities unto themselves. Plus the experience of witnessing rush hour on the Tokyo metro is one you won't soon forget!

Yes it is weird to review a train system..... The maps look like a plate of spaghetti but look at google maps put in your location and destination and it is all easy! Also the station staff are very helpful. Even if they don't speak English they can pick up what station you are attempting to pronounce. We had a JR pass and a preloaded Suica pass so it was easy. Hint: if you have a JR pass don't use your Suica! You are already covered. We had a 2 week JR pass and travelled to many destinations, we found it very easy to navigate and the pass was detain,y worthwhile.

Wide network but challenging.. (This is a review of the trains in general including JR Rail) I have been on many subway systems throughout the world and I found Tokyo's to be one of the hardest to navigate. Part of the trouble is that there are many lines and they do not all connect. In fact many do not. You might consult a comprehensive map and realize you are on a different system. Once you figure that out it becomes easier I finally found an app that worked quite well to navigate everything. The trains in Tokyo are extremely expensive as well you can easily spend $30+ a day if you are busy. The Suica cards make things easy on payment and can be used for other things as well. Don't expect to just jump in and look at the map on the train, if you prepare and get a good routing app you will probably be fine.Trains are clean but can be very crowded- get ready to be crushed into other people if you travel at peak times and don't expect to sit often.

Very very conplicated. We came here with very little knowledge of what we were getting ourselves in to. It's a very complex metro system and very difficult to maneuver if you don't speak the language. We luckily found someone who spoke English, but very few people in Japan do so I wouldn't count on it. I would make sure you know exactly what trains you need to get on or you will more than likely get lost!

Tokyo Metro is just cool.. We used to the Tokyo Metro system to get around Tokyo when staying here and we found it to be the most efficient and easy to use public transportation system we've ever used. Don't be fooled by the horrifically complicated map, it's super easy to use if you arm yourself with Google Maps, and a PASMO card. The PASMO IC card is a prepaid cash card that will allow you to tap on, off, and between stations while moving about without putting much thought into the whole process at all. For a 7 day stay we spent around ¥10,000 which paid for a tonne of daily travel all over the place plus connections to and from Narita International Airport.

Organised, timely and busy!. We travelled throughout Tokyo using the underground and Jr rail lines. An amazing number of stations and routes but extremely efficient. The best way to get around this very busy and interesting city.

Very efficient, safe, clean. It's odd to review a subway system, but here goes. It's all very efficient and fast. Some lines are very deep underground, but most stations have elevators and escalators. The trick to riding, if you have to transfer lines is to learn which are the best stations to transfer at, since lines intersect at multiple stations. One could walk across a platform, or at worst, walk nearly a kilometer underground to transfer. Another hint. Look at the maps at the stations to decide which exit to go to ground level from. Otherwise, one could, again, be quite far from where one wants to be. Japanese people don't talk on cell phones, or eat, or drink on commuter trains. Let's keep it that way.

As good as in London. Everyone in Europe heard the scary stories about the Tokyo metro, how the have people at the platforms purely to push people in to get the doors to close. This is absolutely not the case luckily. Its well-organised and easy to use as a tourist. A day pass is ¥1000. Travelled with it all day. Even though is didn't make use of it in the middle of rush hour, it was never overcrowded.

Perfect way to get around!. This is the best way to get around. You can buy a day pass for 1000 Yen, its by every metropolitan line and the pink machines. There is also a tube map in English that you can get at information disk.

Tokyo Metro. At first looks really complicated, but its not. The staff has no english but they will help you somehow, so go and asked them. One more thing, every station has free wifi. So look for the free wifi to get the most of Tokyo.Tickets I found them cheap enough, they were 180¥, 200¥ and if you want a day pass Metro and JR (japan rail) 1000¥.

Busiest transit system ever. Purchased a Japan rail pass while still in the USA, $250 for a week. When I got to the Tokyo main rail station, you REALLY need to know where you are going. There at leastFour DIFFERENT rail lines operate in Tokyo. (I know?). Main one is Tokyo metro line.Then JR Rail. Toei line and the Tokyo monorail. A gazillion people travel these lines,English is displayed.....AND the agents are helpful as well. Good luck!

Easy to get around. Fear not, you can easily navigate the Tokyo Metro system, everything is written in Japanese and English. There is free wifi in the larger tourist type stations and maps are also available in English to help you navigate.It is clean, the people are polite and in a city the size of Tokyo it is a relatively quick way to get around.

FEAR NOT! You can navigate and use the Tokyo Metro. There are a LOT of subway lines, but they are really easy to navigate. You can get a map with English station identifications. The most difficult thing I found was figuring out prices. So a Japanese friend suggested I buy a farecard. There is a Suica card and a Pasmo card. They both work on the subway. You buy them from machines. Look for one that takes cash if that's how you are paying, and look for the "English" button. Basically, you tell the machine that you need a new card, and put in money. I started with 1000 yen. They charge you a 500 yen deposit for the card and put the rest on the card for rides. Personally, I always end up with a pocket full of coins, as the smallest banknote is the equivalent of about US$ 9. So I go to a Pasmo machine, tell it I want to re-charge the card, dump my excess coins (except for 1 and 5 Yen coins, and the heavy coins are transformed into value on the card. The nice thing about the card is that it isn't only useful on the subway. You can use it to pay for things in the thousands of convenience stores you find everywhere.And speaking of everywhere, that's where the subways can take you. You may have to change trains, but the signs are there and easy to follow. One suggestion is to figure out from maps which exit you need -- some stations have 5 or more, and you want to pop out of the subway at the right place. In conclusion, you won't find a better way to get around Tokyo, although I will admit I don't use it during rush hours when they have "pushers" to stuff people in so the doors can close, but with that exception, go to it!

Convenient way to travel around tokyo. This is the most efficient way to travel in Tokyo. Everything is very clean and organised. Very convenient.If you lose your way, just ask- Japanese are a helpful bunch. You can choose "English" language when purchasing you tickets at the machines- so it is pretty much idiot proof.

prompt and clean!. The subway system in Tokyo is great - easy to navigate, very clean and punctual. it is more expensive than in NYC and is not 24hr, so that only two negatives, but overall, it is great!

Easy to understand and use. For new travelers or short-term visitors, I recommend you get the Suica card to avoid the hassle of buying tickets and worrying about how much it will cost. There is a 500 yen deposit from which you get back 280 yen, the rest 220 is the commission. Totally worth it.

Amazing Organisation. The transport of 12 million people on a regular basis is a daunting task. To do it on time and covering almost every part of this city is remarkable. Usually crowded, but so it's Tokyo, it could be relied on without fail. I had no Japanese but the train lines are colored and the stations numbered. The first time I used the subway at Shinjuku station, an attendant near the information desk, came over to us, printed out a sheet in English on which trains to catch, and assisted us in using the ticket machine. From that moment on we could hit the English button on the ticket machine and everything became straightforward. Probably the best public transport system in the world.

Limited English, very confusing, Chinese cities are WAY better. The only good thing I can think of about the Tokyo metro is how cheap it is. It is VERY confusing and the process of buying tickets is ABSURD. Unlike most metros in the world, you do not actually choose your destination, you choose how much money to pay. So first you figure out where your destination is and the cost of that from where you are, which is not easy looking at the gigantic map if you're unfamiliar with the city. Also most metros, when you are inside the car it will show the map of JUST THE LINE YOU ARE ON as well as a map of the whole city. Not in Tokyo, it only shows the whole city with every single station in tiny font. Very disappointing. Every Chinese city I have been to has a much better metro system, I'm not sure why this one is famous...
One of the best public transportation . Very economical one of the best we have used world wide. Complicated but with practice very easy to use. Fast and clean very polite and safe.

travle cheap around tokyo. some people always say japan is very expansive and u need allot of money to go from A to B that's true if u use taxi to move around but if u really want to enjoy ur trip to Tokyo and save allot of money going arounfd Tokyo and other cities use the Tokyo metro its always on time and super clean and very cheap but to make it even easier as soon as u arrine to japan in (NRT) airport buy suica card its a prepaid card that u can use in Tokyo metro and even in some vending machines

Truly a massive train stations. The train stations and their lines are very confusing..a lot of people taking trains and passengers are very polite and truly they give respect to each other... You should bring map in order for you not to get lost...

Fast way to explore Tokyo. We used the metro as our main mode of transportation in Tokyo. It is very well organized and managed like expected. The trains are spotless, on time and safe even though the trains and stations are not new.We also never experienced very crowded trains and I assume we were just lucky in this regard.

Try Tokyo Metro free app on your phone!. Enjoyed riding Tokyo Metro with this app - it supports English, Chinese, Korean, Thai and Japanese.
