It is highly recommended for visitors sight-seeing in Tokyo.This application displays the main route, time required, and fares in a simple easy to understand format. It made the trip so much easier! You can stop worrying about navigating the huge number of subway exits, and simply relax and enjoy using the subway to sightsee around Tokyo. Well recommended.

Imposing and efficient. The Tokyo subway is pretty efficient for getting around, but generally lacks the charisma that is occasionally either associated with or built into other stations elsewhere. Most of the stations look nearly identical, hardly an omnibologist's dream.

One of the most stunning train systems I have ever ridden!! Truly well designed!!. One of the most stunning train systems I have ever ridden!! Truly well designed!!There are so many ppl but the trains are so quick and efficient that most bottlenecks are handled by the system itself ... the automated alerts and screens telling you what station you are arriving at are a great help.

Best way to get around Tokyo.. Tokyo is a really enormous city, the Metro is clean and efficient. but very confusing. get yourself a map in English, most of the stations are named in English and Japanese, but many other things are only written in Japanese. buying your ticket is confusing, as the ticket machines are only written in Japanese, some of the stations are enormous, Shinjuku is the largest and busiest station in the world, with millions passing through it every day, there are many entrances and exits and many underground passages to get lost in.so you need lots of confidence. also try to avoid the rush hours. Japans trains are world famous for being crowded, there are so many people they have staff to push you into the trains, force packed making is difficult to breathe. Tokyo is one of the most crowded cities in the world, and when you try the train in the rush hour you realise what they say is true. however at other times, its fast clean and efficient.
It's a Subway Train!. Easiest way to get around central Tokyo. Very frequent trains, clean and often crowded. Simple enough to follow and always staf on hand to help if needed

Never wait more than 30 seconds . One of, if not, the most efficient subway in the world. The best way to move around Tokyo. Download the free Tokyo subway app for tourists. Anyone who thinks this subway is confusing probably hasn't taken a subway. Best part, aside from never waiting more than 30 seconds, is the simple letter and number designation for each stop. For example, "G12" means Ginza line station 12. If this is where you're going, all you have to remember is G12, vs the full stop name: Mitsukoshimae. G12 or Mitsukoshimae - which would you rather remember? Perfection!
Very clean and efficient . Very clean and on time. All announcements heard were in English as well as Japanese and very cheap to use. Avoid at peak of rush hour as will be very busy.

A fine example of poetry in motion. Very well run, super clean and well sign posted. Even though everything is in Japanese with no English subtitles, we figured our way round quite easily as the system is very logical. Trains run on time and frequent.

The music!. We took the metro every day in Tokyo and the thing that stayed with us was the lovely music at every station. Maybe people in Tokyo are already used to the cute jingles that play once the metro arrives and leaves, but we were surprised by them every time. We even started recognizing some of them.

Easy to navagate!. We took the metro once we were in the city and it was very easy to navigate. I used to live in Tokyo and I had forgotten how easy it was to get around the city by train. There are tons of pictures and route maps all over the station so it's hard to get lost. Plus, the people are so nice and very willing to help if you get overwhelmed. Definitely take the train!

Very clean, efficient and didnt wait more than 2 minutes for metro. Used the metro for one whole day in Tokyo, was fairly easy to navigate as there are English tube maps. Stations are very clean. Trains are frequent and on time

Definitely confusing with different companies operating throughout system. Takes a wee bit of getting used to as different types of track and the same types of track are operated by different companies with different tickets and ticketing system. Once you've cracked it, it's a clean, quick, efficient system which is actually a total pleasure to use. Toilets everywhere also - great.
Terrific Transportation. The Tokyo Metro is easy, fast, clean and efficient. We were able to see so much in such a short time there by using the metro.

Don't be Afraid.. It looks very daunting before you arrive but it is quite easy to navigate. I was quite surprised that even during peak hours it still worked very well.Yes it was busy but not a paniced busy everyone was still very polite and considerate.I can only wish our trains here ran as smoothly as there's.

So easy. Fantastic!. I used the Tokyo Metro loads whilst in Tokyo with some friends in August 2015. It is so easy to use! And it goes everywhere. We used a JR Card which is like an Oyster Card in London, simply top up and go! The trips are cheap, the trains are always bang on time, it is simply the best, and cheapest, and fastest, and easiest way to get around the biggest city on Earth!

Efficient way to get around town . We have mainly used the green JR line but it's so great to get around town. Once you get the hang of the ticket system, hopping on and off trains is super simple. There is one every few minutes. It's not great if you have luggage but there are luggage lockers at some stations to store stuff.

Clean, Efficient, Useful. Getting around Tokyo we primarily walked or used the metro, and I would recommend the metro to anyone. It is clean and efficient, and there are regular stops across the city. As much as we enjoyed walking and seeing the sights, Tokyo is massive and you will need some way of travelling between districts. Although there is a bus service in the city we never used it because the trains run so often and are so convenient.Our tour operator booked us some IC cards (we had a Manaca card instead of a Suica or Pasmo) and they were waiting for us in our ticket packs. These can be used across different services in Japan, including buses and vending machines, and they are so incredibly useful; definitely get one if you are going to be in Japan for any length of time, because they are so convenient to use.

Fantastic Upkeep. A great way to travel around Tokyo. Make sure you are armed with subway map. Over the years more English instructions have been introduced to help visitors and foreign residents. Punctual and clean. Unlike other metro, I've not met any breakdown so far in my 33 years of visit to Japan. Unless you will be in the move frequently there is no need to buy a pass. Do correlate with the Tokyo city map. Sometimes it is better to walk in the nice weather than wind around in subway system just to reach a location that is just less than 3-5 km away. Besides, walking is a good exercise and great way to take the sights and sound in. Key is research snd planning.
Punctual. Nearly never late. Easy to use and cheap for tourists. Buy a day card from any Big Camera store. You have English names below Japanese names on the map.

Best Way to Get Around. Now Tokyo Metro has so many lines deep underground. Many stations are connected underground, but sometimes the underground passage is very long. So I always check first where to change trains.
Very Useful. The Tokyo Metro system is the best way to travel around the city. The Metro is always on time to the nearest second and is very well run.

The best way to get around Tokyo. To put it simply, there is really no other way to travel in Tokyo. Combined with the Toei Line, the metro system of Tokyo act as the veins of the city, transporting droves of people to all sorts of districts. It truly is an experience in itself.Trains are never late. Ever. And when they are, it's a big deal! The punctuality of the trains was entirely refreshing from the constantly late public transport we have in Scotland. A train is also close by when entering a station, so you never have to wait for long.In terms of prices, it is dirt cheap. Literally pennies to travel across the city. I'd recommend just using a single ticket if you're only travelling to a single destination that day. Pick up an all-day pass for either the Tokyo Metro, Toei Metro or both for ¥700 and ¥1000 respectively if you plan on doing a lot of train-hopping on a specific day. You'll save some cash!The system seems very confusing on first glance – on our first visit the night before we travelled anywhere, it was completely overwhelming. This passes however, and you'll be a professional by the end of day 2. If you have an iPhone, make sure to download the Tokyo Metro guide app which shows you all connections required to get from point A to B as well as the price. It is invaluable when it comes to getting around! Even better, it works offline so for travellers without roaming data, it's all there without a connection.

Buy a Pasmo card and travel will be easier. If you are only staying in Tokyo, buy a Pasmo rechargeable card. There is a 500 yen charge but when a person is finished with the card, go to the office and the 500 yen and whatever is left on the card will be reimbursed. Each person needs their own card. We were surprised that quite a few of the rides were under $3 or less. We were in Tokyo between Christmas and New Years and the metro did not seem busy at all. At the busiest stations, there were uniformed workers making sure that people were able to get on and off the train without any problems. There was never any pushing or budging to get on or off the train. Also, the stops were in both Japanese and in English. The trains were very clean and we always felt safe.At some stations, there were some wonderful small restaurants in which we tried their sushi. Don't be intimidated by the subway because it is well organized, signs in English and an overall better system than many cities throughout the world.

Insane & exciting. For those of us who live in cities with frustrating, unreliable public transport systems, Tokyo is an absolute dream. In most places throughout Tokyo, you're no more than a few hundred metres from a station, and trains run regularly, even at night and on weekends. With a pass (such as a 3-day subway pass), it's easy to get around, though for extended stays, a rechargeable smart card would be preferable. Once you work out how to transfer between lines or to non-subway lines, then you'll know not to try and exit through certain gates.However, with two young children (one in a stroller), it can be quite difficult to navigate the subway, particularly with making changes to other lines. Exiting can also be a big hassle, as many stations still have stairs, escalators only going one way, and either no lift or one far away from where you need to be. Doing some research on the station beforehand is therefore important, while keeping in mind that some inconvenience might still occur.

Dominate the Tokyo metro with a Suica or Pasmo. A little confusing at first, but you'll totally pick it up on your second day if you get a Suica or Pasmo card.I cannot recommend this highly enough. I've done it both ways (tickets and ic card), and it's so much easier with a IC card. Get them at the airport train station or from any ticket machines in the subway. You can even use them on a bunch of vending machines. If you do this, moving around Tokyo using the Metro lines will be easy. You will dominate.
Efficient and convenient. Bought a day pass and went about Tokyo with no hassle. Easy and efficient means of transport bringing you around Tokyo.

Fastest way to move around. If you want to move around Tokyo, look no more, Tokyo metro is the best option.Fast and conveniently located stations near most tourist attractions.Get a Suica or Pasmo card to make your trips smoother and cheaper as opposed to paper tickets.Trains turn up very often so don't worry about missing it.Google maps helps you by indicating the the names of stations you'll go through before reaching your destination.Highly recommended.

I wish the US had transportation systems like this. Always on time, connects EVERYTHING! The only down side is that they stop at 1AM - so make sure you are home and don't need to use the train after that time!

Best way to get around and confusing at first. There are several lines, lotsa lotsa lines. Be sure to grab a map. Only the major information kiosks in Shibuya, Shinjuku, and Ginza speak English. You can get anywhere to anywhere, just be mindful that some lines don't connect. You'll have to tap out and pay again to tap in. Get a tap card from any vending station by the metro station. You don't want to have to pay every time. You can get the amount on your tap card refunded at the airport.

Fast, efficient, and clean!. The thing that I love about Japan is that everything is always on time. If something says that it will arrive at a certain time, you can bet that it will arrive on the dot. The only problem that I had with the metro was space. Sometimes you will become extremely claustrophobic, even if you've never had this problem before. I would recommend getting up before the crack of dawn to beat the heavy traffic!

Reliable and runs like clockwork. Compared with the London Underground, the Tokyo Metro is a dream. It runs like clockwork (you can pretty much set your watch by it) and is never down (except if there is an earthquake!). It's not open much later than midnight though, so be careful not to get caught out. One other word of caution for female travellers is that it can have a bad rep. especially during rush hour, for inappropriate touching. Most lines have "female only" carriages (usually the front two carriages) and are marked with big pink stickers to this effect on the windows.

The easiest way to get around Tokyo. Clean, efficient, and cheap the Tokyo Metro is the best way to get from A to B in the Japanese capital in 99% of cases. Be sure to pick up a good map or guide so you can navigate transfers between lines and systems -- but for the most part it is dead simple.One piece of advice -- if you're going to be using the system for at least 3 or 4 days get a Pasmo smart card. It gets rid of buying tickets every day - and that saves tons of time and hassles.

Great way to get around city and also Japan. We used the metro system to get around Tokyo from our Hotel in Shinjuku. A short walk to the station and then we got a Suica Card which is a bit like a Met Card which you can load up with cash and then use for all train travel and also buy food and drink with at most shops and stores so we just loaded up with some yen and then tap and go which was fantasticWe even used it to get a seat (reserved) on the Nosomi Shinkasen (Bullet) train from Tokyo down to Kyoto. This had to be one of the highlights of our trip as we booked Reserved seats which is a MUST, if you don't you may not get a seat and you will have to stand in between the carriages as the unreserved seats are usually only in the first 3 carriages.Oh and book seats I the Green Car as they are better than most business class seats in planes, you will love them. Travelling at an average of 250kms and at times up to 281 kms was fantastic seeing the countryside flick by as we took 2 hours 10 minutes to travel from Tokyo to Kyoto. Then had a day down there before getting back on train and coming back in comfort and in short time.

Helpful to use Google Maps . Tokyo Metro is a great way to get around the city; it can literally take you anywhere. Would definitely recommend using Google Maps to find your route and saving it if you don't have free WiFi. Google maps shows you all the stops and line changes, which makes a commute a piece of cake.
So Complex!. I think Tokyo's metro/public transport is a representative of Japanese advanced technology. Tokyo station is a city beneath another city pretty much!

Navigated with ease. Bought a day pass for the family and downloaded the Tokyo Metro App and found navigating Tokyo with ease. Take note of which entry and exit you take to the stations as it will save you hundreds of metres of walking by taking the right entry point.
Get a SUICA card. This will allow travel in JR routes without the need to keep change on you. Ideal and best way of getting around Tokyo.

Easy. Buy a SUICA card (card wih chip) and load it with money it is much easier and less expensive. Not very easy to load at the machine but friendly staff everywhere. Metro is easy for those who read some English with map and directions.

The only way to roll!. I wanted to mention a few things about the Tokyo Metro subway system. This is one of the best ways to get around Tokyo and there are two things that will make the experience more efficient and more fun.#1 is the Pasmo Subway Pass. I highly recommend purchasing this pre-loads subway at any one of the convenient Pasmo vending machines located in almost every station. You can pre-pay in several amounts, we chose the 1000 yen option (app. $10) and if you run out of credit you can recharge the card as well. Using this card is simple, you just scan on entrance and exit and the fare is deducted. It saves you purchasing tickets for each journey and will save you a ton of time. Pasmo can also be used for buses and some other minor purchases. At the end of your stay you can return the card and get back your 500 yen "deposit".#2 is the Tokyo Metro Subway app for your smartphone. This is a free app that you can use to plan your journey. Just enter the station you are starting at and your destination and the app will tell you the route including any transfers you must make, the time of the journey and the cost. This is an invaluable help as there are over 180 stations in the Tokyo Metro system and some journeys require 2 or 3 transfers.With these 2 tips you will master the subway experience and make all your underground trips quick and efficient!

Tokyo Metro Good Value. We just did 2 days in Tokyo with a family of 4. We used the day passes in the Metro the whole time and it was relatively easy to use and made travel easy. In a few cases where we were unsure the locals and Metro staff were very helpful.

Very efficient and accessible!. The Tokyo metro/subway is always efficient, clean, on time. you can literally access all neighborhoods of Tokyo using its many lines. A bit complicated but you will get familiar with it by time. Get the day pass to save money during your trip.

Clean, on time and safe with helpful and friendly staff. Ann altogether good experience. The staff managed to help us buy tickets, find the right track etc since we do not speak Japanese. Also here the amount of written explanation in English is limited as in most of Japan. However, the helpful staff, and the logic of the map did the trick. As it is efficient, on time, clean and safe, it is worth using,
2 days pass cost only Yen 1200, good value. Metro in Tokyo, pretty much similar location and stop as JR Train, but lots cheaper still can travel lots of locations in two days time.

Best in the world: read on for cheapest way to travel on it. Tokyo metro not only is uber efficient, sparkly clean, well sign posted (but require attention and planning), but is also one of the cheapest metro/ subway systems in the world.First download the free Tokyo Metro and Tokyo transport system maps - you want one which has also JR routes on it (i.e. The very useful Yamanote line).Have also a printed map on you - available at virtually all stations and on all free tourist brochures.You have two key choices: either the Suica/ Pasmo card or day tickets. Search for Tokyo transport day pass Bic Camera. The latter is a department store found virtually near all major train/ metro stations. They sell 1,2 or 3 day passes which allow you to the subway for unlimited number of journeys (the currently cost 800, 1200 and 1500 respectively). As journeys on Suica Pasmo can cost up to 200/250 yen, these tickets are very convenient is you want to travel around a fair bit as you'd en up spending more using Suica/ PasmoYou can buy individual tickets for Yamanote line if you need to use it.Bic camera sells these tickets normally on the ground floor and you need to show your passport.The secret to navigating the huge stations is following signs closely and read the exit boards (some stations have tens and tens of exists) identifying where you have to go or a hotel or building or landmark close ti where you have to go.On the other hand, getting lost in the stations is kinda of fun. Enjoy

Give it time . My first day I had some difficulties with it and I was overwhelmed but by day 2 I started to pick things up. The staff are very helpful and will kindly point you in the right direction. I preferred the subway cause it was faster and seemed easier to understand. The English writing can be a little hard to see at times but Google maps helped me tremendously because it would tell me the line and platform to go on. The taxis are fair but it's a bit of a language barrier so I highly suggest you use the train. Good experience and be respectful

Great connectivity. There are 1/2/3 day passes with airport connections with great affordability. Imade the mistake of getting the JR East pass when I was only planning 1 Shinkansen trip out of Tokyo. If your itinerary of the Shinkansen trips is affordable with single purchase tickets, then get the Tokyo metro passes for getting around Tokyo. You can check routes on hyperdia.com

Convenient but Confusing. I've ridden on many public transportation systems through major cities world wide. I found Tokyo's system to be one of the most confusing. It is somewhat easy to figure out the lines and directions to go, but some things I was not able to feel comfortable with: 1) different machines for different modes of transportation including the train and metro and maybe something else; 2) seemingly buying a ticket for the metro, but intend buying a ticket for the train; 3) getting off the metro where different metro lines cross and thinking that I could transfer, but instead I had to exit completely (even after only 1 stop and paying the full transit price) and buy another completely new ticket. The price is good 170 yen but I think it costs more during peak travel times; the guy let me out of the station because I think I underpaid and we had a difficult time understanding each other so he let me go.
Clean, Safe, On Time, Cheap,Very Different. Clean, Safe, On Time, Cheap,Very Different Metro and overall public transportation in friendly, polite Tokyo

Best way to get around town. Easy to use, particularly if you come prepared with map in hand and itinerary. If you pay per trip there are some machines (English available) which allow you to select your destination station. You can pay in cash or by credit card. Don't hesitate to use it!

Great!. It takes a few minutes to get accustomed to the system and you are all set. Great connection, easy to use, affordable unlimited use per day, great way to see many places in one day. Probably one of the best metro systems in the world!
Don't Hesitate. Very easy to use. Good signs. Helpful staff. Clean and realiable. Only crowded in rushhour. Remember to keep you ticket for exit.

Return your PASMO card ONLY at Tokyo region. There is a 500 yen deposit to get the PASMO card which is refundable at the end of your trip. You can use PASMO card to almost everywhere in Japan but the price will be the same as buying individual ticket. PASMO does save you the hassle of queuing up and buying individual ticket everywhere you go. However, please note that you can only return your PASMO in Tokyo region. I suggest that plan your departure place properly should you wish to get the deposit money back. I only found out about this at the end of my Japan trip which is in Osaka. So, the deposit of 500yen will not be refundable. Well good thing is that I get to keep the PASMO for future travel in Japan because it will only expire in the next 10 years.

Tokyo Metro. great way to see tokyo, the lines reach almost all of the main attractions and the main area in Tokyo,although there is a lot of lines and stops at the metro system its easy to understand and to Navigate it.all of the signs and tkts machines are also in english.the metro is very clean and safe to use.you can also buy 1/3/5 day pass that can save you some money.please note that not all of the exits from the stations Accessible with elevator, so it can be a lilt bit tricky for handicaps or people with a lot of luggage to climb all the Staircases

Appears daunting but is surprisingly easy and awesome!. First of all...if you are there more than just a day or so get a SUICA CARD. Load it up and swipe away. You can also use it to buy things at many stores...like a debit card. There is a good government site all about the metro with maps you can print out but I cannot provide the link in a review. Below I have some personal tips. The Metro is like a puzzle...you just need to look at each line individually vs. looking at all the bits at the same time. First of all, holding together all the pieces of the Tokyo puzzle is the: YAMANOTE LINE: This train line is the BEST! It is a circle. A loop that circles around central Tokyo connecting the main stations like Harajuku, Ueno, Tokyo, Shibuya, Shinagawa, etc. ...all the ones that you, as a tourist, will need usually. If you can...print out the metro map before you leave from the web site link above and then locate this line on the map first and hi-lite it. It will help you get your bearings. It’s like getting the corners of the puzzle done first and locating all the ‘like’ colors…it makes the puzzle easier to complete. You can get very close to almost any place you are going with this line and then either hoof it or connect to anther metro line easily (btw many of the stops are super close to one another and it might take less time to just walk it vs. changing lines. I often just get off at the YURAKUCHO stop on the Yamanote line to get to anywhere in Ginza vs. changing to get to a stop closer to where I am going ) If you are buying individual tickets vs. Suica card REMEMBER there is more than one company involved in the metro system. You HAVE to buy tickets at the kiosk that services the line you want to take. Most of the machines are in English and Japanese with little pictures. Just follow the prompts and it will tell you how much money is needed. And if you make a mistake, no worries. There is a guy at the exit of every station who will collect the extra fees needed. Last note! Avoid the metro at commuter times. The trains get SO crowded that they actually have ‘pushers’. Yep. There are white-gloved people who get paid to push you or shall I say squish you onto the metro.

Day ticket may be cheap. Air conditioned , avoid rush time, especially morning, can reach any place even airports but with different ticket. If well planned, can visit most of attractions with cheap price.

Crazy but fun and cheap way to travel. There is a fantastic network of metro throughout Tokyo and at first it can seem a little daunting, but in reality it is quite easy.The only frustration is that you have to buy a ticket for each journey, as each line is owned by separate companies, but the ticket machines are really easy to use, and if you get stuck, the locals are always willing to help.

Very reliable and affordable. The Tokyo Metro is undoubtedly one of the most extensive mass transport systems in the world, serving a mega city that is home to millions of people and visited by millions of tourists. It's also probably the dream network envied and aspired for by other cities of the world. Aside from the trains being very reliable as to time, train stations are conveniently located and lines ensure that major areas are served. The Metro is also connected to major lines going in and out of the city. How I wish we can have this kind of convenient, reliable and affordable mode of transport back home. It would certainly raise the quality of life and ensure time is always well spent.

Amazing and Convenient!. A fantastic way to get around the city! It was a little overwhelming at times, due to the extensive number of lines that there are to travel on, however, it helped to look at the colour of the lines, as well as the associated numbers for each station ie A10, A11 etc etc! Very, very comprehensive and convenient! I recommend picking up a copy of the "Tokyo Metro Guide" it has a largely simplified map inside (as well as the comprehensive one) with some great places to visit marked on the simplified version! If you can, pick up a Tokyo 3 day metro pass for 1500 Yen - as a tourist, it saved me soooo much money! If you google "Tokyo subway 3 day ticket" you will find out where they are available! It allows you unlimited travel on all Tokyo Metro lines and all Toei Subway lines for 3 days! Amazing!!! Please note that note all lines are Tokyo metro lines or toei lines, so be sure to check :)

Tokyo Metro Underground Mystery. I had a really great time on playing English version of “Tokyo Metro Underground Mystery”, sponsored by Tokyo Metro (Tokyo’s subway company).To play this game, you have to visit Tokyo Metro’s Ueno station to purchace the game package. Once you begin the game, you gonna solve lots of riddles inside. When you get correct answer, you’ll get to know which station you need to head to. You do this over and over until you reach the final destination. There’s a huge mystery waiting for you in the end, something you can ever imagine. This game package includes one day free pass, so you’ll get to see places around Tokyo during/after the game…pretty nice. lolFor me, it took about 3 hours to complete this mystery game.You might don’t realize during the game, but you actually get to see the neat places in Tokyo. If you got some spare time, I really recommend you to try this out. Very neat experience.

The only way to get around Tokyo. At first taunting maybe, but the Tokyo Metro system is fast efficient and can get you to just about everywhere you want to go in Tokyo. I bought a Suica card which you can top up. Makes the travel much easier.

Use of PASMO or SUICA Cards. Best and most convenient way to travel in and around Tokyo metro, including back and forth to Narita. Purchase ONE (1) card...I used the PASMO...and put in whatever you like (say 5000 yen to start) and you don't have to keep purchasing tickets on Different travel lines. Every subway station has a place to 'recharge' your card...and even to add more, if there was not enough in it on your last trip. There is a deposit taken out of the first purchase. HOWEVER, at the end of your trip, you can get back your deposit AND any remaining balance! (I did this at the subway turnstile counter on the way out of the train station at Narita). Use your card by placing it over the indicator through the turnstile...and no more figuring out ticket costs for each trip (OR!! repurchase for each new 'private' train line.)

Manageable and comprehensive - best way to get around. Some things to be careful with are; travelcards including Toei lines (they're some of the network and if you're traveling a lot it's worth paying more to include).Also some areas/lines are better served by the JR lines which again aren't included with travelcards.Google Maps and the maps are easy to work-out and everything is very well signed - perhaps too much information sometimes!We traveled during rush-hour and in the centre and it wasn't too bad compared to London.
Best Metro ever. Easy to use, with very helpful staff who will guide you in the right direction, cheap, frequent trains, modern, great way to get around Japan!

Absolutely brilliant!. We spent 7 weeks in Japan with our 3 children aged 6, 8 and 10 and the thing that made it such an awso e trio was the trains! Because Japan has such good train network it's so easy to explore and get close to real life in Japan.Although we travelled to lots of cities in Japan during our trip, much of our time was spent in and around Tokyo where we used the trains and subways every day. We used our JR rail pass until it expired then we used SUICA cards. We got ours from a machine at our local station and we took our children's passports to a JR ticket office and got them children's SUICA cards so they only paid 1/2 price. We went to a Daiso store (¥100 store) and got card holders and cords so we could put them around our necks when dashing on and off trains. The great thing was that we didn't need to worry about buying tickets for every train we could just scan and go. There are top up machines at most stations and you can select English instructions. Most trains show a station map so you can count how many stops until you need to get off, but many trains also tell you in English what station is coming up next. If all else fails don't be afraid to ask someone for help. We found people very friendly and most understood enough English to be able to help us.We downloaded the Japan Trains app from the Google Play store, which made it super easy to plan which trains to catch. Just Google the nearest station to where you want to go, put it in the app and it will tell you the different routes and fares. The app also shows the stations in Kanji so we could show our screen to JR staff or other passangers if we wanted to confirm we were on the waiting in the right for the right track. We lived by the motto 'there's always another train' because if we missed one there was usually another coming just a few minutes later. Obviously the trains get very crowed at times, but we always felt safe and people were very polite even in the most cramped spaces. We often had adults giving up their seats for our children, especially at night when people could see they were tired. We chambered up 1000's of stepes as we rushed to make connecting train transfers. But, there are escalators and lifts if you need them too.Most stations have restaurants, cafes and convenience stores. Lots also have shopping malls attached as well. All in all super convenient and absolutely brilliant service!

Skip the tourist bus, ride this!. NEVER i repeat--NEVER EVER TAKE A TOURIST BUS IN TOKYO. The Tokyo Metro is the ultimate Japan experience or at least Tokyo. It's clean, it's fast, it's on-time and it's freakin' neat. If you're afraid you'll get lost in translation then don't worry--it got english display everywhere. You can get to almost everywhere with the metro. Buy the rail pass for a much cheaper price than to buy a single ticket every time. You'll see how organized, efficient and discipline Japanese people are.

Crazy experience . We used the Tokyo Metro for 4 days. The first day was a bit confusing with all the different companies. After the first day we got into the system and dos some sightseeing . The 1 day pass is worth the 1000 ¥ if you do go some distances . In the evening at the rush hour , prepare yourself for a crazy , overcrowded train were people push each other in so you don't even need to hold on.

A Great Service With Both Japanese And English Signage. Use this service with confidence. Initially you may find it a little confusing, that's only because it's new to you. Just take your time to begin with and you will find the service very easy to use, quick, information with overhead electronic information boards and indeed you will find that young people, when they see you looking at a metro map will walk over to you and ask if where you are going to and enquire if you would like any help. If you do need help, find a younger person to speak to as their English is perfect and they will be delighted to help.An all day ticket is £5, what a cheap and easy way to travel around Tokyo. And its fast.Make use of it, you won't be sorry - oh, there are lots of public toilets within the metro areas and these are very very clean.

Simple, Amazing, Fast & Clean transport !!!!. We had a amazing experience with Tokyo metro. It is fast and very clean. They have English display in all stations and station master are well equipped with information to guide tourist. They were really helpful in all the stations. The price is very good and is the best way to travel across TOKYO..

great metro system. maybe little bit confuse when the first use it, but after all its easy , just have a look with the map , with the number next to station u want to go its the price u need to pay, other way there is always have the staff or japanese people near by helping you, they even waiting u buy the right ticket show you whatever u need to know before leave u , amazing people and city

The Best Train System in the World !!!. Wow this system works beautifully - once you get the hang of the colours and where you need to be its a breeze - anyone will help you all you have to do is ask - we bought day passes 600 yen and you just jump on and jump off - trick is to now which exit you need before heading back above ground - great fun though...watch everyone on there phones here as well it's mind boggling...

What a great system. As soon as we left the airport we needed to jump on a train to head for our accommodations. The ladies at the info booth gave us very clear directions and helped us pay our fare. The stops were easy to figure out since all the trains have a map in English and Japanese over each door, and the announcements are in English and Japanese as well. It is important to remember to line up on the markings on the floor to get on the train as it stops on the exact same spot for the doors to open each and every time. The metro was very child friendly but also very accessible for those who use a wheelchair or are blind. It is by far the best system I have seen in the world.

One of the Best Public Transport Systems!. I would say Tokyo has the most elaborate Rail\subway system. Not just talking about Tokyo metro but the whole subway system. I got to 90% of where I wanted to go using just the Metro and Toei lines. I only needed other lines for Disney Land and Odaiba access (Odaiba is an island with lots of stuff to do).I would say Tokyo is just a tad more comprehensive to Londons Underground, although Londons system also gets you everywhere you would want to go, and is a lot less complicated.Make a note of buying the 3 day open pass available at Haneda airport (They also sell them at the BIC Camera store in Shibuya at the pharmacy) 1 500 Yen for 3 days unlimited travel on Tokyo Metro and Toeie Lines. Very useful if your hotel is closer to those than the JR Line (The ticket does not allow for JR Line travel)

Excellent metro system, on time never late. For those who need English instructions do download an app called Navitime by Japan tourism. It states clearly prices, indications on line change etc. Metro tickets are easy to purchase as there are English instructions on the machine (option to select English)

Very confusing and not tourist friendly.. Very confusing and not tourist friendly. It is very hard to purchase tickets, to find the right route and even the right exit. It took me tremendous amount of time and effort. Signage is not intuitive, few info spots, few clear English directions
Essential. Get yourself a Suica card and a metro map, and Tokyo is your oyster! Once you get your head round how the metro works, the rest is easy.

Easy to use...once you know how it works. When we first arrived in Tokyo and got a map of all the different railway and subway lines, I was convinced we were never going to get used to using it. But, in a couple of days we were practically experts at finding our way around the city. The metro is hands down the best form of transportation when in Tokyo, and it's really cheap! You may have to be a bit careful when transferring on some lines, but the information/ticket offices are very helpful if you happen to hesitate. Also, there are apps that can assist you with the different routes and times if you're still having trouble.

A convenient and cheap way to move around in Tokyo. The Tokyo metro comprises 9 Metro lines and 4 Toei lines and a few Japan Railway lines. Both of them are different operators but use the same platform. It is the cheapest and most convenient way to move around this beautiful city of Tokyo. Most of the tourist sites are within a short walking distance from the many stations. The key is identifying which station the place you want to visit is located and finding the right exit. To use the metro, just go to the ticket machine and look at the metro map. It will tell you where you are and how much it cost you to go to that particular station. You can pay by coins or bank notes. If you intend to travel a lot l suggest you get the one day subway ticket which cost ¥1000 which allows you to travel on all the metro lines except the JR lines which you have to buy a separate ticket. There is a one day pass that cost ¥1590 that all you to travel on all the lines. The signs are usually in both japanese and english. It is a little difficult initially but once you get the hang of it is easy as abc as what l found out. You may need to change lines depending on your destination and to do this just follow the sign boards which are written in japanese n english.

Super efficient. For 170 yen you can travel on one line for any number of stations. The trains are always on time clearly marked red, yellow line etc and incredibly clean super service one of the best metros in the world.

Impressive!. The Tokyo metro is more than just transportation. It is world in itself! You can go from anywhere to anywhere in Tokyo (and beyond...the locals link to the intercity Shinkansens at some stations) with ease, at fairly reasonable prices. The metro is living...and the friendly helpful Japanese folk that travel the metro make it much easier for foreigners to commute.

Underground maze in Tokyo, not subway!. Well, the Tokyo Metro subway system is hard to use not only travellers from abroad but many Japanese residents. It's always hard to know where to transfer, so I always wander lonely with a metro map in hand! Why don't you change your idea? This system is not a subway, but huge underground maze in Tokyo. There are exits anywhere and you can get some snacks at the cafe when you are tired from wandering in the maze! I want to ask for the metro station staff one thing; Will you please make some maps with many languages?

A good way to get around Tokyo. But the JR Rail Pass will not work on these private train lines.. The Metro is a good idea to save time as you crisscross between cities in Tokyo. The JR Yamanote line is probably the line you will using 75% of the time. A question asked is Should I buy I JR Rail Pass? It depends on how many LONG DISTANCE travelling you will be doing, especialluy on the Shinkansen (Bullet)

Most Efficient and Clean Transit System. I've been on several transit systems in various cities, and out of every single one. Tokyo Metro was the best. This was my first time visiting Japan from Canada. I never had an issue navigating or finding my way around. The entire process is mapped out and directions are given for everything. To make things even better. The entire transit system from stations, terminals, and the trains themselves were exceptionally clean. I wish the transit in North America ran as smoothly as it does in Tokyo.

Amazing . Incredible system. Used it today for the first time and couldn't be more impressed. It's frequent, fast and very clean and efficient. I've used them all over the world and this is right up there with the best.

Not difficult to use especially if you're familiar with the tube. It took us a little while to get used to the metro but it is very similar to the tube. It is quite cheap and a good way to get around. But don't be afraid to use a bus or walk so you can see more of the city!

Convenient. This is a great way to get around IF you understand how it works.There are many lines in Tokyo so if you know which lines you wanna take then its great.The train & train station are always crowded though.
metro journey heading from airport to town. efficient and convenient service into town - quick and easy to navigate. especially for lone and budget travelers.

Tokyo metro cheap and convenient. Tokyo metro is a fantastic cheap way to get around Tokyo. It is a must do to get around approx £3.00 for an all day pass.Very simple and easy way to get around and you can reach most places.

Great way to get around the city. It's so clean and people are always about to help if you get stuck. We prefer to walk which we did around Tokyo but it's a large city so we took the metro if going from one side to another. If you are doing less that 4 trips a day then our hotel told us to just buy a ticket for the station of destination which you can easily buy from the machines!! Much nicer that the tube!!

Standard subway, not an attraction!. There is nothing special about the Tokyo subway so I'm surprised to see it listed here! It's a standard subway. It feels London-esk at parts with the heat and non-barrier protected stations. Doesn't feel as clean and modern as it should be. Avoid during rush hours, you're packed in like sardines and this is when there are station attendants that help push people on. It's very hot and sweaty!!As others have said the PASMO card is extremely useful and can be used on public transport, vending machines and some shops in Tokyo.I suppose if you have never been on a subway system before it's an experience in itself. The subway system seems overly complex here which can be daunting. It takes a little while to understand what's going on and where your headed but station attendants should be able to help. If you are using google maps be warned that on a number of occasions it told us the wrong direction we should have been heading in so double check!You will definitely be using the subway to get around in Tokyo either way but if subways are your thing, the Hong Kong MTR (subway) system is by far the best and most modern I have seen.

Best way to travel around Tokyo!. Seriously the quickest and best method of transportation around Toyko! I never road at rush hour so I am not sure what that is like, but all other times of the day is great. The stations area easy to find and its easy to get around town and all the major landmarks/attractions. You can buy day passes which are great for travelers and they are cheap!

Get a PASMO or SUICA card - you won't regret it. The Tokyo Metro and other subways systems are super convenient, BUT buying tickets every time is a pain in the butt. Save yourself some trouble and buy an IC card (stored-value card) such as a PASMO or SUICA card, and use that to go in and out of the fare gates with ease and speed.

Best way to travel around Tokyo. The Tokyo metro is easy to use and can take you to most attractions in Tokyo, as well as connections to JR stations. It operates from 6am to Midnight 7 days a week. As well as normal fares which are around Y200 per trip, there are also 1 day tickets for Y800 and 2 day tickets available for Y1200, which offer unlimited travel for 1 or 2 days. The metro can get crowded in peak times, so take care. Trains run every 3-5 minutes so there is always another train soon enough. The best way to travel around Tokyo

Positive reviewers must never have used a decent subway before. Where do I start? My subway frustrations put me in a sour mood the first time I visited Tokyo. The thing is, it's not really a single subway system, but three or more systems with minimal interactions with one another (Metro, Toei, and JR). Transfers are difficult and expensive. Just because there are two lines that overlap doesn't mean there will be a station there. You may have to pass through poorly marked ticket gates two or three times within one station. There are fees for transferring from one company's line to another's. There are two payment options: 1) go to a ticket machine and figure out the fare to the stop you want, 2) buy a cash card. Option 1 is just laughable. In one of the most high-tech cities in the world you still have to do the calculations yourself and buy a paper ticket. Option 2 leads to price gouging if you use one of the company's cards to pay the fare on another company's line.Bring a decent map before you arrive. One that both gives station names in your native language AND Japanese, and that clearly denotes which lines are operated by which companies. Other negative reviewers have noted that the maps are difficult to read if you don't know Japanese. Well, my second time in Tokyo I was with a Japanese woman from out of town, and I had to explain the maps to her!Finally, the attendants at the ticket gate windows may or may not be particularly helpful. But thankfully, if you stand around looking like a confused/exasperated foreigner for a few minutes, odds are a civic-minded Tokyo resident will help sort you out.

Great transportation system . If you need to get around the metropolitan Tokyo area, this is the way to do it. It is clean, safe and reliable. Some of the cars get really crowded so beware. Almost all of the directions are written in both Japanese and English. There are multiple stops along the multiple trains.
Crowded. If you like it fast loud and structured. Go to Tokyos subway. The amount of people who are sucked in by a tube is just not possible until you see it with your own eyes
Clean, safe & reliable.. The Tokyo Metro is clean, safe, reliable & easy to navigate. The ticket machines will work in multiple languages & prices provide excellent value.

Not to be missed but wait for the weekend. Go to the huge Shinjuku train station and wander around. BUT ONLY ON A WEEKEND when the crowds are smaller. There is so much to see before you even take a metro train. Shops selling all kinds of items, food vendors, adverts and people wandering all about. You can buy an all day ticket for 600 yen which is about $5. Lots of people, just regular Japanese passengers will help you navigate and it's the fastest and easiest way to get around

Easy to use very quick and efficient. Once you realise that metro lines are coloured and stations have numbers as well as names the metro is very easyto use. A day ticket is 600 yen which is very good value.Electronic screens in the carriages clearly show where you are and the announcements are in English as well as Japanese.A great way to get around and see people.One word of warning...there are a couple of lines which are run by a different company and you need another ticket. Not a problem if you plan as you don't need to use them.

How is this an attraction?. The Tokyo Metro is an excellent transportation system. But how is this #4 out of over 1000 things to do in Tokyo? I'm giving it a low rating to hopefully have some impact on the ranking. That said, trains are the way to get around in Tokyo. If you are visiting, purchase a Suica or Pasmo rechargeable card. You can get these from the ticket vending machines that are labeled with Suica or Pasmo (as opposed to regular train ticket machines). The cost will be ¥2000, and will include ¥1500 credit. This will greatly simplify your use of any train line (and there are quite a few privately owned lines in addition to JR and Tokyo Metro). Watch the ticket gates for 30 seconds and you'll figure out how to use. While we're at it, please observe how other people are acting on the train. In Korea, people are excitedly talking and cell phones are going off everywhere. In Japan, in general, people are more reserved. They sit quietly, or talk in hushed tones. Act however you want, but keep in mind that loud talking and laughing only reinforces a negative stereotype of Westerners here.

Unless you have to, I would suggest not using the metro.. For most foreigners ... you have a JR pass of sorts, and this isn't included. Then, if you go on a private line you're doing fare adjustments. It's plain not worth the money unless you have to use it. I personally feel like the amount I spent using it over the last trip I went was wasted money - maybe I'm wrong!
Wouldn't say it's a must see. More of a useful mode of transport.... Really easy to use and very cheap especially the 3 day pass. We managed to not get lost so anyone can use it

Easy to use, great exposure to the people. Tips:1. Download the english PDF map of the system to your phone - most of the train car signs have both english and japanese maps, but a few didn't.2. Unlike the London or Paris systems that use the first/last stops on the line as the designator, use the letter and number abbreviation both for the stop you are getting off on, and to make sure you're going the right direction. The stop signs have a big letter and number in the middle with an arrow pointing in the direction its going with a smaller letter and number for the next stop.3. If you're going to be there for a couple days, get either a Pasmo or Suica card. Its basically a debit card that you prepay at the little vending machines, and each time you go through you just wave the card over the gate and it simply debits the correct amount from the card. You can recharge the card. Way easier and quicker that trying to use the ticket vending machines for a one way ticket each time.

Great system . It does look daunting at first but just buy a one day pass for 600 yenAbout 5 euroThere is English everywhere and on the TVs in the train tooFastNot crowded outside rush hourTokyo is spread out so a taxi would be expensive Plenty vending machines tooSome lines are a big walk apart underground thoughAbout 350 m

A great ride at a fast pace. When you are in Tokyo you should try to take a ride on the shinkansen or Bullet train. We decided to give it a try and boarded the shinkansen at Tokyo station for Yokohama. Although over 50 miles away the trip only took 15 minutes. The ride was so smooth, you had no idea you were going that fast until another train passed in the other direction. They departed exactly on time and arrived to the minute and were spotlessly clean. Give them a try, I'm sure you will enjoy the ride and the comparison to US Trains.
Good, cheap and convenient way to explore Tokyo. Good, cheap and convenient way to go about Tokyo if you don't want to walk. I bought a day pass which allowed to hop on and off where ever I wanted

A great way to get about. Without a doubt the most organised Public Transport system I have ever seen.Very easy to travel on, as long as you don't rush and think about where you want to go and look for the appropriate line or station to get on/off at.

One of the best.. Everything runs perfectly. On time, smooth, easy to use and in English. Not many workers speak English but the machines are easy to use. Get the day pass for 600-1000 yen depending on if you want just the metro lines or the Toei ones as well. We managed on just the metro ones personally. Signs are in both English and Japanese. Not the biggest underground, especially when compared to London but it works so well. Use it over cabs any day.

Great network, not so easy to use machines. My first recommendation: Apply for a JR pass before you travel to Japan. This is a must have for any tourist believe me. Unless you read Japanese!5 years ago, we got thr JR pass and didnt have to use the regular ticketing machines. It was extremely convenient.This time we forgot this and we ended up buyinh tickets like regulat public.a) too expensiveb) not every station has English directories.In case you dont have a JR pass, get a Suica Card like regular public, you can put credit in it so that you dont have to calculatr the fares between stops (fares varies depending on start and end stations and you need to buy a ticket with exact fare total of the trip that you will do. If you cannot read Japanese maps showing fare differences between stops, you have no clue how to figure this out)If you have a JR pass - fantasticIf you have suica card - it is good alsoIf none of above - will struggle

Good way to travel where JR train does not go. So first of all, do your homework. Know the different colors and general routes before you use it. Also know that these stations are in the underbelly of the station - so be prepared to walk a lot - especially climbing stairs. Having said that, I really liked this service. Cars are clean, stations are clean and frequency is good. If a JR train and metro both go to the same station, take JR train since metro may not always be covered. Also, because JR line is above ground, less walk but it is a great option to navigate. Use suica card for travel.

Hectic but effective. This system is unlike any other. The external rails are operated by different companies. Japan Rail (JR) intersects throughout. I didn't get the PASMO pass so i operated strictly on tickets. You will have to exit and get a different ticket each tick you switch a line (its a pain). If you switch from a line to a JR rail you may have to walk a couple hundred to 500 meters to the metro stop. All in all though it works. Also get the HYPERDIA app- its a lifesaver. It will navigate you through the entire Tokyo system!

Brilliant especially if you get a PASMO card. Cheap, efficient and easy to use. The metro will take you all over the city, the staff are very helpful and all directions and announcements are in English, it is so straight forward to use. I bought a PASMO card which was brillant. Pick one up at the airport, the card can be used on the all metro and train networks and you just load it with cash and off you go. No need to worry about buying the right ticket and you can cash it in at the airport train station when you leave the country. We used them to travel to Toyko, Yokohama and beyond. Apart from buy a pasmo card, my other tip would be if you are using the metro to get to you hotel from the airport find out which exit to use as all stations seem to have at least 6.

Good efficient but a lot of walking. The system covers almost the whole city except Odaiba. Enough English signs and maps to guide you to the right train. However you may have to walk up and down quite a bit to do a transfer. I still cannot believe they don't have direct metro link between Shinjuku and Ikebukuro or Shinjuku and Shibuya. We used the 3 days metro pass which saved us some money.

A Great Transport System. If in Tokyo the most convenient way to move around at low cost in the Metro. It may seem a little confronting at first to establish which train and which station and what cost but ask for help and people will provide it. Most trains now have English signs and notification on the train. There are also good English written guides available and if you want to see an efficient, on time and clean system try Tokyo Metro.
Best in the world. Best train system in the world. If only it ran all night, it would be perfect. Covers the whole city, easy to navigate once you get used to it

Unclear . If you plan anything with the subway in Tokyo if you haven't been there, I suggest downloading the subway app in advance. The coverage of Tokyo by sub is HUGE and very unclear. But the price is reasonable

Great!. It offers cheap ticket almost for all tourism destination. Also offer one day open ticket for budget travel. So you do not have to buy additional ticket when you come from station to station. Ticket machine also has friendly interface for firstimer with bilingual service.
Best way to get around the city! . Best way to get around tokyo! Fast and easy to use. There's many information about it and google maps works well with their schedule

Best way to get around Tokyo. Taking the public transport in Tokyo can be daunting if you're traveling for the first time to the country's capital. There are different train companies running different lines. It's recommended to buy a day pass however some places may be only accessible by JR or a different train line this you will need to buy a separate ticket. Metro trains are generally less crowded than JR trains and their free wifi works a lot better too.

Great system once you get to know it. The metro is a great system once you work out there are 3 different rail companies on the same map. There is the jr trains and toei as well as the metro. Best way for a tourist is a one day pass for 600 yen or the 1000 to use toei subway too.Best way to get around

Study Up!. As you can probably tell from looking at the route map or from other reviews the Tokyo subway is impressive but complicated. Ignoring the JR trains there are 2 different metro companies, this makes it complicated if you want to buy tickets. The easiest thing for us was to buy day tickets (or multi day) for both lines. There is the subway ticket for tourists which gives you a discount on this, we should have bought this but didn't at Narita and would have had to go to another station to get it so we just got the 1000 yen one. For us this was definitely worth it as we used the metro quite a bit. I also recommend getting the iPhone app: Tokyo Subway navigation for tourists its free and not only tells you how to get from one station to another but also how long it will take and specifically the exit to take for attractions near that station. Being from Boston I am not used to such a high end metro system, nor am I used to such large stations, the exits numbers matter a lot so you will want to know which one to take when you arrive at a station. In addition knowing the number of the station in addition to the name is very useful as it can be hard at times to see the English signs. Finally try to familiarize yourself with the signs the first few times you ride, even after we figured things out we did still sometimes walk towards the wrong platform or struggle to find the right exit.Beyond the fact that the metro is complicated it incredibly clean, reliable and I found pretty cheap for what it offers.

Easy, comfortable & cheap way to visit all the Tokyo attractions. The Tokyo Metro is for me the easy way to travel around Tokyo as Taxis are quiet expensive and trafic is dense. Numerous line of Metro. Markings are in Japanese and English. Metro is clean and comfortable.Advice, purchase two daily passes, one for the metro and one for the trains. Because it could be confusing when you have to choose.

Worked well but can be confusing.. I used a tourist pass for two days which worked well for our travels BUT with more than one transit system it can be confusing and when changing systems it can be hard to find a new station. The system is not as modern as Beijjing, but still it worked reasonably well for our trip

Be prepared to buy two types of cards. To navigate the city you will need a card for the metro and another card for the trains. Indeed, The Tokyo metro is a combination of two major companies running a certain number of lines - buy a 1 or 2 or 3 day pass - and a network of - commuter - train stations run by JR. To go from one point to another sometimes you ll need to use the metro card other times you ll need the train card. Hope this makes sense. The good news is if you visit other Japanese major cities the pre-paid card you will have bought there can also be used in Tokyo. In Tokyo it is called PASMO or SUICA and in the Kansai Region ( Osaka and Kyoto ) they labelled it ICOCA. You can use the. IC(OCA) card even when you commute in the Hakone area. So always make sure that when in Tokyo you have both the metro - paper - card and your pre-paid. IC card you can top up at any PASMO/suica machine to avoid transport headaches.

Small, Confusing, Expensive but Essential. In my opinion, Tokyo metro system is confusing. It is also quite expensive.The trains (the coaches) and the platforms are relatively small (if compared to Singapore MRT and Sydney Trains. They are just about same size as Bangkok BTS). Tokyo being a first world country we had a higher expectation. However, this was our only mode of travel as it is a well known fact that cab fares in Tokyo are very steep.

Clean, efficient & the only way to travel. This is one of the best metros in the world with an efficient & easy system to navigate even for foreigners. Buying a pasmo card allows easy access & there are always staff on hand if you have any questions. There are clear maps, onboard messages & even advice as to which end of the train you will need to be in for your particular exit point. Other metros take note.

Matro. Best metro system I've ever had the pleasure of riding on. Easy to navigate (despite the initially overwhelming route map. If you need help, you can actually speak to station attendants (with some creative translating, of course)

Efficient mode of transportation. The metro system in Tokyo provides an effective way to get around the vast city. It can be very crowded at rush hour, so be prepared. The metro cars have a wonderful electronic information system that lets you know which stop is next, and how long it will take to get you to your destination. The only drawback to the system is that there is more than one metro company, and sometimes you have to go out of one station, walk a block or two, and enter another station, and it's not always easy to find the entrance.

Almost the only way I get around in Tokyo.. Tokyo metro is the best way to get around in the city. It's very easy to use, very clean and quite price-proportional. I personally use the refillable PASMO-card. It is very convenient since it works everywhere I personally go. It works in busses also and even in some stores. It is similar to the suica card in Tokyo, or to the T-money in Seoul metropolitan transport system. If you are travelling a long distance, I recommend you to see if there are any sectional semi-/ semi-express, express available on your route since it saves you time. The trains are very packed during rush hours. This can be a little bit tiring during longer rides. I frequently used odakyu-line. Which is a private train company. Although it's very similar to the JR-metro trains and etc. For the comfort of the passengers, there are sometimes reserved seats for older/pregnant people and special carriages for women (usually at night time). There are also sometimes wagons with lighter air conditioning if you are sensitive to that. The temperature is quite comfortable in the trains even during the hot summers in Japan. I definitely recommend Tokyo metro when moving around in Tokyo!

Tokyo was absolutely amazing. The only way to get about in Tokyo but finding your way into and out of thr stations is very challenging but don't worry just open a map and look puzzled and people will come to your rescue. Once you have learned how to connect from line to line it's a breeze treat it as an adventure. Japaneese are very courteous and will help you find your way.

great transportation. We spent 2 weeks in Japan , using Tokyo metro and other forms of transportation ( taxi, " bullet trains") in few words- timely, clean , efficient. For bullet train you can buy a pass ( if you are just a visitor to Japan) which is way less expensive than buying individual tickets.

GREAT WAY TO GET AROUND TOKYO!. The Tokyo Metro is a quick and easy way to get around Tokyo! It is also a great experience and gives you an immersion into "Tokyo Life." Also fun for people watching. If you are a tourist and have a JR Rail Pass along with a PASMO Card, you have it made! The PASMO card is somewhat similar to the Carte NAVIGO in Paris, France. You can get it at any METRO station. The nice thing about PASMO is that it does not expire!!! As long as you have credit on your card you can use it! It sure beats buying tickets!!! It is amazing to see and experience around rush hour, but very different from the New York Subway, or Paris METRO, etc... as people are polite and patient letting people get off the metro car easily and then boarding in an orderly fashion!

WHAT A GREAT SYSTEM.. I have just spent five weeks in Tokyo and in four words what a great system.I have used the Metro before with relatives or friends but this is the first time I have tackled it on my own. At first it can be a bit daunting, so many stations , so many lines , so many levels but after a time or two it becomes quite simple. There are plenty of signage boards at the stations in English showing all the stations and different lines and where to change etc.There are always staff in the little offices at the gates who are only too happy to help you and their are plenty of staff on the platforms doing their thing and they will make sure your getting on the right train or as a last resort ask a local traveller.It is very interesting to watch the platform staff on the busy stations perform, very formal and efficient. The stations themselves can be like shopping centres, you can buy nearly anything you want without leaving the station and the different levels of lines can be five levels below you . Don't worry about missing a train as the next one is only a couple of minutes away, I personally never bothered to look at a time table, one leaves and another arrives , beautiful. The best thing is to buy what they called a SUICA CARD, I was given one the first day I arrived and it was the best thing ever.Put money on the card and then you just swipe on and off as you enter and leave a station.This card you can also use at most convenience stores in Tokyo and even some tourist attractions, it is brilliant, without it you have to keep going to machines and buying individual tickets which can be confusing and time consuming.They have a unique way of lining up for trains which I still don't quite understand especially at busy times but no problem just follow the locals. The system moves millions of people per day so morning and afternoon peak time is crazy and best to be avoided but on saying that I think you should do a peak time trip just for the heck of it , it is a once off experience you should have, I found it exciting and would not miss it.Another interesting thing is that during peak times their are woman only carriages, sorry guys no men only carriages,Take note that the Japanese commuters are very orderly and quiet, talking loudly and talking on the phone is frowned on and I have never once seen any loutish behaviour. Yes travel the Metro it is super efficient and a great way to see the amazing city of Tokyo, have fun I did.

Tokyo metro is enormous but plenty of help. It's easy to feel overwhelmed in a station of this size do the best advise is to go into the JR ticket office for you tickets and directions. Trains are always on time, very regular and very clean.

Tokyo Metro Fantastic and fascinating. Tokyo Metro Fantastic and fascinating : clean , fast, directions well indicated, and very effective even prices a little bit expensive but you have for your money. Counted 5 levels of tunnels with trains in some areas
Travel within Japan. we have experience riding the trains in Japan, particularly the Tokyo Metro, quick and easy and on time.

Gonna love this. Well this is the most used subway lines in the world. If you visit here, don't panic, most railway workers understand English and the words, I am lost! Each station has a free map and city guides at the gates. You can also get a one day pass which is super cheap.

Well connected.... This really is the best way to get around Tokyo while sightseeing. The JR pass can't be used on this railway. But the tickets are pretty easy to purchase as required. Use google maps to find the directions and exact fare. The purchase of tickets at the machine is based on the fare cost. They have special kids priced tickets with a little symbol on them. When kids pass through the ticket checker, it beeps. The maps have English names of stations on them, so that helps too.

Looks daunting at first.... The Tokyo Metro may appear daunting at first, but it is a world class system that's actually logical and easy to handle after only a very short time. Less than a few hours and getting from place to place is a breeze. Be sure to get a Suica card and load it up to make things even easier and faster!

Nothing to be afraid of. Like the underground in London it's the best way to get around Tokyo. Unlike the Tube its painless on your pocket, ¥1000 for an all day pass on both metro networks.
It's is fast and efficient and like any city in rush hour it can get very crowded, but otherwise there's plenty of room.

Very neat and cost effective. Everytime i travel to Japan, subway is always first choice move around because it's the best way to blend in local area and people. It might be little confused but one of the greatest thing in Japan is that people are always welcome to your question. Also, every big station, there are tourist information boxes that you can get helped. You might feel uncomfortable being with a lot of people cramped, but it is one of the culture in asia being with lots of people around. so, enjoy!

SCARY AT FIRST. Wow I have never seen so many poeple trying to get on trains . Once you get used to it after the initial shock you realise it is an easy,efficient , cheap , on time every time , fast ,way to get around the city. We used it every day never had a problem .The station staff are there to help and every one of them that I had dealings with spoke English.We even asked some of the locals and they helped too.

Very efficient. Tokyo metro is very efficient and convenient. It practically connects each and every corner of the city. It can be crowded at peak times, so avoid peak times if you are having some luggage. As a tourist, an efficient public transport system like this really helps.

FANTASTIC WAY TO GET AROUND.. Wow Wow if we only had a transport system like this.Fast Clean reliable safe and busy although it never really felt to busy because it was so organized.Never once did we feel uncomfortable or worried. It would have to be one of the safest and cleanest transport networks i have ever been on.

So Easy To Use. These is a System Map in Japanese and in English. But even if the Tokyo Metro will be 100 percent Japanese it's still so easy to understand the system. I've tried the NY Subway system and I find the Tokyo Metro quick and faster to understand. It's also safe and cleaner that other countries.
Best way to commute. it might be confusing at first, but its the best way to commute , efficient, clean and professional.
Best way to move. Definitely the best way to move and see Tokyo !!! Clean , organized and helpful staff ( not all speak English ) but all station tickets have English option

Best railway system ever!. Trains arrive every two to four minutes and quickly transport you to your destination. The Tokyo Metro is the most efficient railway system I have ever experienced. There are hundreds of stations on dozens of lines all over Tokyo and it's surrounding suburbs and there's never a single issue. The easiest way to make your way around the city, with stations located near every major suburb and attraction. Make sure you grab a map your first day in Tokyo for easy navigating, you will use it every single day! When at the station, follow the signs navigating you to each line via letter and colour. The signs will include how long the walk is to each platform, as many of the stations can be over a kilometre in length, and depending on what entrance you take into the station, the walk can be quite extensive. Every station is numbered along the line, and at the stations signs will indicate which way the trains are going (what the next station/number is etc) and announcers on the train will tell you in Japanese and English when to change for another line. You might have to take two or three different lines to get to a particular station, but due to the trains coming so often, it really is very easy. If you grab yourself a map and follow the subway signs, you will have no trouble navigating the Tokyo Metro, and will find getting around Tokyo so easy and pain free. One more thing to mention - each subway entrance will be labelled with a number/letter. Take note of this number when you're entering to make it easier for you to find the right exit when you're returning. If you just take any exit you can often end up blocks away from where you're meant to be, and it can be very confusing to get back!

Higashi-Ikebukuro on the Yuurakuchou line of TOKYO METORO. Higashi-Ikebukuro station on the Yuurakuchou line of TOKYO METORO is connected with Higashi-Ikebukuro 4-chome of
the street car station of Tokyo Gavament.
Therefore if you are interested in Metoro and Stree car, the satation as Higashi-ikebukuro on YUURAKUCHO line of
Tokyo metoro line is very convenience for transfer.

I must be map illiterate!!. How on earth do the previous reviewers say such wonderful things about this system. I'm from London, travel extensively having used numerous city trains. Yes it's an efficient, cheap MTS yet the signage is incompressible (albeit in English) esp when you have to navigate across, down and up several underground passages, department stores and stalls in the stations. Shinjuku and Ikeburko being amongst the worst offenders. I used the Metro app which helped enormously but having watched the locals using their equivalent and the numerous visits to helpful staff members couldn't persuade me to give it any more stars. The 3 hr nightmare with non stopping trains today which gave me a 3 hr journey time for a usual 1 hr ads to the frustration. Still thinking about the locals using their app. I've never had to use mine as much elsewhere. This just compounds my negative experiences.

Best system ever. I live in NYC and have travelled all over, so needless to say I'm used to metro systems...but this far surpasses anything I've seen. Clean, super organized, comfortable and super timely!! Best way to get around. Be aware though that after 12:30AM you have to cab it. My Japanese is not great and at the risk of embarrassing myself I used to to ask for directions...very gracious staff, very kind and will do the best to guide you. Heck I even got a free pass when my SUICA (like metro card system) ran out of money. Don't be afraid to use it...it'll take you everything in very fast time!

The best way to get around!. Once you get the hang of it this is the best way to get around this huge city. You can just stick to the JR line as it services all major spots and has annoucements in English so you cant go wrong. This is tokyo so expect to move quickly and with purpose and you'll be fine. Dont take open food or drink on especially during rush hour.

perfect, clean, organise, punctual. it was amazing to see that if a train is scheduled to arrive at some time, it will...biggest delay i saw was around 40 seconds...and the people there are very organised and polite.. the people waiting in line to get in the train, will wait in lines on the side of the doors, to not disturb those getting out, and then they will get in.important to say that it was almost always crowded... sometimes, till zero free space, but everything with politeness.we used it a lot on our trip in Tokyo, and is very efficient to go everywhere in the city using it... the only bad things is that from there you don't see the beauty of the city above the ground.
Excellent . Like all public transport in japan the metro is clean fast on time. At times its a crush but no worse than say London or Paris.

Punctual and Efficient. So easy to navigate and helpful staff speak enough English if you're unsure. The ticket machines also have an English option and really easy to use. Makes seeing the city fun and simple.
