Best way to travel around Tokyo!!!. With more than 10 lines between the combined network of Tokyo Metro and Toei subways, this is surely an efficient way to travel around Tokyo. Formed in 1941, the system is widely used and efficient. Some of the stations and trains may be old but not down and out. With the introduction of smart phone apps, its easier to plan and travel. Have fun hearing the station names and pronouncing the same.Avoid the morning and evening peak hours for a better experience.

Firat introduction to Japanese punctuality. I never worry about being late in Japan, If you miss the train, chances are, there's another one coming in a few short minutes (reallllllly short). It's fast, efficient, and affordable. The only thing to take note is that sometimes they have two completely different stations with the same name, like Asakusa Station (Asakusa Line) and Asakusa Station (Oedo Line), so make sure you're on the right station! With that being said, the metro is the fastest way to get around Tokyo. You can also rent a bike, it's a good way to cut down costs and get around.

Use the metro. The metro is very easy to use with each stop labeled with a name and an alphanumeric identification. Much more economical than a taxi!! Used a taxi for a 10 minute journey cost 1720, purchased 2 metro days passes for 1600!!!

The complex simplicity . When I firstly arrived in Tokyo I was somehow confused about the train system. I often took the wrong hotel on my way to my accommodation( 南先住 was the station I needed but I was stuck at 上野) After an odyssee I found out that I had to take the joban line. To put the whole matter in a nutshell I got lost on my first day but the next day I was an expert. I could easily travel around without getting lost. So the train system in 東京 is actually simple and effective. Just try it out and you will see.

Great Network. The only problem... some old-dated trains. Tokyo Metro definitely rules every train network on the world. Depending on the station you get off, it is easy to transfer from one to another that will make your journey smooth. However, the reason why I rated this 4-stars, it is due to some old-dated trains. For example, the Hibiya line that runs from Naka-meguro to Kita-senju, has lots of old-dated trains, comparing to Hanzomon or Chiyoda line which has lots of new trains with screens on it. Also, there has been lots of suicides happening inside Tokyo Metro, that may delay your journey dramatically, so keep that in mind. A cheap ride costs you around $1.50 USD (170 JPY) which is a deal!

Wonderful Metro. Anyone who has used the Tokyo Metro knows how intimidating it was before trying it; and how easy and delightful it was, once they did. Like most everything else in sprawling, beautiful Tokyo, it is highly civilized, well organized, and thoughtful, with signage and audibles in both Japanese and English.

An Unbelievable Network of Spider Webs. The Metro map looks very daunting but in reality it is the proper way to get around in Tokyo. It will take a day or two to get used to it but it is the easiest and cheapest way to travel in Tokyo. All you need to master the Metro is common sense. Read the signs (all are in English) and know your destination and you are home free. You may run into a problem if you must change trains two or three times but for no train changes you should be on cloud nine.

Super Efficient. I've been to Europe, the US and several countries in Asia but I have never been on a more efficient mode of transport than in Tokyo's Metro. You can literally get to where you're going in less than 20 minutes. Plus there are lovely places to eat in near most stations.

Its a must do. At first you will find it a little bit confusing, but once you work it all out its the most amazing system in the world. On time, easy to use ticketing system, and can get you all over Tokyo in a matter of minutes

Give it a try.. The Metro system at first can be very confusing and some of the stations you could get lost in for hours. However don't be afraid the station staff are wonderful, most speak good English and will give you great directions. Often they write the directions down. After using the system a couple of times you will feel very comfortable. A great and cheap way to get round Tokyo.

Brilliant service in a brilliant city.. I lost my wallet on the metro after stupidly leaving it on the seat as I departed the train. I had stupidly placed half of my money and my passport in the wallet, including my disneyland park tickets for the next day. I panicked and ran straight towards lost property with thoughts of how I was going to leave the country and embark on the second leg of my journey through asia on my mind. Literally 5 minutes later, after telling the guards and watching them walk off, they walked right back with my wallet in hand. And this really sums up my metro experience. People are honest, kind and polite. There was never a moment I felt unsafe, or unhappy. It's reliable and quick and super clean.

Great transportation. Metro together with JR trains and another lines build very convinient system of traveling inside of this huge city.For me shocking question is how they keep this place clean. After seeing all conditions of rubbish in New York London and especially Paris I ask the question every time I go to train in Japan. HOW THIS IS POSSIBLE? Very recommended.

Wow! Punctual! Efficient!. Very convenient and very punctual! A little bit confusing though. However not to worry as there are station masters over there to help. They speak understandable English. Make sure you are at least 5 minutes early on the platform as the trains arrive either 1 minute early or just on time. Very impressed by the system. However, I don't understand why they want to cramp everyone inside the train during peak hours as they could have operated longer and more trains.

Great transport link. Great transport link. You can use the JR pass or buy an all day ticket for 700 or 1000 yen. The 1000 yen ticket means you can go everywhere and is good value for a sightseeing day. Clean and safe, if a little confusing. Take some time to see tokyo station.

Faultless subway system. Great system for getting around Tokyo and all other reviews about ticketing and cleanliness are spot-on.
Only advice for first-time visitors is to consult the yellow signage and maps when exiting the station to ensure that you reach your desired destination as the subway network can be quite cavernous.

An Amazing Underground Maze. The Tokyo underground network is an amazing maze. Wear comfortable shoes as sometimes you will walk for quite a few yards in between stations. Bento sold in the stations are not worth the money and trash bins are hard to find, but you get from place to place quickly and efficiently.

Just use it and see Tokyo the fast way. This is the one and only eay to travel im Tokyo and a must if you want to get the most and best out of this fantastic city..works 100% and is spotless and so time saving and cheap..get used to it and just ride along and save time and money

The Tokyo Metro is great transportation in the city. Since Tokyo is massive in size and difficult to drive or find parking the metro is great for transportation. The cost is reasonable and the schedule is on time. There are English translations for the stops so easy to find your way around. Best way to travel without expensive taxis sitting in traffic.

Try to Get Pasmo. Traveling by metro is the easiest way to visit all the areas in Tokyo and vicinity. They do announce in English and stations are written in English. Rather than buying tickets each time, get a Pasmo card and put in money before you start the trip. This will allow you to use the card for practically all transportation including JR and drinks at the vending machine also.

Very good way to get around Tokyo. My wife and I were in Tokyo for 3 full days and found the metro to be the best way to get around. Good luck on trying to get a cab, we were consistently unsuccessful.The Tokyo metro is unusual in that it has about 8 color coded lines, each owned by a different company. They give you a map. The most effective way to use the metro is to by an all day pass good on all lines for 1000 yen (about $8.25). Trains come and go very quickly we never had to wait more than 5 minutes. There is some distance walking and stairs similar to the London and Paris Metros but I think this one is better.

A feel of modern day Tokyo. Personally I feel this is something everyone coming to Tokyo should experience. It gives you a taste of what it's like to live in a one of the most populated, yet most organized cities in the world. Most ticket machines have an "English" button.

On time, everytime. No Exceptions. Tokyo Metro is the easiest & most efficient way to move around Tokyo. there are many ways to organize payment. You can by a card before you arrive at Tokyo or get single passes, day passes or whatever way you want to do it. Metro workers are very friendly & helpful. There are always subway maps available & the Metro connects you to the JR railway service & the Shiskansen lines. The Metro will take you anywhere in tokyo you want to go cheaply & efficiently. There are bathroom facilities in every Metro station once you pass through the paid gate. Most stations will have disabled access.
Tokyo Metro. Busy but efficient....seems strange that no one is talking......Maps are INTERESTING to say the least

Great fun!. I was intimidated by the metro/train system on my first visit, but taking the metro and the JR trains is now one of my favorite things about visiting Tokyo each time I'm there. It helped to learn that there are two systems--the metro and the JR trains (the JR system covers a wider area). Don't bother with single tickets, as you can't move between the two systems on a single ticket. Buy a Suica or Pasmo card. Not only do you not have to worry about figuring out your fare, but the Suica and Pasmo cards also work as a form of debit card in most of the station shops and for the all-important drink vending machines that are everywhere (love the iced green tea and the iced coffee). If you are confused or need help, ask anyone--whoever you ask will help you or find someone who can. Be sure to line up for the train at the designated spots and speak quietly when on the train.

Easy, even if you don't speak the language. Super easy, efficient system. One of the easier ones in the world. Definitely by a Passmo card before you start but very easy to move around and clean. People were all very quiet in the subway so make sure to not talk on your phone or even just too loud. Most stops are in Japanese and English so just listen and you will be fine.

Conquering the subway. the best way to see up and below the city! Great way to see the locals and the sights! For visitors get the unlimited subway pass for 3 days at the airport, just show your passport! If you miss that get to the subway ticketing machines.. Vending machines sell unlimited daily pass for 600 yen... Getting lost and wandering in and out of tokyo will be a breeze... The stores and displays are amazing even underground! The people around are always nice and very assisting... English announcements are clear and timely in the subway trains! Go go GO!

Don't worry...it's really easy!. Being English speakers who didn't speak a word of Japanese, we were understandably nervous about using the Tokyo subway. If you're in the same situation...please don't be. It's probably the easiest subway I've ever used. The maps in the main stations are usually in English and Japanese. Japanese people are the friendliest I've encountered in the world and whenever we had our guide book map out in subway stations we had people coming up to ask how they could help us! Plus there are always station staff on hand. The DK Tokyo guidebook available at any good bookshop or on the internet has an extensive subway map on the back page which we found invaluable for planning journeys. We found it was more economical to forget the various day passes etc. unless you're doing an extreme amount of journeys and just pay for single journeys as it's cheap as chips.The first time you use the machines, take a little extra time to figure it out. When you've done it once, it's easy peasy.

Journey through Tokyo. It is a bit confusing with two different operators. But the metro line is a good way to get around in the big city Tokyo. If you seem lost at the station, some Japanese will help you to figure out where you are heading. It was fun to experience the rush hour, not recommend to do this when you are bringing a lot of stuff with you.

Easy to use!. Day one was confusing as we arrived in peek traffic with our suitcases in Tokyo Station! However Japanese people were always offering help without us even asking and we were on our way in no time! A Pasmo card worked well for us as it saved us time having to buy a paper ticket each trip. Pasmo cards are bought from the electronic ticket machine and it has an English option If you return it to a manned ticket office at the end of your trip you will get the ¥500 + your remaining balance minus ¥250 returned :) Also pick up a Metro Map on your first day and it will become your best friend!

Easy to navigate. Don't be put off by the sheer size. The train system in Tokyo is pretty complicated, but just grab a Suica or Pasmo pass and dive into the subway. Most lines are on the main map (although a few places you might want to get to might be on separate maps, such as JR or Japan Rail lines) and they're very easy to follow. Just make sure you're heading towards the right direction. Many of the trains have English announcements and the signs are in western script as well as characters. A note about some of the apps you can get for your smartphone/tablet - again, they may not include all stations and all lines. If you're looking to get to the cafes/boutiques in Daikanyama, for example, that station is on one of the private lines in Tokyo. Your passes work but you won't find the station name on the subway map or app - ask at your hotel.The trains are clean, safe and run very efficiently. Try to avoid peak hour if you can, otherwise it can be very cramped.

Clean and efficient. Every train experience I've had in Japan can be explained in a few words: clean, efficient, and on time. The Japanese are very serious when it comes to their trains and travelling on the trains and metros is very safe and very easy to travel on. There may be times where people feel it's a bit complicated, but all the staff is very nice and helpful, so don't hesitate to ask them!

AMAZING. This is the best attraction in Japan, specialy because cabs are so expensive. Stations are massive, I saw a store in the underground levels of Tokio Station once, I tried to go back a few minutes later and never saw it again... stations are relly huge. In some stations near the exit there is a stamp that you can print on a paper to take as a souvenir. Very nice to go from station to station looking for the stamps, also helps you keep track of what you did in the trip. Try to get the front car, when you are approaching a station you can see the light from far away and then as you drive in everything lights up... makes for a great picture.

Easier than people think. Tokyo's known for its overcrowded and complicated transport system, but having used the ones in London, NYC, and Hong Kong, its not really a problem at all, Plus many have helpful officials to show you how. Not as daunting as you may think.

Very clean and efficient - but must use HyperDia. We used the metro system every day for three weeks while staying in Tokyo. We bought PASMO cards when we arrived at Haneda Airport (but SUICA is just as good - make sure you get either of these cards as soon as you arrive - you will use it all the time).As everyone says, the metro system is very clean and efficient BUT it's also hideously complicated, mainly due to the many different train companies running many different lines. We couldn't have survived without mobile internet to access HyperDia, which we needed for almost every single trip.Also, it gets expensive if you are staying some distance from the city (e.g. Machida). We quickly worked-out that's it's cheaper to stay closer to Shinjuku/Shibuya and pay higher rent rather than stay further out and pay up to AUD$40 per day per person for train travel.

So Efficient; So Clean!. As a regular user of the NYC subway system, I was overwhelmed by the cleanliness and efficiency of the Tokyo subways. Every station and train was pristine, on time and, even if crowded, pleasant. Since the stations and lines are written in English it's pretty easy to figure out which train to take to your desired destination.

Gets you there, but you need to be adventurous!. Millions of Japanese depend on this system as their only way to get anywhere. It's always crowded, it's always crazy, and it's very confusing. But if you don't want to spend the money on cabs ( very costly) and you are doing lots of sightseeing, this is the best way to travel in Japan. Before you attempt it go online and get a guide do you know what to expect.

Perfect, clean and fast!. I'm really amazed with the quality of the service. The metro is clean (I mean perfectly clean), fast, it has well ventilation (it's not stinky like most of other metos around the world), it's pretty fast and always on time. Even if you don't know Japanese langiage, it's perfectly described with iconographic so don't worry: you won't loose yourself! Perfectly clean restrooms as an addition :)

Download the Metro App!. I highly recommend downloading the Tokyo Metro app., it saved me. Also, purchase a Pasmo card at any Metro station, it can be used for multiple forms of public transportation. Load your card with money whenever needed. I was told that if I didn't use all the money, they would refund the remainder. Metro is clean & quick. It can be a bit confusing at first. Plan your route ahead of time & sit near one of the screens that tells you what stop is coming up next. The Metro enabled me to check out so many different areas of Tokyo.

There's always a train!. You can do it! I was incredibly intimated before going to Japan and using the train BUT it's super easy and convenient. If you know you'll be going to several places in that day, I recommend buying a day trip pass as you will be transferring quite a lot. I will be honest and say that NOT every relationship can endure the metro. After three days, we used only taxis to save our relationship. But you never have to wait for a train! Longest I waited was 5 mins and they are SO Clean!!

Crowd, yet Clean. Tokyo is a busy city, there were so many lines in Tokyo Subway System, but it is not that difficult to comprehend where to go. It is crowded, punctual, and even after all the crowds it is still clean. In the rush-hour, even when the passengers are pushing each other to find a space, people are just so quiet that the pushing-things never break-out into a chaos

What an efficient way to travel. The Metro runs on schedule which is about every 5 minutes during the day. transfers are clearly marked in Japanese and English, some of the walk are very long but very well explained. Elevators and escalators are extensive but many are not handicapped accessible. Cars are clean, sometimes crowded but I always managed to get a seat eventually. In all, The Tokyo Metro was a good experience.
Best Metro I have been on. As is to be expected with Japanese transport systems, this one is pretty hard to fault. Thoroughly enjoyed travelling from district to district on the metro.

Walk walk walk. And walk some more. Also, stairs........lots of them. Also, pay close attention to the yellow exit maps and signs when you leave the train....otherwise you will walk more than you intended. This subway is a great workout and the fastest way to get from point A to B. Solid shoes are a necessity.

One of the best. At 1st it looked confusing. So many lines and providers. However, every sign is clear in Japan. We can even print out our route if we are too afraid to forget it. The machine is available at the station and we can use it for free. The punctuality is out of question.

Fast and cheap metro. When I was in Tokyo I really wanted to see the most of it. It was pretty difficult because of its size. Metro in Tokyo is a bit complicated to understand but you will get used to it pretty soon. I was admiring how fast it is and how cheap. Definitely great system of public transportation in Tokyo - thumbs up.

Going Underground, and seeing the city... If you really want to see a great city like Tokyo and see how it works, it's not just the attractions you need to look at look at how the city works everyday, and there's no better way to do that than to travel on Tokyo Metro particularly during rush hour, when thousands on suited Tokyo men and women on their daily commute to work, I was put in mind of a Lowry painting, it is all very orderly, as we have come to expect of Japan everybody would stop and form a queue a safe distance from the platforms edge at the trains door opened there a slight serge forward as the carriages fill up with uniformed guards pushing the last passengers on the door close the train leaves, and within two minutes another train arrive so if your just a tourist there's no problem in waiting. With not speaking Japanese I was a little apprehensive about using the Metro at first however I needn't have been as there are sign and announcements in English, touch the left hand corner of the ticket machine and it displays in English, plus most of the staff speak enough English to help you...

Getting about on the Subway. A little confusing at first but with a little thought travelling on Tokyo Subway is both cheap and easy. There is always a Subway employee available to help with directions and advice. The only drawback is the amount of steps and a shortage of lifts

Fantastic system. Not much to say here, one of the best metro systems in the whole world. Easy to navigate around Tokyo, fast and clean. There are English signs and announcements everywhere, you will be fine.

A bit difficult to understand at first, but once you get it - it's awesome.. As the metro in Tokyo is operated by several companies, it's almost impossible to get complete information about a planned route from a single company, as each company tries to promote its own lines.However, just use Google maps and it will plan your routes accordingly.Tickets are easily available from vending machines and you are better off getting a card and top it up whenever it is done.The Metro is safe throughout the day and night, but try to avoid rush hours if you are claustrophobic, as it DOES get hectic, especially at big stations such as Tokyo, Shinagawa and Shinjuku (which is a maze of platforms, escalators and lines).

Another interesting experience in Japan!. Metro in Tokyo - is a very complex system of transportation because numerous metro lines belong to different carriers. However, as soon as we understood how it works and why different vending machines have different interfaces, we started enjoying our metro rides :) Also, we were surprised that there were no queues and not that many people even during rush hours. Taking into account ridiculously high taxi fares, metro is indisputably the most convenient transport. Be ready that Tokyo metro is very expensive (120 - 500 yen for a ride inside city area) - and enjoy it :)

Still one of the best. It had been 30 years since I first took the Tokyo metro, it remains pratically the same, punctual, crowded during peak hours, efficient and relatively cheap. It is amasing to see that despite some of the carriages were obviously old, they were still clean and tidy. Stops announcements are now also in English. It is so easy to navigate. All you need is to know where you are and where you want to go to. Each station can be identified with a coloured circle that designates the line and with the station number inside the circle. There are clear signs of which direction and next station the train is heading towards.

efficient, clean and crowded. The Local JR trains and subways in Tokyo should be model for the world in mass transportation. My biggest complaint is the confusion to exits in their major JR stations for short term visitors.

Easy to navigate. If you have ANY experience with Japan's train ticketing process, this will be a breeze for you. If not, you'll quickly get the hang of it! There was always an option on the automated screen for English - check the upper right corner. Grab a map at the station for suggested places in different categories, such as "night-life" or "shopping." It was also very clean and prompt. In a city with 20 million people, they designed their transportation system right! We NEVER waited more than 3 minutes for a train and people operate on the mentality that "1 more can fit."

Train lines forest. Incredible and perfect. The first impression you will get when you grab a Tokyo metro subway map is fear and confusion. But, if you study it carefully you will soon discover the endless possibilities of this world's most intense subway system.All the lines carry their name, letter and a color. Each station bears it's name and a number preceded by a letter of the line. The trains bear the same color as a stripe on wagons.First, you have to position yourself, find the place where you wanna go and decide the best and fastest option. Interchange stations are encircled on a map. While changing simply follow the signs (according to line name and color), then see which direction you need in order to go on the right track.TICKETS !! For me the best way is to buy a 1, 2 or 3 day (specially 3 day) Tokyo subway ticket on the airport upon arrival. It covers both, the Tokyo metro and Toei metro lines which you'll use. I didn't do that, as I was misled reading articles it doesn't pay off. That's not true. Tokyo is an enormous city, forget foot sightseeing, forget the buses which can be jammed in traffic. You are doomed on metro, and you'll use it extensively. That 3 day pass is only 1.500 Yen, and I spent over 3.000 Yen on the Pasmo card for 3 days. You can calculate yourself, one ride is approximately 180 Yen (depending on a distance traveled and lines used). You'll use at least 5 times the metro during the day.This Pasmo (or Suica, the same but different brand) card is the second best option. You buy a card which you can easily refill whenever you need on machines in every station. You validate it when entering, and they deduct the sum when exiting from metro. On the display is shown how much did you pay and how much you have left on your card. Don't get stressed if you haven't got enough on your card, you will easily pay the difference to very polite station attenders. The machines are easy to use. Just select English and follow the instructions on a touch screen. NOTE 1: Pasmo and Suica work nationwide. You can use them in Osaka, Kyoto, Hiroshima,..... (but there are better options for those cities, see reviews for them).NOTE 2: When finished with the need for the card you can return it at any metro station, and you'll get a 500 Yen deposit refund for the card, plus any unused money you have on it.STATIONS !! Stations are small underground cities. There are plenty of shops, shopping malls, restaurants, supermarkets,...you name it. You can easily get lost there. Just don't be distracted by those, know your way and follow the signs. The signs are bilingual, each has English explanations.EXITING the stations: DON'T just follow the crowd towards the nearest exit!!! You could exit a mile away from your desired point. Each station has several exits, some of them up to 10. When exiting the train find a big yellow list of exits. Find your aim (attraction you're heading for) on that list, and find out the corresponding exit number for it. Then just follow the signs towards that exit.

Can't Beat It. If you visit Tokyo, you will use the Metro system. It is incredibly efficient and gets you anywhere you need to go. Best to use a smartphone app to figure out routes between stations including connection points and lowest fares.

Amazing transport. Initially it is hard to understand due to the lack of English signage and lack of English speakers but once you understand it, the possibilities of getting around Tokyo quickly and cheaply are endless. Get a Subway map and pick your route. Go to the ticket machines and press English. On the machine you pick the price of the journey, not the route. Check the over head maps which give the price for the stop you need. Once on the train the stops are called out in English as well as Japanese. Its so quick and efficient you can plan your trips around the city easily. Some English Speaking Japanese stopped to ask if we needed assistance. The people who can speak English are very helpful.
Reliable & Clean. Makes getting around Tokyo fast and easy. Can buy a refillable pass for subway and railroad. You can get a refund on unused portion.

Unlike any other public transportation experience. As someone who uses a wheelchair I am always apprehensive about public transportation. I have had may bad experiences traveling around the world.I have never had such a pleasurable adventure as using the Tokyo Subway system. Arrive at the station master's kiosk and tell them where you are going and within minutes a personal guide with a ramp appears an guides you to a specific spot on the platform and helps you board the train. At the other end another guide is waiting at the specific spot where you will exit the train and places a ramp and helps you off. You are then guided thru the station to the exit.If you have to transfer between trains the process is continued.Amazing service. The other rides are great at giving you space. One of our highlights of our trip to Japan.
Very efficient. Clean & fast, easy to comprehend once you get over the initial disorientation.The platforms are well marked & so is the distance to them.Not expensive.People are extremely polite.

Maximum efficiency!. In my experience, Tokyo demonstrates the best example of public transport in the world. Especially by comparison to public transport in Australia. Trains are frequent, very rarely late, ticketing system is intuitive, maps are good and have english, clean, fast, safe, people are v polite and helpful, trains are quiet inside, no phone calls or people eating. A pleasure to get around.

Tokyo Metro. You probably find yourself thinking that the metro will be hard to figure out, but it isn't at all! Once you get accustomed, you're good to go. The metro is clean, quiet, and very simple.

So, so simple - and so clean!. The map will probably look a bit intimidating at first, but it really is simple once you get the hang of it. Each line is associated with the first letter of the train line name (e.g., A = Asakusa), the color of the line (e.g., green = Shinjuku) and then each stop is denoted by a number (e.g., A20 = Tokyo Sky Tree). Take a photo of the map on your phone so you can easily refer to it. When you get to the train platforms and need to determine which side of the track to be on, just look for the range of numbers that contains the stop where you are headed. For example, if you need A20, look for a sign at the platform that says something like "A12-20" and that will let you know that you are headed toward the Sky Tree. Simple!If your point of initiation is Haneda or Narita airport, just find the rails at the lower level of the airport. The information desks can help point you to the best line for you based on your destinations of choice. As with all subways, hang onto your ticket! You'll need it to get through the turnstyle to get in AND out of the train area (sometimes you will insert these multiple times) so you do not want to lose these. Prices are very reasonable and the trains are timed exceptionally well. The trains, platforms, entrances/exits, shops, food vendors, restrooms, etc. are all impeccably clean and efficient. The U.S. could learn a lot from the Japanese transit system!

It's very, very good !!. One of the best in the works, very efficient, always on time, clean & soo quiet in the carriages......everyone is very polite & respectful.......just get your Pasmo card from one of the machines (500 yen deposit, returned when redeem).......makes the whole process a lot easier & simple......you might even get to feel like a local :))

Except the bird sound. It is a very well organised and easil used system. Just go to a counter and touch to English. Than to Pasmo, it will help you to create your own card, with your name on it. Or you can buy a ticket to your route.You do not have to know English. Englisw words are written next to Japanese ones but sometimes smaller.In Japan, they drive like English people, on the left. But when walking in the metro, it changes. Since it is a very busy metro and many lines cross, walking on the left does not work. So follow the lines on the walls or on the floor.I will kindly ask the metro officers to add some more bird sings. Same sound, non stop, irrigating.
the best Transportation in Japan. When you are travelling in Tokyo, it would be the best transportation that you can easily go to the visit points by it. It is fast and convenient to all travelers.

Efficient and Convenient. Get a PASMO card (500 Yen deposit and 500 Yen cost) to breeze through the gates without having to buy a ticket for every leg (sometimes you have to get another ticket just to transfer). Also, download a Tokyo Metro App on your phone. Make sure you know the exit for where you want to go! At some stations exit 1 and exit 20 can be over a mile apart at street level. Most stations have maps showing major attractions to help you out (in English too). Rush hour trains can be a packed with people so brush up on subway etiquette (bags, noises, conversation volume). There are a couple negatives: lots of stairs and you're almost always underground (some lines come above ground outside of city center)

The smartest way to move around Tokyo. I can't imagine a trip to Tokyo without using the metro...it just wouldn't be the same. If you want an authentic feel of how most move around the city (besides the occasional car or riding bikes: another main transportation), I would suggest going down those stairs into the metro. Don't worry, it's much safer and cleaner than any around the world. It may take you a couple rides but once you understand it, you'll realize its one of the most efficient public transportations in the world. And lucky for most, almost everything is written in English as well!Now let me just clarify, during the rush hour, you will not be too happy pushed up so close to a bunch of strangers...BUT you should definitely see it sometime. Tightly, structured chaos like no other

World's best metro. Hans down the best metro in the world. Everything runs on time, it's very easy to understand the system and it basically takes you everywhere, with 200+ stops. The last rides are around 00:30am though, so don't count on taking the metro after midnight. Starts at about 5am.

It's The Way To Go. Once we figured out how to buy the tickets, we were smooth sailing all over the place. Had to figure it out using the silly little pictures but managed. It's all in making memories.

Efficient and easy to navigate. Best way to get around Tokyo - with well marked maps (often will tell you what's the next station along with the past one) and easy transfers.Pay attention to the exits - some stations have more than 10 - as getting off on the wrong one can leave you much further away from where you want to be - but all and all - fantastic and cost effective service

Worlds best metro . Fantastic metro in Japan, trains run like clock work and also on time,Metro can get you most places in Tokyo to with in a few blocks.And they run every few minutes so if you just miss a train another is only 3 to 5 minutes away depending on line.
The only way to go!. Best way to get around the city. The best metro I've tried so far. On time and clean! Riding the metro is an experience in itself. Nothing like anywhere else I've been!

Good way to get around Tokyo. The Tokyo Metro system together with the JR is the best way to get around Tokyo. It is worth spending a little time studying the systems and learning the way to navigate them. The only unfortunate thing about it for visitors is that the systems are operated by different companies and whilst efforts have been made to ensure connectivity that could be better. Another issue is that most Tokyo Metro Maps do not include information about the JR system, whereas often the JR Yamanote line may be the more convenient system to use within the city, especially for commutes between the main railway stations and the attractions near those stations. Nevertheless the subways and the commuter trains combined is definitely the best way to get around the city. It is also a blessing to visitors that locals are very polite and there is no pushing except during the worst of the rush hours.

Best Metro In The World.. I can not put into words how much I loved using the Tokyo Metro. Super easy Super clean and the people are so polite. The Japanese people are super friendly and super polite when it comes to manners in public places. The Metro had both Japanese and English so its super easy to get around.

Punctual, Accessible. Love the punctuality of the Tokyo Metro trains making it easy to plan our travelling around.Works well with Google Maps about the timings/platforms too. Would only advise to buy the Day pass if you are travelling 3 or more times on the metro for that particular day. Pre-Planning is good as you would know if you require to take the JR or the Metro Lines.
jjkkkk. we really enjoyed our trip in tokyo japan sleeping eyes every where nice people and we did enjoy the metro quickly

Very well connected. Buy tokyo metro one day rail pass , and you can visit all places in your itinerary. Good connectivity, only problems is there are lot of line and connections, so one should know very well how to travel in Metro in Japan.
Great Public Transportation. The Metro is always on time and easy to get around the Tokyo Prefectures. It is very clean and safe for all,children, women....
This is Tokyo. If you want to see what Tokyo is, this is the spot. The metro itself it's one of the things that you have to see.

Great subway system. Great way to get around the city. Easy to follow directions and map. Trains are clean and cheap to use. Visit the Shibuya station area and grab a coffee in upstairs Starbucks to get the best view of the crossway.

Great way to get around Tokyo. get the manaca card, just top up as needed & can be used for vending machines!! Cheap & easy way to travel round Tokyo. Very clean, but very busy if you travel before 9am.

Beyond clean and organized!. Tokyo metro system is very easy to use and is so clean and inexpensive! If traveling within tokyo this is your best bet! Taxis start at 730 yen and if stuck in traffic can cost you nearly 3000! Not worth it! Take the train as much as you can to save yourself time and money!

Clean and efficient!. I personally love Japan and their metro system is awesome. You may need a day or so to get familiarize with it, but it's actually very efficient and clean. You can petty much get everywhere, very convenient. If you're planning to be travelling on subway often each day, then Suica pass is the way to go as you don't need to carry so much change, just tap and go. Otherwise, when I was in Tokyo, I just pay as I go. :)

Definition of efficiency and precision. Most large cities in the world have metros and they do a good job, but the Tokyo metro carves a niche for itself. It is not just about maintaining precise timings, but the overall system as a whole is worth emulating. Shinjuku is the busiest station in the world with approx 3.7 million footfalls per day - yet is cleaner than most stations, the world over, that do not receive even one-tenth of footfalls. There is no fighting for seats even in crowded trains. The staff is super-friendly. Even for a traveller who has just arrived, the signposts can lead to the correct train. It takes some time to understand the ticketing machines, but they are very user-friendly. I guess, the whole metro system gives efficiency a new meaning when the number of commuters are taken into account.

All Metros in the World should be this awesome!. Tokyo's Metro is a modern marvel of urban transportation! Uber-convenient (you can get within a block or 2 of ANYwhere in Tokyo & it's as easy to figure out as the Paris Metro), uber-timely (trains arrive & depart precisely on time every few minutes). A mere fraction of the cost of taxis and sooo much faster ... I swear every traffic intersection in Tokyo has a stoplight so cabs take forever!3 pieces of advice: (1) get a Suica "smart card" loaded with value, then you just "tap in/tap out" like Oyster Card on London Tube; (2) don't get intimidated ... at first it seems overwhelming and at first blush everything seems to be in Japanese ... take a deep breath, walk a bit further along in a station or on a platform and you WILL find a map in English, also the digital signs everywhere cycle between Japanese & English; the onboard announcements are easy to understand too since they enunciate very clearly & Japanese is very phonetic ... Harajuku will sound like Harajuku when it's announced!; (3) AVOID rush hour, the urban legends are true, it you're not claustrophobic now, you will be after riding Tokyo's Metro during rush hour!The only time I got stumped was trying to reload my Suica card at a ticket machine ... just go to a manned booth, and they will help you out with a smile, even if they don't speak English. Just hand over your card & cash and they'll do the rest.By the way, every station has SPOTLESSLY CLEAN bathrooms. So convenient!

Best in the world. I have travelled all over the world including London, Paris and New York and I beleive Tokyo's metro is by far the best! It is clean, well organised and the metro staff are super friendly and want to help you. There is also a train every few minutes so it is incredibly efficient! What a great way to get around this amazing city!

A well oiled machine. Wow talk about efficiency. The Japanese transport system is the best we've travelled in anywhere in the world. Don't rush if you think you will miss your train, another on will be along in less than 5 minutes and arriving exactly on time. Meticulous clockwork, pristine carriages (no graffiti) or trash or slashed seats and the station guards in well groomed uniforms proud of their jobs. We travelled all over the city and a cab fare for a 340 yen rail trip was $35 and took a third of the time.Get a travel map of the metro system and its easy and cheap.

Crazy Japanese People!!. It's efficient, fast, and super clean but it's not the top attraction. It's still just a metro. Crazy People!!The toilets in the stations are super clean compared to other metros around the world.
amazing. i have been to so many developed countries but it is true that Tokyo subway has no match. It is clean , on time, convinient and fast

The only way to travel in Tokyo. It was not the best start for us when we boarded our first Metro train to head towards our hotel in the morning rush hour. Donning sunglasses, bright T-shirts, travel backpacks and massive grins at finally arriving in Japan, we sat down and promptly realised that everyone else in the packed carriage was a middle-aged Japanese businessman wearing a suit and most of them were staring at us. It's fair to say we felt a bit out of place.Anyway, you can't really beat the Tokyo Metro - compared to other subway networks such as Paris and London, it is cleaner, faster, and quieter. People do not talk on the trains at all, and nor should you. It is very reasonable priced and you will simply need to purchase a Pasmo or Suica card and top it up. Each station has a machine you can do this, which can be switched to English. By my calculations, around a week's worth of frequent travel could be fulfilled by 5000 yen per person, which is about £30. The card is then used to scan yourself in and out of the stations.Contrary to what some people have said, I believe it is fairly easy to navigate as long as you have a map with you. A pocket-sized subway map was strangely hard to find so just ask for one at the tourism/information desk at the station you're at rather than wandering around searching. Most stations have fairly good English translations and with the help of the display screens on the trains you can usually be confident of where you're going.The screens on the trains are very useful - they won't just update you on the route, and how long it is going to take to get to each stop, but they provide a blueprint of the next station so you know which side to wait on and where the doors to exit the station are going to be on the platform. The Tokyo Metro is just like the London Underground, but 10 years in the future.

Likely one of the most efficient Metro's in the World. If you have lived in London for a long time and used the Tube, I would bet that you have heard the following statement much to often then you would have liked to: " We are sorry about this delay but we have a signal problem". The only time the Metro trains are delayed is if there is a major disaster like an earthquake, serious weather conditions like severe storms, suicides. Signal failures and planned engineering works are rare. I do not know how they do it but the trains usually arrive on time to the second.

Not really the no. 1 thing to do in Tokyo!. I think some of the reviewers might be playing with their wonderful reviews of the complicated, dirty, polluted and cramped metro! Compared to taxis it's a godsend- relatively cheap and seems v efficient. But it's so complicated and difficult to work out- it makes the tube in London seem like a dream! People here seem more polite than other cities - in Japan people wait for others to alight and don't push on. I'd definitely recommend it as a mode of transport and, it's range of stations is fantastic, but I wouldn't go out of my way to use it if it could be avoided and, in my opinion, it's certainly not the number 1 must see or do thing here!

Tokyo travel options. SubwayGetting around Tokyo is easy – super easy. The subway system is remarkably efficient and you will rarely be waiting more than five minutes for a train. Signage is in both English and Japanese although station entrances are not necessarily conspicuous from the street. Ticket machines, available in English are located at all stations and day passes which are valid for a 24 hour period can be purchased for 1000 yen (about $10 AUD). The amount of people who utilise the subway is homage to its efficiency; even at close to midnight businessmen, students and trendy young things are rushing on and off carriages on their way home. Some subway stations also connect to JR lines and I’d recommend purchasing a pass for travel on these lines if you plan on going outside Tokyo (see below).Gents, be aware that on weekday mornings until 9:30 some decorated pink carriages at the front of the train are designated female only in an effort to ward off wandering hands in crowded peak hour commuter carriages. JR EastJapan Rail combines the suburban rail network, Narita Express and Shinkansen (bullet trains). If you are travelling outside of the Tokyo area, utilising JR is a must. Special passess are designated for tourists and must be bought prior to entering country. A five day pass that’s valid for fourteen days will cost about $280 AUD and use is only counted on the day you travel so you don’t need to travel on consecutive days to get your money’s worth. Initially purchase of the pass is fairly hassle free however acquiring it once in country can prove a hassle and was the only time we were failed by the usual Japanese efficiency.On arrival in Tokyo, present your purchase printout and passport to a booth located near the entrance to the subway at Narita airport. Although the line was only around 30 people deep it took us nearly two hours to get our pass – not my preferred way of spending my time after a long haul flight. The Narita Express has regular trains running between Tokyo and Narita airport. The carriages are spacious, comfortable and clean. Seats can be reserved in advance either online or at the station. Drinks and food are available for purchase and unlike the subway, eating is encouraged on-board.Shinkansen is the fastest way to get around if you are travelling a long distance. The ride from Tokyo to Nagano takes around 90 minutes vice a four – five hour trip on a bus. The ride is surprisingly smooth and feels like you’re 40,000 feet up rather than on the ground.TaxisYou won’t normally need to use a taxi in Tokyo unless you have a large amount of luggage or have been partying into the night and missed the last train. As with all other transport options in Japan, taxis are extremely clean and the drivers friendly and courteous. Most will not speak English so it’s a good idea to have a map or the name of your destination written in Japanese.

Best way to get around Tokyo!. Forget taxi's! Ludicrous prices unless there's 3-4 of you travelling or its after midnight! As a foreigner it was super simple to use the ticket machines. Just buy the lowest cost ticket then when you get to your destination there are fare adjustment machines. Pop your ticket in and pay the extra. What a fantastic system! The trains are always on time. A bit chaotic during peak hours but that's to be expected...

Surprisingly convenient. Having been absolutely confused when preparing myself in the internet with the metro system of Tokyo, it worked out really well in the end. We bought a Suica card at 7 Eleven and Google Maps showed us the required connections. The one or two confusions at the track were clarified by helpful Tokoyers. Wonderful, a great way to travel throughout the city.
avoid peak hours. may be impossible to board during peak hours, so schedule your trips, especially if travelling with children and luggage

Effective and the people flow was amazing. Have you ever been experience a metro line like a spider web? If not, try Tokyo Metro, the best ever. The only down side of it was the ticket machines. Tickets for railway and subway are separated in different machine. Please make sure you buy the correct one.

Complicated but easy. Complicated if you don't understand japanese, but here everything is so clear and easy that you just have to follow the signs. Even when you think you're lost, you'll find your way.

Metro efficiency. Hey, the Tokyo Metro, is a metro system that works. Given the incredible number of folks the system moves the Metro is efficient and quite easy to navigate. Guidance is given in both Japanese and English and it is an exceptionally easy system to get around in. And the system is reasonably cheap and easy to use given one of the easy to purchase passcards. The crowds using the system are generally polite and well behaved and toilet facilities are convenient.. Certainly, given the big distances around Tokyo the Metro our JR network makes touristing very easy. Tokyo's metro is great, but it is only on par to systems in all the great cities. One uses the metro in Tokyo, one would not go to Tokyo with a priority to "see" the Metro.

Challenging but great. Overall the Tokyo Metro (subway) and train system can be both scary and confusing for any foreigner or visitor. The main reason is that there are two main subway companies: Tokyo Metro and Toei Metro additionally to the JR railway system and they do not connect on a level that you might be used to from other Metropoles around the world. If you get a subway map and don't find a subway to the place you want to go - don't give up, just check the other map. Or even the Railway. Be aware that you often have to leave the metro station in order to get to the other metro line (of the other company) and that you have to buy a seperate ticket for that as well. Asking my japanese friends from Tokyo how they get somewhere they all say "no idea, but I have an app for that". Highly recommended. If you do not have an app, make sure you have the metro maps of both companies, and ideally of the Japan Railway (JR) which can save you lots of time during your trip!

Efficiency with bells!. I'm travelling in Tokyo this month. For a city of 36 million, their metro system is amazing! Trains run on time. Platform guards call out the destination, thank you for travelling with them and bow as you leave each station. The trains themselves are spotlessly clean. Everything is pristine...the carriages, the stations, the platforms. There are no litter bins because there is no litter! The information on the trains is in Japanese, Korean and English. There are live, visual diagrams giving clear and coherent information. It makes life easy in a country where I'm not yet familiar with the language.

Totally reliable trains.. Very cheap for tourists. I paid £15 for 4 days unlimited metro ticket. Exceptionally safe just as Japanese people are very friendly. Crime is almost unheard of just like Saudi and UAE. Super experience.

Best system in the world.. The best way to get around Tokyo is through its extensive subway/metro system. It is, hands down, the best in the world. No other country has got a system that’s more efficient, clean, ingenious and well managed. It’s mainly divided into JR lines and Metro. Sometimes you have to exit one to get to the other, but signage is clear and locals/attendees go above and beyond to help you, should you have any issues. Depending on your location and destination, each trip costs around 200 yen. E.g. Shinjuku to Shibuya is around 120 yen, whereas Shinjuku to Asakusa is about 350 yen. We got a momo card, and topped it up with 2,000 yen, which lasted 5 days (stayed in Shinjuku, used it at least twice a day).
One of the best . I think is one of the best in te world. All you need is a map that you can get a any station. Thicketing machines have english option and everi station is marked.

super efficient. A quick cheap way to get around this huge busy city. Every line is colour coded and stops numbered so its very easy to find your way around. The machine for buying tickets has an english option too and the staff are happy to help us lost looking tourists!

Very efficient system. At first you would find it terrible and it would make you worried, lost but calm down and look at it again and again, you would find it easy by colour codes, then you would work out to way to go easily.My tip is to buy one day ticket even though you travel outside Tokyo unless you stay in Shinjuku, it will save you heaps.

Impressive!. Just one word - impressive!!! For a huge mega city like Tokyo the whole metro and railway system of public transport is really remarkable... efficient, on time, fast, super clean... it was not easy at first to deal with metro maps and lines but after first day and with a little help of always helpful and super polite metro staff we manage to deal with it with no problem... and yes it is cheapest way to go around Tokyo... it is however recommendable to get informed in advance via internet... there are lots of useful web sites about Tokyo metro and railway network...

super easy and super clean.. The metro in Japan is soo easy to use and really clean. Compared to China its felt much much safer and really easy to understand where to go. I used it almost everyday. But morning and Afternoon were really crowdedSo I recommend avoiding those time.

comfusing system so research the internet first. The subway system is complex, and runs below much of Tokyo. It is very confusing.to figure how to get where you are going. To purchase ticks very difficult. Research on the internet for direction. Retain the name of the exit station.Try to avoid Tokyo station, as It has so many people,but it has information desks,and we wandered around. Remmender to research the internet, including a search for “map Tokyo metro”.

Pretty low-tech, but efficient. The Metro is hands-down the best way to get around Tokyo. Just take the time to figure it out. First note that there are several competing lines and I could not find a map that showed all of them. So, we stuck with the biggest, the Tokyo Metro line, in combination with the JR Yamanote circle line. We never tried any Toei trains.If you want to use these lines buy a Suica pre-pay smart card from a kiosk at any station. Simply flash the card at the turnstile reader and you're off. If needed add more yen. You can also use the card at many station eateries and vending machines. We also used the card in Yokohama. Before you leave Japan simply sell the card back for full value at a JR ticket office (like when you buy your ticket on the Narita Express to NRT).Best tip - don't rush out of any train station. Figure out which of the numerous exits is closest to your destination.Interesting note - Japanese do not yak on their cell phones while on any trains. What a pleasant surprise.

One of the Best in the World. The Tokyo Metro is the cheapest and best way to travel in Tokyo. It is composed of several subway and train line. If you travel via JR lines, use their ticketing machine. If subway, use their system. From the map, see your location and get the amount of ticket. You can also use suica card. Follow the direction of train name to plaform and ride on it, The train and subway is always on time. If you are not sure try asking. From Narita airport to station, take NEX line, show passport to avail of 1500 yen trip, take taxi from nearest station to hotel if near. Japanese are good in giving direction by signage. There are also whole day pass which expires by midnight.

Tokyo metro system, best in the world. I have travelled the world backpacking, now I find myself in tokyo again 15 years on being a goldsmiths and silversmith, and my homestay is on the outskirts of the city.Normally I would leave plenty of time to get from A - B. Here this system runs perfectically no leaves on the lines....no points failure.....a smooth and pleasant ride if you miss rush hour into Shinjiku and Shibuya.don't worry about getting squeezed it's all part of the fun , and you will not hear an angry word from anyone. you will not even get breathed on as the Japanese are polite enough to wear surgical masks if there is any chance of a cold....so no germs are spread.the drivers are immaculate white gloves hat and suit. the guards on the platform do a wonderful arm display that only the japanese will do it will bring a smile to your face every time a train inbound outbound comes past......London you are the pits.....take a leaf from these guys.....London is way too expensive and too many guards doing far too little. shame on you London Underground......after the 2012 Olympics are thought no going back......but how disappointed I am. £1 into Tokyo = £2.70 into zone 1 from zone 2. Complete and utter rip off......you obviously have so much more to learn. this is where I am not proud to be British.......can you not looks after the tourists abit more?

Amazingly Simple System to Use. I travel quite often and try to use local transportation systems in the larger cities. This can be a challenge in many foreign countries but it is always an interesting experience. The Tokyo metro system is one of the most impressive systems I have yet found. There are several interconnecting lines that will get you to any part of the city in a timely fashion. As a tourist, I used the 2 day pass (bought at the airport), more to save time than money. This pass lets you get on any of the subways within the city, although the pass does not work on the JR above ground train that goes around the city (Think Lost in Translation). The metro system provides great maps and signage, with instructions (written and oral) in English. Once you figure out how to use the maps to exit the subway (a little tricky at first) and link these to a tourist map, you will be able to exit the subway very close to your intended destination. The city has several street level maps of the local area (close to subway entrances and bus stops). I found these great to get my bearings and walk throughout the city without ever getting too lost. Combined with walking, this is the best way to get around Tokyo.

Excellent transportation system. For over a year now, I have been using Tokyo Metro for days I'd like to spend strolling around spots in Tokyo. It totally didn't come as a surprise to me that Tokyo Metro is listed as a top destination in TripAdvisor, because Tokyo rail transportation is in itself a wonderful experience.Trains servicing Tokyo Metro are generally clean and are punctual by the minute. Train stations are likewise clean, despite most of them being old structures in use for nearly a century. Huge train stations tend to be labyrinthine in configuration, but accurate directions and labels are provided. Such directions are bilingual at the least; some even have translations in four languages.For my own strolls, I make use of the Tokyo Metro Day pass at around 700yen. The pass may be used for a whole day and is applicable for all Tokyo Metro Stations. This makes trips to Tokyo very affordable, and gives a traveller plenty of destination options. Many Tokyo attractions are near a Tokyo Metro Station; but on a rare case in which there isn't any nearby, a traveller may still opt to avail of other affordable passes that allow entrances to Tokyo Metro and other railways (e.g. JR East, Toei).Probably the only setback with Tokyo Metro is that like any other Japanese railway service, it gets a little too busy and packed on rush hours, but that shouldn't be a bother if a trip is planned not to fall on crazy hours.

Best metro ever!. An impressive metro system which has many lines and an amazingly fast speed. The price is much more cheaper than a taxi, and it's extremely punctual, making the best choice for getting around in Tokyo.

Dont need taxi. Me and a friends visited tokyo for the first time back in 2013, when we landed at the airport we did take a taxi to the hotell, but from there we only used the Metro lines. its a easy and fast alternative to a taxi. recomend to buy a multible pass card so you dont need to buy a ticket every time.

Don't worry it will be fine! . We were initially a little concerned about coping on the Tokyo metro. .we are very much country cousins down here in little old New Zealand! So if we can manage anyone can! What an amazingly efficient clean quiet system! For the most part we kept to the inner city loop although we ventured off a couple of times. We found it relatively easy and when we needed assistance there was always a help desk attendant who spoke enough English to guide us,as well as the charming friendly locals who on several occasions came up to us to see if we needed help. If you are hesitant, don't be!

Impressive. tokyo metro is clean, quite, organized and complicated. its not cheap. i used app to get around the city and it worked ok. there are 2 different companies running different lines, sometimes you need change stations and purchase another ticket to get to your destination. metros + jr trains are the best way to get around this huge metropolis. there are vending machines and toilets in everyone station

Great way to get around Tokyo. It's a bit overwhelming at first.... Just ask for help in figuring out the various routes etc... Everyone I asked went out of there way to help. There is place to select English when purchasing your ticket via the machine. I used it once a day so I did not buy a pass. The cars are very clean like everything else in Japan.

Incredible!. Travelling around Tokyo was a huge worry for me when travelling here, however that fear was soon gone when taking the metro. The other reviews sum it up, but it was clean, simple and a great experience! The Japanese take pride in their jobs and the city and it shows. London transport could really learn from this! Metro tickets are cheap, I usually paid 170 yen and the machines and maps are in English. All stations have drinks machines if needed.The only bad thing is the toilets - basically a hole in the ground!Overall, Tokyo metro is a brilliant and efficient way of getting around an insanely busy city!

The Best Metro system in the world. No doubt Tokyo Metro is the Best Metro system in the whole world. So many lines, so many stops and so many different exits in each station could seem impossible to get all of this. Specially if you don't speak japanese. First of all, to buy the tickets in the machine is easy because you can choose English in the main menu. There are many different fares options ( 170 yen, 200 yen, 240 yen....) to choose from, so it depends how far are you travelling. There is a app called TOKYO SUBWAY NAVIGATION FOR TOURISTS that calculates the fare based on the start and finish stations. And always remember your exit number because each station has about 12 exits ( A1, A2, B1, B2....)

From not liking public transportation to - OH that's how you do that. Clean, no homeless, no graffiti, no panhandlers, people take pride in their stuff and don't ruin it by carving into it with a knife. I know it's crazy, but when you just ride and that's it, then its not bad and pretty cool on how it all just works and makes seance.
Best way to get around. Wow...I thought Osaka was crazy. This is worse so many people every minute of the day. Not hard once you know where you going but initial it's overwhelming.

Excellent train system!. It is confusing when you start reading the instruction. But it is like other train system in big city with far more complex yet easy to use train system. For foreigner, do not worry, there is always very helpful train crew to help in the ground, so use and enjoy it :)

What an overwhelming system. It is not just an underground train system, but an underground shopping system!
Tokyo's Metro is very efficient, and loved by the city's great population. Is it any wonder? Trains arrive on time, every time, and they are spotlessly clean.
Signage in stations is a problem and will need to be fixed before the city hosts the Olympics.

great but too complicated. tokyo metro is considered one of the highlights of tokyo city but i have to confess that i have been quite disappointed by some things.first of all, everytime you need to change subway you need to walk A LOT from one station to the other, it's understandable cos it's huge and there are many lines, what is really bad and spoils everything is that there are several and many of them belong to different societies so sometimes you need to buy several tickets for a few stops and it's very expensive

Best way to get around. Buy an IC card from one of the machines ( they have an English button) and start exploring. I wish every city had such a clean and extensive mass transit system. It really makes Tokyo's huge size manageable

How do they do it?..... Punctuality to 'die for'. If the information board says one minute to next train rest assured the next train will be there in one minute! And SO clean! Who'd want to be on the surface when you can ride the Metro :-)

Very good method of transportation. Very good way to get around. Only negative is that its on the pricey side. I didn't do my research well enough to find out if there were any discounts available. Most of my spending money went to this. I can honestly say that it beats the price of a cab and they're very clean. Japanese people do not eat on the go which explains why. There are many lines and maps with translations. The train itself speaks English when making stops. The ticket machine would be confusing for any one that doesn't know about it, but its simple once you get it. Just feed the ticket, collect it when passing. Feed the ticket again when leaving the station but don't expect it back.

Great yet...Crazy!. After living in NYC and taking the subway there for a few years, I never thought I would get to encounter another city that has a similar system if not crazier then NYC and this city was Tokyo! We took the metro for the first time from Asakusa to our hotel in Shingawa and realized that even though it was pretty well indicated, it was pretty insanely busy at the same time. There were so many people down there going every which way and at such a rapid pace. Even though most station are also indicated in English, taking the metro down there is not as simple as 1,2,3. There are so many different colors and so many different types of train that you need to pay attention and ask the locals if you are not so sure.Overall, this was a unique and amazing experience but I would not rate that has the top 5 things to do while in Tokyo, just like I would not rate the metro in the top 5 in NYC. Different, exciting, a little stressful at time and definitely worth doing a few times, but thats about it!

Easy and efficient way to get around Tokyo. The Tokyo netro is by far the best way to get around Tokyo. There are so many lines that you will always have a station close to where you are going. Get a Suica or Pasmo top it up and just swipe and go. Whilst there are a lot of lines, the lines and exit names are all in English, and, with arrows to point you in the right direction, after using it a couple of times you will find it straightforward. Just be careful on which exit you take as there are so many exits at some stations you could end up a long way away from where you wanted to be although the places that people want to go to are usually signposted. If you do want to get some information on how to get from one station to another use Hyperdia.com, it will give you all your options plus the times and cost.

Incredible!. Always on time and the best way to travel around Tokyo. Easy to use, rush hour is an experience in itself! Get a Suica or Pasmo card (load it up) and use. You can also use these at designated vending machines and even some stores. Card keeps a certain amount on it as the "fee" for the card, but you can get it back at certain locations (we keep ours as a souvenir).
Fast and on-time - to the second.. The most convenient transportation mean in Tokyo. Unbelievable fast and on time - I use it 5 times and it was never late even once.

Amazingly efficient!. You can get within walking distant of just about any destination in Tokyo via the Metro. The Pasmo card is a must. Get the card at one of the machines in the station, 500Y deposit is refundable. Load and reload as needed from the machines. The card will get you on any of the public transportation options and even allow you to buy a snack at one of many station kiosks. The trains are on time, clean and quiet. Be sure and note which exit gets you to your destination, because each station has many exits and taking the wrong one can put you blocks from your destination.

The only way to get there in Tokyo. This is the coolest subway in the world. It goes down like at least 10 stories and they have them everywhere. Then you can either walk or cab it fro the subway. If you don't like crowds, this might not be for you, lol.Very easy to find your way all over Japan via train/ Subways. Everybody speaks engrish too!Very Nice country, going back soon.

On time, clean, efficient.. Tokyo is huge, therefore getting around by metro is an easy way to get to know this city. The information is displayed in English. I don't speak Japanese, but was able to navigate without any problems. Avoid rush hours (Around 8 AM and 7 PM). Getting a SUICA or Pasmo is a good idea to save time, because you don't have to buy a new ticket for every ride. These are rechargeable cards for cashless payment. Just put your card on the gate when getting into the station and again when leaving.Tokyo Metro offers free WiFi in its stations.
Great transportation... Tokyo subway is excellent, easy and on time. Map is little bit complex but it is OK. Quite fast, comfortable and clean.

Like a precision clock. At the first glimpse, the subway and the subway stations in Tokyo seems a big mess. Several operators, several lines ... but actually after realizing the how it works, the system is very simple ans very well planned. It is very easy to travel around.All the trains had information in English, incluiding the name of the stations. The stations and trains are the most clean I ever saw. Many of the machines where you can buy tickets and passes have instructions in English.

A model of efficiency and excellence. The Tokyo Metro is easy to negotiate, quick and efficient and gets you to all places you may want throughout the city. The high quality clean trains are underpinned by an efficient rail card that you purchase at machines at the stations. The card we used was PASMO. The machines can be set to English and you just follow instructions to both purchase one and charge it up with yen value (minimum 1,000 yen) and off you go. Each time through a turn style you tap and go and it debits the card telling you the remaining balance. Each metro station is often multi-layered but the English signage is easy to follow. This card can also be used on other lines such as the metro JR ones. But if you have a JR rail pass use that instead. If you find you are going in the wrong direction just get off and changed sides of the platform. Its all great fun and easy to use.

Great value, easy to navigate. Purchase a card. We used the Suica pass for our 8 day stay, topping up regularly. You can also use the Suica pass for vending machines if you run out of change and in some small shops were the green sign is seen. You purchase them for JPY500 deposit which you get back on return of the card to any JR station. We used them o the bus, subway and JR Lines and you can also use for the bullet trains.Peak hour on the JR lines particularly can be intimidating with the crowds but that was also part of the fun!

Very Easy!. It's very easy to get a hang off, especially if you're used to travelling via underground. The stations are clean, big and the trains are always on time! It's the cheapest mode of travel around Tokyo, totally recommended. PS:Don't forget to buy your Pasmo/Suica card as this saves a lot of money as well as time! :D

Easy to navigate. I was in Tokyo for 5 days and never needed a cab due to the fantastic metro system. You pay for the length of the ride if you are purchasing individual tickets and there are maps at all stations that have English. Also, all of the trains have English translations when you are approaching the stations. Definitely an easy way to travel the city!

Perfect but very difficult to communicate in english... Visit this beautiful city is really easy thanks to the large underground tram network. The very valid the Tokyo subway is a model of precision, punctuality and cleanliness. You can reach virtually every corner of the city and every attraction through this service and efficient for anything expensive, I would say that the price for a day pass are quite content. Also you can reach the city from and to the Narita airport. The only downside of all this perfection is the very low level of English spoken staff, almost no one is able to communicate in English and if you need to explain a few passersby will certainly help you more than them. In any case, they themselves try in every way to help you.
Best trains in the world. If I lived in Tokyo I wouldn't even consider owning a car. The transit here is amazing, the best in the world without a doubt.

Fast and cheap. We never used a cab during our stay in Tokyo. Its a huge city, but surprisingly you can reach any part of it within 20-30 minutes if you stay near Shinjuku station for example. I recommend you book your hotel near this huge terminal, so you wont have to bother much about transportation. Ask your hotel for guidance on trains. At the station itself, dont hesitate to ask a local person, we had great experiences with them and they were very helpful. Just ask them in a friendly way. All signs are in Japanese, so you will need them.

Great system. I had never been in Japan before, and I didn't speak a word of Japanese, so I was a bit nervous about heading out into the city alone. I need not have been nervous - the Metro is modern, clean, efficient, and most important easy to understand. Besides being a marvel of modern efficiency, it is just a great way to get around the city.

So organized. The best metro, so easy to get around from one place to another, even though you do not know Japanese, it has A/C, Japanese are well organized and polite, so nobody is pushing or crowding you, just the best transporation

Cheap and easy transport. Tokyo metro and the JR line are great ways to get around this hugh city. Signs are in English, the subway map that you can pick up at hotels and Tourist information is easy to use.Transport is cheap and faster than taxis!

About Tokyo Metro. Today was the first one in Tokyo and I felt very excited about people walking on its streets. They walk faster than the usual european people. Specially at the metro! I love this place! :)

Fast, modern and efficient. the Tokyo Metro is one of the most extensive and advanced in the world. The trains are never late and don't spend too much time wAiting at stations. Be careful during peak times as they are more Han often heaving with commuters.

World's best transportation system. The Tokyo Metro is the most user friendly system I have ever seen. 12 or so lines all with a unique color, letter and name. The stops are numbered. So if you are at M10 an need to go to M8 you can easily determine in with direction and for how many stops you need to travel. Try that in NYC where you have to figure out which stop is first, 47th street or 5th avenue.  There are video screens on the train that tell you what station is next as you would expect. The screens also give you a graphic of the approaching station and where the car you are in is in relation to exits and transfer points.

Going between Shinjuku and Asakusa. There is a confusing transfer when taking the Metro between Shinjuku and Asakusa, 2 main tourist destinations. The transfer between the Bakuro-Yokoyama station on the Shinjuku line to the Higashi-NIhonbashi station on the Asakusa line requires you to "check out" of one station but you get the ticket back to "check in"at the other station. You don't lose the ticket when you check out if you paid enough for the tickets.By the way, taking the Metro is much better than JR when the weather is hot or cold.

Easy, clean and efficient . We were able to use our JR pass for most of the lines. The map of the lines looks rather intimidating but it is easy to navigate around. We used the subway to get around to everything we wanted. We were very impressed by how helpful and kind the staff is to travellers. The locals go out of their way to help us get to where we need. Very impressive system.

Get you almost anywhere in Tokyo within walking distance. You can use the Tokyo Metro and the other subway system Toei to get almost anywhere in Tokyo within walking distance. The two networks combined serve the majority of commuter ridership in Tokyo. Punctual, fast, clean and safe, this method of transportation will serve you best if you work in or visit Tokyo. Surface streets and toll highways in Tokyo are always bumper to bumper and it probably takes twice as long and 3 times as expensive to get from one place to another.
