With such a extensive network, visitors are often totally confused, found standing in front of the ticket machines in stations staring at the board wondering what route to take. It is a good idea to map out your "strategy" before you leave your hotel. You may need to take one or two transfers. IC cards such as Suica or Pasmo cards replace ticket purchase confusion in calculating your ticket price automatically. Just tap in through the gates on the way in and out. No need to tap again at transfers except when you transfer between the two systems, Tokyo Metro and Toei. You can buy these cards at most ticket machines in JR, subway or private rail stations. There is about a $5 card fee which is refundable if you decide to turn in your card before you leave Japan. Forget taxis. They are very expensive. They are only good for short distance because the base fee of $7-8 are set for the first 2 km. Buses are also everywhere but if you don't read Japanese, it may be very difficult to find your way around and they are often stuck in heavy traffic. On the other hand, the Metro has clear signs in English (Roman alphabet) and many places in Chinese and Korean characters. Some major stations even have PA in English.Best way to travel within Tokyo.

Confusing!. Coming from Seoul, which has the best metro system in the world, I was confused! It's hard to compare I guess but the multi-operators system makes it more complicated than it should be regarding both tickets, transfers and station layout and location.

"Very efficient ". Tokyo Metro (formerly known as Eidan) is one of Tokyo's two subway operators. It runs nine of the metropolis' thirteen subway lines, while Toei operates the other four.While the nine Tokyo Metro lines provide access to many of Tokyo's city centers and tourist attractions, they alone do not provide the perfect solution for getting around Tokyo. Instead, they are best used in combination with the Toei subway lines and the urban JR lines, especially the JR Yamanote Line.Tokyo Metro fares range from 170 to 310 yen depending on how far you travel. A one day pass for unlimited use of Tokyo Metro on one calendar day is available for 710 yen, but note that special passes for visitors are sold at Narita Airport and Haneda Airport for only 600 yen for a 1-day version and 980 yen for a 2-day version.A day pass valid on both Tokyo Metro and Toei subway lines is available for 1000 yen, but note that a special ticket for tourists, the Tokyo Subway Ticket, is sold at Narita Airport and Haneda Airport for 800 yen for a 1-day pass, 1200 yen for a 2-day pass and 1500 yen for a 3-day pass.

Confronting at first. The Metro diagram looks like a Jackson Pollock painting with lines and colours going every which way. My first experience wasn't a good one and I didn't research enough and got hopelessly lost. I was given the advice to download HYPERDIA and it was brat advice. It is a free app that will get you around the metro. Invaluable. It is daunting but by using the app, taking it slow, matching colours to lines and asking when in doubt you will be an expert in no time.

Cheap efficient and easy enough yo use.. Firstly buy an IC card this will avoid having yo buy Seperate tickets for each journey and remember the lines all have different owners so you may need several tickets to get from a to b an IC card cuts all that hassle out. You can top it up easily at the fair adjustment machines if you go out of credit your exit will close and you will need to re credit it before leaving the station. The metro is pretty good, but I found it was not always easy to find the name of the station I was at from the train as station names are often in small font and the signs are not as frequent as other metros. Many of the trains do not have real time maps so again it can be easy to miss the station you want so keep your wits about you. It is incredibly busy and if you get a seat during rush hours you will be very lucky. One thing I found odd was that some of the lesser lines are not displayed on the official map and additionally some stations do not appear on the maps either. Generally there will be a staff person on every platform and at every exit, most have a basic understanding of English if you want a specific place but can't find the exit or train etc just say to them "sumimassen, (place name) wa doko desu ka" between you you will figure it out. Considering they must answer thousands of similar questions each day they were all very polite and helpful.Try and learn the Japanese number system Itchy nee San etc so you understand platform numbers when they answer you. Some stations have dozens of exits over several floors and choosing the wrong exit could mean a long walk to find where you want to be so do research on which exit you need before heading off out or at least ask the staff.

User friendly, foreigner friendly.. Busy station like what we saw in the movies or films, however, it was not what I imagined, difficult, language barrier, sign board issue, etc. Everything worked out smoothly on my first trip to Tokyo, and on my second and third trip it feels just like getting on public transport at home. Too easy. High-tech yet simple ticketing machines at the station, subway maps big and easy to read on the walls, signboards with english language. The ticket machine is easier to use than other countries in Asia, all you need to do is, press which station you wish to go, and it will pop up a price of say 200Yen or 360Yen, pop your coin in and a cute tiny ticket will be printed out for you. Easy. If you are unsure of say changing platforms and lines, will it cost more or so, no worries, just press directly to your destination, it will add up and print both tickets to you.There are people working for the subs and JR company, also security guards and policemen all friendly to ask, however, simple english only. Which is even better, easier. So do not hesitate to ask them, they are friendly and helpful. Lockers in different sizes, restaurants or convenient stores,and toilet are available.

Easy for foreigner. Tokyo metro, subway system made for total idiots, excuse my language! If you understand English, it's for you if you're a foreigner! Have your subway map, locate where you live and where you want to go. And you're at home from any place once get underground... Until 12 am or so, though :( . Easy connections, just make sure you can be charged more, when changing lines from Tokyo metro to toei lines, which are private and also JR and monorails. All the rest are just great. My advise to get a one day ticket, for only Tokyo or both Tokyo and toei lines, which is a bit more expensive. And enjoy your day travelling around the city. Do not take one time ticket if you plan to visit many stations. Save money for great shopping!

Nothing like any other metro system. We've traveled extensively in Europe and have also ridden many subways in the US. The subway system jn Japan is nothing short of amazing, in comparison. First and foremost, the trains are immaculate. The floors are clean and there's no graffiti to be found. That could be due in large part to those that use the system. The passengers are orderly, turn their phones off or to silent when boarding and don't often eat or drink in the cars. Much of that has to do with Japanese culture, but it makes for a unique subway experience. While I'd rather take a taxi, this subway provides a cheap, easy, and efficient way to get around Tokyo.

Great way to travel through the city. This metro system is actually very easy to navigate. Everything is well laid out and labeled to make it easy even if you don't speak the language. Very clean and organized.

Not as crazy as you first think. Our first experience with the Tokyo Metro was looking helplessly at the map at Tokyo Station and trying to work out how to get to where we needed to be as thousands of people moved past us.After the first day we found it was really easy if you disregard the Japanese names, follow the color codes and number systems for the lines and stations.Ticket machines were easy to operate and had a button to display options in English. Even the "Fare Adjustment" machine didn't cause any dramas for us. Fares are not expensive.If all else fails ask the station staff who are always on duty while trains are running. We found them to be very helpful.Trains ran every few minutes and even during peak periods when they were crowded it was still fairly easy to get on and off, but start moving towards the carriage exits before you stop as the trains only remain stationary for very short periods of time.Finding correct platforms at stations to change lines was also fairly easy once we worked out the color coding system.Trains are clean and graffiti free. If you miss a train don't panic, there is another one in a couple of minutes. For the number of people they carry the journey is remarkably quiet as there are no loud phone conversations and almost no conversations at all between passengers. (How I wish Melbourne's rail system was this good)The same system applies in all the major cities we visited.Japanese Metro make it easy to move around Tokyo and also other cities.

Great way to ride along the massive city... The screen has an English version on top right hand side; left top will have round trip or one way& no of person.if, roundtrip..ticket with a line is 1st used or, won't be able to get out..hang on to the 2 nd ticket cuz this helps when lost & in Japanese writing! Metro line is not the same as the new Yurikamome line to cross the rainbow bridge in Odaiba. Please also note that a rail pass will not be viable for yurikamome rail also..Map of Tokyo rail can be a menace & intimidating at first until explored and thank goodness for the hospitality of the Japanese people...one gal literally walked me into another rail after exiting & walking out on streets!Some rail are older and confusing in Shinjuku & then, another newer caught from Times Suare at the Mall is clear in flat screen TV and note able on stops, FYIIt can get taxing if not used to traveling.FYI,Rejoice, tourists to Tokyo! There is a new Tokyo Subway Ticket available to domestic and international visitors costing only 800 yen (approximately $8) that allows one day of unlimited rides on all Tokyo Metro and Toei Subway lines (this is a lower price than the current Common 1-day ticket!) Prices going down in Tokyo? No savvy traveler is going to pass this up! For those folks who plan to be spending more time in Tokyo, 2-day and 3-day tickets are also available, and they are a great, affordable way to zip around Tokyo, hassle free!Tickets for children and adults are available for purchase at Narita and Haneda airport sales counters, and also at regional travel agencies. Hey, hold that door open! This is my stop!For more information, please visit here.53 comments

Best City Metro in Asia. The Tokyo Metro is a great way to get around the city. You can easily get anywhere in Tokyo as fast - or faster- than if you were to take a Taxi. If you read this, I recommend one thing. This will save you a lot of time and headache and possibly a lot of money. Get a PASMO card!!!! This is a game changer for the subway because since the subway companies integrated recently it will let you ride all of the subways on one card and you won't have to buy tickets each time you want to ride; thus save you money by getting charged exactly what you use. The place you get the card is next to the turnstile and ticket machines. Ask for help to get the card. The machines are pink and you can't miss them. This card lets you use the bus, train and metro. It also allows you to pay in certain convenience stores and vending machines. When you leave Tokyo you can return it and get your money back, or just keep it for the next trip - like I did :)Side note about this is that if you are in Tokyo for one day it is not worth it. This card is only useful for a several day trip. You also need one per person. The advantages of the metro are: always on time, very efficient, minimal switching if needed, friendly (and sometimes English) staff to point you in the right direction and ease of use.Cons: can be very busy. some stops have Japanese with white gloves that literally push you onto the subway. fun experience, but it can be a bit claustrophobic

Fantastic Way to Explore Tokyo. Clean, efficient and stations everywhere!Only experience one delay in a 2 week trip due to a large lightning storm. Service delay was 10 mins and then the next train came ! Some Hints and Tricks - Download Hyperdia App - Available on iphone and android for a small fee this app allows you to map out your journey, advises frequency of trains and alternative routes with less stops or quicker tranist time. A must have for travellers not use to using subway and train lines. To make life easy find your routes the night before, save a screen shot and then the next day will have a handy reference. If the times change, generally there is a train every couple of minutes.If you plan on spending most of travelling around by train invest in the Suica Card, this is a pre paid card, you charge up and instead of spending time trying to work out which coins you need to pay for your fare, simply swipe and select your ticket. Most ticket machines have an English button and a handy search by station name function if you get confused.Most if not all of the stations have English signage and line maps. There is guaranteed to be a large map in around the ticket machines of the area (all in Japanese, with some main roads in English). This will help you find your correct exit and get your bearing.Don't stress too much if you miss your train another one should be there in a 2-10 mins!When ever you are out at night, note down the last train time to make your journey back as it is often around midnight, miss your last train and your up for an expensive taxi ride home.

Great with a local, scary without!. The subway system is incredibly clean and efficient. Nothing but praise for the Tokyo Metro.What I would have done without my local tour guide? I would not recommend anyone to go at it alone to any destination first or second time by themselves. To many subtleties, exist.Some stations have five subways in layers. The maps are not geographically correct. No way of knowing exact distances with the Metro maps.Simple in some ways, but too complicated for most tourist.Sure you can eventually get there, but you will waste a lot of time figuring out!

The most efficient transportation system in the world. The Japanese subway train system is the most efficient transportation system I've ever come across. It's easy to navigate your way in Tokyo, outside the city and even cross cites using JR or Shinkansen, never a daunting task even for non-Japanese speaking tourists. You'll be able to get hold of the train timetable at the stations or online. The beauty lies in the reliability of the timetable, ie when it says it will arrive at 1.54pm, it will arrive at that time, making planning a breeze. For tourists, day passes are available for sale at the stations. For single trip ticket purchases, the route map has very clear fare indications and connections, which leaves little room for confusion. When unsure, the friendly station master is always around to help, albeit many with limited English fluency which I didn't see an issue at all as many will go all out to help you.Do note priority seating and cabins, especially during rush hours. Do not use mobile phones or talk loudly onboard the train.Should you travel during colder seasons, the heater (usually installed underneath the seats) will be turned on to warm the commuters.
A Great Metro System. You can go any place in Tokyo on the Metro. Buy a 1-2 day passGreat Value for the $$. The metro & JR station can be use to explore Tokyo on your own time & place

Good transportation, can be a bit confusing though. The Tokyo Metro is the best way to get around the city. The stations are close to every tourist attraction and it get you were you want to go pretty fast.It can be slighty confusing though if you are using it for the first time since you are not chosing your stop at the machine, but how much you gonna pay. so first you have to figure out how much it is gonna cost to get you to your destination. But once you get the hang of it it's really no problem and I found the people to be very helpful if you ask for assistance

Excellent Transport System. Enjoyed using the metro in Tokyo and travelled in almost all the lines and also the bullet trains from Nagasaki to Kyoto and from Kyoto to Tokyo.On time departures and on time arrivals. No scope to complain.The trains very clean and using the elevators also very disciplined.

Save money and buy special tourist Tokyo Metro passes at Bic Camera!!!. Our new hotel was less than 5 minutes from the Akasaka-Mitsuke station, directly below Bic Camera department store. Go to the street level cashier and show your passport (which they will definitely check before they sell you tickets).Special 1-Day Open Ticket: Adult 600Yen --- Child 300YenSpecial 2-Day Open Ticket: Adult 980Yen --- Child 490YenPerfect for us since we go everywhere, anytime, everyday:) With these tickets, we can get lost in Tokyo, and not worry about the cost and our safety:)
Little bit complicated . I have been using the day pass which cost 1000 ¥ , it is well connected to all Tokyo but complicated however u will get used to it .

Complicated but fun. At first glance the size and complexity of the metro map looks really intimidating. Thankfully the staff and regular Japanese will go out of their way to help you and explain how the ticket machines work. There are about 8 lines crossing the city, each are colour coded and each station has a letter and number. Easiest mistake to make is to be on the right line but going the wrong way. Check the stations at the end of the line you want to go on. Even if you do stuff up, staff will help you. Things you'll notice inside the trains are, massive amounts of advertising and the really low hand holds hanging from the ceiling. When you stand up to get off I swear you will bang your head over and over again.

Tokyo public transportation experience. Japanese public transport is the best, systematic and well organized. I travelled by Shinkansen train from Nagoya to Tokyo in April 2014, and thereafter using tokyo metro which is the most efficient transportation moving around different places.You need carefulness when choosing the line to your destination or even where transfer is required. This is the type of transport which other countries transportation companies should take note!

Public transportation at its best. One of the most efficient in the world, the tokyo metro is also one of the most complicated. Its actually made up of several railway companies intertwined in the same rail map, Metro, JR, Keisei, and some other individual lines. So make sure to pick up a rail map at the airport when u first arrive. If you happen to arrive tokyo from Narita airport, you may also want to pick up a Metro day pass, 6xx yen for 1 day, 9xx yen for 2 days. You can get it at the tourist information counter in the arrival hall, its a credit-card-sized-green-soft- bendy-plastic-card. The day pass is only limited to the metro line though (that means no yamanote line, that belongs to JR) but i got around to all the major areas fine (shinjuku, harajuku, shibuya, asakusa, ikebukuro, tsukiji, odaiba and the like). I'd say if you will be going to more than 3 locations around town, it'd be cheaper to get the day pass. If you dont buy a day pass, then you will need to buy tickets for each time u take the train. To buy tickets, you will need to find the station you want to go to on a huge map and check the fare for that station. Then just buy the ticket with the correct fare. The ticket machines have understandable english.Transit between rail lines will make u feel like a mouse looking for cheese in a lab maze, with signs pointing to 6 different cheeses in different directions. But the signage is reliable if you can follow them properly.

Best system. Most of the stations are within 5 to 15 mins including different lines. Most station staffs are not well in English, but as long as you know which place or station you are going to, go to the window office to get the best direction and price.Things need to take note:Some stations transfer within same price required to exit and re-entry. When exit to transfer, you need to use the orange gate which you will get back the train ticket, others will not get back the ticket. If happens, go to the window office to explain.JR trains now comes with monitor at every door. It shows information on "minutes to every station", next station information: lifts, escalator, staircase and line transfer direction. So, check it when you are coming to your station. Tokyo had the busiest network and there are stations with major transfer. Once lost, go and ask the platform staffs, always ask for the platform number better then asking the way.

Transport companies Worldwide please take note!. Japanese efficiency at it's best. A pleasure to take public transport? Pretty much unheard of compared to most big cities in the world. Frequent service (every few minutes), clean, modern, safe carriages, and well priced fares. Fares are priced by distance and start at 170 yen ($1.80 au) you can buy these from a ticket window or machine. Machines are easy to operate and have English options. Most of the bigger stations also have a staff member standing by to offer help if needed. The bigger underground stations house restaurants, conbinis (convenience stores) and even little bars! Busier lines such as the Yamanote (which circles through Shinjuku, Harajuku and Tokyo station among others) do get very crowded. In my year living in Japan this was never a problem. Tokyo is such a densely populated city that Tokyoites are accustomed to this and will show extreme respect for the personal space of others.Often joked about...if a train ever does happen to run past a few minutes late (and by a few I mean 2 minutes) an apology will sound over the loudspeaker! Go Tokyo Metrooooo!

One of the best in world. Tokyo metro could be best or one of best 5 in the world. What it makes it best is that despite being super crowded no one push around, no one steps on you,no one gets into your space. People attitude and discipline makes it a great and easy experience. Tokyo metro is super crowded thanks to 36 million people plus so many toursist. You would always spot too many businessmen in black suits any time of day. The trains are super punctual and clean. The announcement are in English and flash screens messaging station names. The seats are clean and well-marked. No one would push you to grab a seat. The staff at station is polite and always ready to help if required. The whole system of metro, JR rail and private rail system makes Tokyo transport system one of the largest and best organized in the world. The stations platforms are super clean and the toilets are probably most clean I have ever seen the world. All kind of tickets including one –day passes are available at major stations. The stations in Tokyo could be huge and confusing though ,like underground cities with massive shopping and eating places and multiple dozens of exits.
Ichiban. Hands down the best transit system in the world. Always crowded yet not noisy. Never once did I feel unsafe unlike the trains in California or east coast.

Probably the best in the world - timing, connectivity, accessibility, discipline. I used this transport during my visit to Tokyo in Apr '14.What can I say about this wonderful piece of engineering? Almost every corner of Tokyo is connected by 2 lines - the Tokyo metro and the Toei lines. Tokyo metro has 9 lines - all underground.All stations are easily accessible and can be identified on the ground with a symbol 'M' in white on blue background. Boards indicating the nearest stations along with the distance in metres are put on the ground. I was awed.Inside the subway, there is a station office, a lost and found section. Though officers know only some English, they help as much as possible. Metro maps, attractions in Tokyo and other pamphlets are available free for pick-up. Commuters promptly bring things lost by other commuters to the station office and write down at what time and where they found it. Kind of a heaven on Earth, isn't it? Which country's citizens are so prompt? Card recharge and ticket pick-up counters are just beside the gates. Though all info are in Japanese, they have exclusive pages for information in English at the press of a button. I never saw anyone cheat, jump a queue or travel without a ticket.Routes to all trains or different lines are marked clearly so that no one could get lost. People are expected to stand (indicated in sign boards) on the left side of the escalator so that others who want to climb up faster could use the right side. And every single person followed it. I think these things are ingrained in their blood because they follow it impromptu without any kind of supervision from anyone.And train timing (and frequency), as everyone know, could be used to set our watch times - on the dot. Board inside says that mobile phones should be in silent mode and no one should talk inside the train. And everyone follow it without questioning.Cleanliness everywhere is a given.Anyone visiting Tokyo cannot miss using this service as it connects almost every corner and is presumably the fastest and cheapest mode of transportation. I am awestruck with the service, good attitude of Japanese citizens, connectivity, accessibility and ease of using Tokyo metro.

Best Metro System in the World. Being from the US where any public transit systems are mediocre at best (even the best ones in NYC) traveling throughout Tokyo and Japan was a dream! Though rush hour trains may be crowded they were always punctual and cheap. At first choosing the right platforms was tricky but with a good understanding of the language and the extremely helpful citizens and platform staff I was able to get anywhere easily. In addition, most metro stations were very clean and nicely decorated. I could only dream of having something comparable at home!

Not cheap if you buy individual tickets- but great deal with the daily pass. Just the best way to travel around Tokyo - just watchout for private vs public lines when choosing the daily pass you want to buy.

MUCH Better than anticipated. We had read that the metro was so crowded that authorities literally pushed people into train cars. Our rides on the metro were as pleasant and courteous as the rest of Tokyo. What had started with some in-trepidation, quickly became our favourite mode of travel.

I really cannot understand the good reviews. Out of all the modern cities in the world I have been to, Tokyo boasts (not exactly anything to boast about) the worst subway system out of the lot.For a start, its very expensive. Its too expensive. Compare it to Seoul where you pay a flat rate and can get anywhere in the city for the same price. Perfect model. Price ranges from where you go, how long you go, how many lines you use, which line you use.The fact that it is owned my x amount of companies is a very negative factor, and this is an issue that really needs to be addressed, one of many, before Japan hosts both the Rugby World Cup in 2019 and the Olympics in 2020. Having to pay for one line then pay again for another makes sense for the companies who own it, but those who have to use it get financially robbed. Its a farce.Another major issue of the Tokyo Subway is... there are not enough cars to accommodate the commuters. When you see so many people cramming into space that doesn't exist, you question the mindset of people. If there were more cars, and the platforms were designed for a city of 20 odd million people (an estimated guess), then the crammed car issue may be alleviated. As it stands, a morning ride in the subway is enough to ruin ones morning.The last point is the choice of voice on the subway. The female announcer has possibly one of the worst voices on earth and is enough to ruin my day on a daily basis, as a Tokyo resident.
Expensive but clean. Confusing maps and layout but ok when you are familiar after a couple of days. Security checks when you enter but well organisedl.

Convenient, clean, cheap and quick. This is one of the best ways to travel around Tokyo. It is relatively cheap, compared to taxis, and most of the tourist sites can be reached via the network.The trains are punctual, and have good systems and announcements to show where you are at any point. It can get very crowded during peak periods though, but the next train is just minutes away.One negative though - the lines may be operated by different companies, so you may have to buy more than one ticket when you make the trip, depending on which lines you are travelling on.I like the JR line, which loops around the Tokyo Metropolitan area, and it is also generally cheaper than the other subways.On arrival at Haneda or Narita airports, you can also easily travel downtown via the network as well.
Very clean !. I was impressed by Tokyo metro, it is so clean compared to other metro around the world. Pasmo card is useful. There is a lot of metro lines, to go everywhere !

Advantageous networking of the Tokyo metro & rail systems benefit both residents & tourists!. Hats off to the Japanese to build and provide a logistical dream network of subway/metro, rail both local and high speed systems to inter-network with one another. As a tourist that has visited Japan many times I have enjoyed using Transportation so efficient, clean & convenient! The Suica card makes it even easier & faster to pass through the turnstiles without the hassle of stopping while traveling around Tokyo.

Very easy to use. Once you work out the system it is the quickest way to get around Tokyo. There are different companies and lines, so make sure you get the most convenient for your travel. Otherwise it night cost you more, and mean changing stations etc. Best to avoid peak hours if you value your personal space. Don't talk on your mobile phone on the trains either, it is considered very bad mannered, and if you do get a seat, always let the elderly sit down. It was a novelty to watch the female train driver, and the way that she always pointed towards the signals as she passed by, as well as the conductors on the platforms in the stations. At one stage we were not sure which exit to use, so we asked an older man in a rail uniform, and he gave us directions in perfect english ..... not so many people we met spoke english in Japan.

What an orderly and civilized subway. Don't be scared to venture down underground to catch a Tokyo subway. It's the best, cheapest and fastest means of getting around this otherwise gigantic city. At first glance, staring in disbelief at the subway Tokyo map, wandering how to get to any destination may seem overwhelming. However, it's not that difficult. The ticket vending machines have English menu. Tickets are sold in brackets of different price categories, starting at ¥120, ¥150 and up. Just pick English on the screen, then hit the search button and type in the first characters of your destination and a selection of stations pop up. The network is extremely dense, but be aware that different train companies operate different lines, especially in suburban Tokyo, and you may find yourself having to buy new tickets as you travel along. Down in the overcrowded trains, be courteous and polite as the locals, we did not fear pick pocketing, neither to travel late at night, but of course one should always remain wary of unexpected situations. Trains run frequently. Don't forget coins for ticket purchasing though machines accept ¥1000 notes.

Convenient and comfortable. very convenient and comfortable! Traveler can go to most famous tourist spots in Tokyo by subway and JR. The lines are a little complicated, but you will find it's not hard to understand if you spend some time to study the map. The peak time of the subway is 7~9 AM, it's very crowded at that time. If you want have a more comfortable trip you can avoid that period.

Big disappointment. The biggest disappointment with my trip to Tokyo involved the city's subway.Because various lines are operated by different companies, transferring from one line to another can be confusing and involve a long walk. Sometimes, you have to exit the station, walk 500 meters above ground and go into another station.Most of the metro system also seemed embarrassingly low tech. C'mon...this is Japan, one of the world's centers of technology. Where are the bright colorful ticket kiosks? Where is the free wi-fi? Where are the interactive touchscreen station maps showing the amenities and exits? The trains look like they've been used continuously since the 1970s. At some stations, the subway route maps didn't contain English. That's why you should always carry your own route map.The only good thing I have to say about the Tokyo Metro is, the coverage is excellent. You can be almost anywhere in the city and the nearest station is only a short walk away.
Great experience. Really efficient way to travel in Japan. Wish L.A. had something so nice. It gets really crowded during their "rush hour" times and I mean really packed like sardines.

Best subway in the world . Only way to commute in japan. Download Hyperdia on your phone and that app makes it super easy for you to find your way around using subway, train and JR lines. Enter in where you are and what station you want to go to and it will give you all the subways you need to take. Awesome app!!!! A must in japan if you want to experience subway in Tokyo.
Just superb. Always on time, pretty easy to use even if you dont know Japanese. It is difficult to get lost here.

The best way to travel in Tokyo. The metro and subway are the best ways to get around in Tokyo. It's cheaper and more efficient. Make sure you get a map so you know where you're going. Rush hours are between 8-9 AM & 5-6 PM.

Traveling in Tokyo metro. Despite seeming cluterly Tokyo metro functions well and it takes just few trips to get acquainted. The biggest chalange is to get used to fare adjustemnet system which means that you sometimes need to pay a little extra to get out in the case you travelled more far then you payed. It is very quick and easy.

Punctual, fast and efficient. Japanese efficiency and punctuality extends to the Metro system. If you have suffered in London, New York and Paris - forget that, Tokyo Metro is the best by miles. Ticket machines in every station convert to english and are clear. Platforms are well marked and with a metro map easy to navigate. If you make a mistake with the ticket its no trouble at your destination to pay the difference at the friendly little kiosk next to the out gates. Its a safe environment so don't worry. I can't speak a word of Japanese but found it straight forward with a bit of common sense and good manners.

How could you not be impressed. On time, trains stop with a few inches of the sliding doors of each carriage entrance. The staff are efficient, the signage is in English and Japanese, the carriages are clean and not spoiled by graffiti or damage to the interior. Some cultures may find it unusual that carriages are often quiet inside, as I did at first, but I think it just adds to the charm of Japan and the Japanese. The signage in the carriages can confuse as it's in Japanese initially, but be patient as it's repeated in English. Access to most stations is relatively easy and most have easy access to platforms. My advice, get yourself a Suica card as it makes entry to stations relatively simple.

Excelent Train System. All signs are in dual language, with fares clearly stated for each stop. If you're confused, like I was, there will always some very helpful locals willing to help, even with little English. The locals would help to really find out the answer to your questions, even using their cell phones to look up for info...

The Epitome of Efficiency. Didn't have one late train, compared to the London Tube, it is a dream to have air conditioning!All trains on time, queues to the doors, women only carriages... what else could you be looking for as solo female traveler?!Sometimes the boards in terms of stations were confusing to follow, just due to the number of stations and lines, but I did find that if I looked confused enough someone would try to help me, even if the English was very broken.

So confusing. There are no English signs in some stations and most of the staff speak little English. Some carriages are too old and usually overcrowded. You have to go out in the street to transfer to another line, which will probably be operated by another transportation company. Then, you will have to pay again. Connection between the main stations is bad and it takes you twenty minutes to cover the transfer (maybe two or three transfers) for a five-minute journey. The ticket machines are also very confusing, you need a lot of time to get to know what is the fare you have to pay. Many stations have no escalators or lifts. This is by far one of the worst subway nets I have ever seen, I don't understand why people give such good opinions about it...

clean, organized, efficient and well priced. The system is very well laid out and convenient for travel across the city with many opportunities to see the sights without difficulty. It is reasonably priced, readily accessible fast, clean and efficient. A great way to move around the city!!!

Complicated?Not really!!Fantasctic way of travel in Tokyo. At first glance, it seemed to be very complicated and unbelievable. Then, after having used the metro/JR for 3 days and night, it became obvious that it is a very well-functioning, unbelievable structure. Probably one of the best metro in the world and complications come from the simple reason, that there are really too much lines and stations. But in fact, it serves the users. Unfortunately, there is not so much options to get a real reduction if you buy a plastic card, but definitely, it is much more practical then to buy for every and each trip a ticket. In the metro of Tokyo principally you pay after the distance you run, so every and each time you have to calculate your money. Except, if you opt for a Passmo or Suica card. I had Passmo and it worked very well, even for trains to get Haneda airport. Of course, in rush hours it can be extremely crowded, if you can, just avoid some main lines, like Ginza, Hibyja or Chiyoda lines, between 5-7 pm and 7-9 am. Other advantage is that there are a lot of lockers in the stations, and the officers are extremely helpful and kind, most of them speak sufficiently enough English. Great service. Only inconvenience, that there are no trains during the nights....

NOT expensive(compared to London). Tokyo metro is well organised network with efficiency!! 5 stops ride is less than fifth the cost of London tube!! Not only that, it is clean, air conditioned and Wi-Fi plus people do not use mobile while travelling except emailing. Only people who are talking on mobile are foreigners!! I would say that Tokyo metro is the best tube(subway) in the world. London tube is far far too expensive for what it is and it is dirty, no air-con and not efficient!! If London tube is a rip off then Tokyo metro is a bargain!!

Overwhelming but wonderful. The Metro is very extensive and easy to use, the day pass is a deal and you can get pretty much anywhere in Tokyo. But it requires walking and maneuvering an impressive underground maze. Quick tip. If you are heading to a spot, look up not only the line and exit but also the street # to exit the train station on. An example would be Ginza Line, Ginza Station, #7 exit. With each stain have a ton of exits, you will wonder through them to only end up 2 blocks away from where you were headed.

Get The Tourist Book. Unlike anywhere I've ever been, the tourist books at the airport include subways maps that show you on a map where each exit from the subways will take you. This was unbelievably convenient. The subways system itself is great, security can speak some English, and the day pass is a steal.

Challenging, memorable highlight of 3 weeks in Japan. A most impressive transportation network.Hours at home of Google map listing of Metro directions to desired sights plus highlighting stations on a Metro map ( See map link below) helped prepare me for efficiently negotiating our 6 days in Tokyo. It was well worth the time and I highly recommend expending the effort.Shinjuku Station was overwhelming enough without the added burden of commencing one's learning curve upon arrival.Metro map link:http://www.tokyometro.jp/en/subwaymap/pdf/routemap_en.pdfWelcome the challenge and enjoy the satisfaction of a day's jam-packed sightseeing agenda successfully accomplished.

WOW!. So many lines but so easy to use. With the JR line (green one, Takes you around in just over 1 hour And FREE WITH YOUR JR PASS) you can go to al lot of mayor tourist attarction (or just enjoying tokyo. evey 2 min a train is there so no need to run ;-) (really cheap to, around 120 to 170 Yen) Also free wifi so easy when you look up some information. (2 hours a day)in the beginning you will get lost (for example Shinuku station, so many exits) but really nice, fast way of getting around Tokyo.Last, during rush hour (half of the day) it's really busy. and you will be packed in the subway. and eveybody is pushing so eveyone gets in. but no one is screaming or fighting becasue you push, it's normal, eveyone want on the train. people around the world can learn a lot from Japanse people!

You can get practically anywhere, if you have the stamina. The Tokyo Metro (subway) was a mad max mixture of lots of lines going practically anywhere you want to go in Tokyo. It is very clean and efficient. It is also not too difficult to decipher all those 13 separate lines, but takes a lot of leg work to get from one platform to another. The one day pass of $10 was well worth the price.
Tokyo Metro system. it is awesome, and the RESPECT of other people is beyond understanding. Highly appreciated indeed. :)

Transport Perfection. The Tokyo Metro and JR Train systems of Tokyo are outstanding. Their advantages are obvious (1) They are kept meticulously clean (2) Arrive on time and if you miss a train, another should be there within 5 minutes (3) Travel to all parts of Tokyo. Given all of the above they are good value for money in my opinion, although I am from Australia where transport tends to be ridiculously expensive.There are a few tips people should remember to avoid issues(1) There are coloured maps in the stations which display the various lines and which stations these lines stop at. When I previously traveled in 2009 this was all Kanji but in recent times there are English labels as well so select where you want to go and there will be a number, indicating the number of Yen you will be required to pay to travel to this location. To figure out what line you need to travel on look at the colour of the line of the station you are travelling to and check the legend for colours (ie it will say "Sobu Line" = Yellow, "Yamonate Line" = Green) - that is the line you need to find. Around the station there will be arrows indicating the lines, which will have the same colours as displayed in the board. It will give you two platform options for that line depending which direction you want to go in, there is normally a second map near the platform that ensure you are heading in the right direction - even if you get this wrong and end up on the train travelling in the wrong direction this isn't a big deal, simply just get off the train at the first stop and swap to the opposite platform, there won't be any additional financial consequences. Some stops may require you to transfer, just figure it out using the coloured system and know which station you need to get off at for the transfer - you don't have to pay for 2 tickets in these situations. Once you get to your station get out of the train and place you ticket in the ticket machine before leaving the station. If you got your fare wrong that isn't a big deal, there is a fare adjustment machine which you can place you ticket in and will adjust the additional cost of the fare, giving you the correct one. It is easy once you have done it once or twice.(2) There is a whole bunch of etiquette for trains in Tokyo and you will actually find signs (IN Japanese) requesting you abide by these. Most of them support the trains being a quite place where people can (and will) sleep. These include- Never blow your nose on a train, this is considered rude- Don't talk loudly and don't ever talk on your mobile phone in a train- No music on trains- There are certain seats (normally have a different colour and pictures of elderly/pregnant/injured people on them) that are priority seats and are only suitable for priority passengers such as thoise above- When getting on a escalator, one side (I believe its the left) is for people who want to stand still on the escalator, the other is for people who want to walk up it. Do not stand on the wrong side otherwise you will annoy people. These sides can change from city to city- With the trains more than the metro there are women only carriage - this is marked on the door and have been established to reduce instances of gropping(3) Tips - Try to avoid rush hours if you can, including 0700-0900 and 1700-1900 as you will be standing and cramped like a tin of sardines- There are limited ramps and lifts in the station and these can be an issue for those will mobility issues. Lots of stairs- There are cards including Suica cards where you can pre-pay. They are poorly advertised to tourists but can save money and convenience for those who get them - Don't throw away your ticket ever, you need it to exit the destination stationOtherwise enjoy the metro, it is a strangely interesting experience.

Very Expensive but Efficient. I think it's a bit ridiculous that it costs you 160 yen to go to either 1 station or 3-4 stations then if you need to transfer to a station on a DIFFERENT line one station away, you're forced to pay ANOTHER 160 yen to transfer a short distance like this. Compared to countries like Singapore and Taiwan, train travel can get very very expensive using the Tokyo Metro (and any other rail company in Japan for that matter).Besides the cost, the train is very timely and will get you where you need to go fairly easily.

Once you know the trick this is the way to travel in Tokyo. A coloured map is offered at hotels or airport (with a legend) indicating Metro/JR rail/ or private lines; the minimun cost is about 130 yen, but a day pass get be purchased at your hotel for 600 yen; otherwise tickets are purchased by machines that have an english option; Simply pick the place you want to go, look on the board for the number (this is the amount of yen of ticket you need to purchase) use the machines to purchase a ticket to that amount of yen; your map will tell you which line you need to find and follow (note the number of the station eg: Hanzomon is the purple cirle Z line and you maybe at Z12 and need to go to Z5 so you head toward that platform. AND... if you can't seem to find the amount of yen needed you can simply purchase the cheapest fare, and when you get to your destination there are fare adjustment machines that you simply insert your ticket and it will tell you how much extra yen is required, add it to the machine, it will give you a new ticket and then you can exit... word of the wise make sure you look at the exit numbers this is helpful to exit where you want... each station has a very easy map to figure out which one you want to exit because when your out on top it is really hard to work your way around the block when you cant read the street signs... Note to mention the map will help you avoid THE STAIRS there are heaps... and there is a KEEP LEFT ruleNote JR rail own the loop train in the centre so that will be an additional cost.Oh and if you missed your stop, easy just get off, walk across the platform 5 steps and get on the reverse running train... presto!

Clean and Free Wifi. The Tokyo Metro is a very effective way to travel. Each line will get you where you want to go. There so many stops that will get you where you need unlike the JR lines. There is also free Wifi in the stations which I found very useful especially for a tourist like myself when it came to looking for nearby attractions or restaurants. The maps take a bit to get used to but with some practice you'll be able to use figure it out. The only thing is that there is less English in the Tokyo Metro system (map wise and staff wise) than in the JR lines. Overall, a nice and surprisingly clean system effective in getting where you need to go.

Efficiently brilliant!!. At first i was a little messed up when first looking at the complicating subway map,but later when i got used to it ,it was quite easy to travel with.I am not sure how other countries metro trains are but this one is really on time ,and a new train comes every few minutes ,so no long wait,very efficient and can take you to almost anywhere in Tokyo.
Most complicated transit system. Most complicated metro system but once u got used to it its very easy to use but quite expensive to travel are Tokyo...

Outstanding system. Tokyo Metro can scare anyone who looks at it massive map but once you use it then it becomes so incredibly simple and easy to use.I suggest getting a Suica or Passmo card if you plan on riding them often which if you are staying in Tokyo you pretty much should be riding the metro often.They area almost always on schedule only had a delay once due to a small earthquake and they were back up in a few minutes time after doing a safety check. They are cheap compared to a taxi and many of the attractions you will want to visit are just a few minutes walk from a metro station. If all else fails the workers are very helpful. Just look for the signs and remember the station names you left from and are going to and it will be simple.

Fast and efficient. This is the only way to get around Tokyo. It does get very crowded, so you have to keep with the flow or you will get push around.Best to know which station you need before getting amongst the crowd

Complex but very Clean and well-organized. If I have to compare this train station to the other stations I have tried in other countries, this is hands down, the most clean, complex and yet very efficient and organized.We got lost inside this station as there were plenty of exits. Being new in Japan and our first time to take the train from Tokyo Disney to Shinjuku, we didn't know where to transfer. Prior to that, we did ask the info desk before buying the one-way pass only to realize that we didn't quite understand each other.It's very near the Imperial Palace if you take the exit leading to that. Aside from that, this is like Grand Central Station in Manhattan so you can disembark here and transfer to other lines leading to the other towns in Tokyo and the suburbs.I suggest you get a Suica, Pasmo or the multiple use tickets. You'll save more.

Make Sure You Get A Suica or Pasmo Card. I've utilized other subways in Korea, HK, and Singapore using a pre-paid card. I've been to Japan before but wasn't initially aware that they had their own prepaid, re-loadable card. For Japan, it's called Suica or Pasmo. I cannot recall the initial price you pay for it, but trust me, it beats having to buy a separate ticket for each journey as not every station as an English fare chart. I'm actually surprised that it isn't more publicized for tourists. Anyway, the subway is hands down the best way to get around in Tokyo....clean, efficient, and on time! Another bonus, Japanese passengers are usually very polite - no loud talking, music etc. Actually, you will see signs advising against these acts on the train. One thing to note, avoid these three times: rush hour (0700-0900), lunch time (1200ish), and last train (0000-0100). Trains get really packed, especially for the last train. If you miss the last train, taxis charge a premium fare so make sure you plan accordingly.

Amazing Experience. One of the most amazing things I have done on this trip is simply stand in one of these train stations during the early rush and watch the people walking to the trains.....quietly, in order, thousands upon thousands upon......Yes, I know standing in a metro station is not generally a life changing event......but this is. It really makes you ponder a lot of life on planet earth. Check it out.

Yes, confusing but probably the best. Practical and way more precise than any metro you've ever been on, it can take you almost anywhere in the 30 million people mega-city, the only problem can be understanding the maps and realizing where you are, but that is because of the immensity of Tokyo ! Just take an english paper-map and you'll be fine as long as you don't get lost in the sea of millions of daily japanese transferring at Shinjuku...
always on time. well if you need to get round tokyo the metro is the best way to do it as they run dead on time, very clean and a good price and the staff are very helpful.

Beat the traffic. It took us a while until we figure it out what and where as it can be very confusing at the beginning. But after you get the used to it will be your best friend. Everything is spotless like everywhere in Japan and the lines are logically arranged for a better understanding. I think it’s the best way to travel in Tokyo and reach your points of interest. I recommend you to buy a Suica Card because it’s much easier that way.

Planning is key. The government has clearly done a fantastic job with its metro system. Despite being planned and implemented decades ago, the system is still as efficient and connected as ever. Constantly upgraded and increasingly connected, the metro system puts other cities' to shame. Extremely clean, and the Japanese commuters are as quiet and considerate as ever.

Very efficient. Looking at the train map for the first time, you cannot help but feel overwhelmed but once you are there, in the station and experienced your first ride (and line transfer) you can easily get used to it. English signage is abundant and if in case you feel that you are about to get lost, do not hesitate to ask any local, they are very polite and will really get out of thier way to help you. Just follow proper etiquite when inside the train, try not to make calls in your phone when inside the train and make sure you are not seating on the seats reserved for old people/with kids.

So efficient. Took a couple of days to get into it. With the help of locals, of course. They stopped asking if we needed help. The first woman was great, giving us a tip (as it turned out): the numbers in the circles on the scheme are the actual prices to get to another station. So we always paid precisely and never used Suica card.All the trains and metro are on time, just watch carefully - all the info is there on the signs: direction, stops, time. There are also station officers you can ask. By the way, a guide told us that because there is no crime in Japan, the policemen ("Caban" for Police) are only happy to help people to find direction. You should be aware that there are hardly English titles on the schemes of Metro/JR, so my husband surprised me by memorizing the Japanese symbols of the station where we lived and Tokyo - helped a lot.

Easy with Punctual Trains. We used both the rail and subway trains and had no difficulty finding our way around. We never waited more than a couple of minutes for a train and they are very reliable. Some of the stations are very large so you have to be careful which exit you choose or you could end up a long way from your intended destination.

Almost impossible if you don't know Japanese!!. I planned my trip out thinking that I could take the subway everywhere I needed to go in Tokyo. The lines are confusing, it's all in Japanese, even the little booth to buy the tickets and hardly anyone speaks English to help you. I had a friend who lives in Tokyo come and help me get around and buy me tickets- I would have been seriously screwed without her help!!

Beat way of traveling. The subways are one of the cleanest (like most of Japan) I've ever visited. The subwaylines are easy to understand, if not the personnel is very helpful, it's fast and flexible. Buying a Suica card is a recommendation since it makes everything much more easier.

Beware !. The trains are frequent, clean and pin-pointedly run to schedule ! If a train is due to leave at 10.13, it leaves at 10.13 !!An all day Metro ticket costs circa ¥700 which we thought was good value and would 'do the job'. Frustratingly, even annoyingly the circa 8 Metro lines are complimented by a further 6 Subway lines ; the subway lines are not included in the price for the Metro ticket !! Adding insult to injury, we purchased a combined Metro & Subway all day ticket ( ¥1500 ) only to then discover that there are an additional number of private lines.....which again are not included in the price for the combined Metro & Subway all day ticket !!!When you look at the Tokyo Metro map, it's not distinguishable from the graphics which lines are Metro, which are Subway etc. You have to read the info on the bottom right of the map to make out what's what.....to then do your route planning and associated costings.

Best way to move around. Fast, cheap and clean. Only way to move in the city. They even have air conditioning. Don't be afraid, every thing is in English. Stations very nice. Bad thing, you pay different prices according to your destination and at the end you may have to pay an adjustment.

You do not have reasons to not use it. Tokyo Metro system is possibly the best in the whiole world as it has stations and lines to everywhere, it's organized and extremely ponctual. A good tip is using google maps as a tool to know how to locomote. It provides the routes you have to take, in which station you must change line, etc etc. Very useful. Make sure to study well the lines you might use to use the tools like Google Maps as their metro has so many lines, trains, stations and plataforms that the likelihood of getting lost is considerable.

Best way to get around Tokyo. Before going to Tokyo I was massively concerned that the Metro system would be really confusing and I would end up getting lost for sure. How wrong was I! Ended up using it with ease on many occasions. Trains are clean, efficient, almost always on time and surprisingly cheap too! Make sure as a foreigner If you are travelling from Narita airport that you get a Narita express and Suica card combo ticket. Will save you some good money and the Suica card is a pre paid card you simply scan to ride the metro. All in all I found the Tokyo metro system to be great! Very easy to get across the whole of Tokyo!
Fast efficient travel around the cities of Tokyo. Really great mode of transportation.More expensive than the rest of Asia...but still less than$12 a day...Peak hour rush was bearable...

Always punctual. Can be busy during rush hours... not cheap either BUT saying that always punctual. Will get you to your destination on time. If you have an important appointment and don't want to be late... take the Tokyo Metro. Taxi's are comfortable but traffic can get you in trouble.
awesome metro. Trains are clean, they are allways on time. Everything works like a clock.I felt safe every time I was there, which I can not say about the subways in USA, for example.

Clean and easy to use. Contrary to my expectations, the metro was easy to use and everything included English (from the ticket stalls through to information on the train re:stops/changes). Like everything else in the city, very clean and organised; make sure to know ahead of time which metro exit you need as finding your way above ground is much tougher than while in the metro stations, which have clear directions.Runs once every 5-7 minutes and stops around midnight.

So easy to use!. Loved using the tokyo metro. Fast, efficient trains. The colour coding of the lines and numbering and naming of the stations made it easy for someone who doesn't speak or read Japanese. The buying of tickets at the machines was really straightforward and it was great to be able to use the fare adjustment facility where we had paid the wrong fare or changed our minds about our destination. Also much cheaper than the London Underground!

Avoid rush hours. It is very convenient travel around with the train. You can get to almost everywhere with train. But, the fares rather expensive. Tourist 2 days pass only available at airports. So do purchase it before you leave the airport, some travel passes can be purchased online in advanced. We did face some difficulties while purchasing ticket because the ticket officer doesn't speak English. My advice is even it has English writing at station but better do more researches. Avoid rush hours like 7-9am and 5-7pm. It is really really crowded.

Fast ,Cheap,Reliable transport in Tokyo City. We visited Tokyo ,Japan several times already , and each time we visit , the Tokyo Metro is a convinient method to get around the City.We usually board the JR Yamanote Line , to go to other parts of the city ,like Shinagawa, Asakusa, Ueno ,Shibuya,etc.All of this trains were congested by working commuters in the morning and after work in the afternoon.Sad that there's very little instructions in English , usually we buy single trip ticket only,and ticket buying is not as hard as it looks..Fast , reliable ,cheap ,clean and on time.

Fast, clean and gets you to your destination easily. There is a helpful information personnel to assist with any queries. Press "English" to purchase your tickets. Follow the colored signs and there are signs above each train door showing the next destination. Train fares are cheap compared to Australia. And it is fast, clean and efficient. Avoid the office hours rush..it will be packed like sardines.

Good but tread carefully. It is a good, reliable and clean metro system (interlinked with the JR system) and comparable with the system in HK and Singapore, even though it is far more expensive. If you need help with directions and do not speak Japanese, you may have a hard time. So do your homework beforehand. The locals have a tendency to rush (if not run), regardless of whether they are going to work or returning home, despite the frequency of trains. If you are knocked over by another commuter in a rush, he will probably turn back (if at all) to see who he had knocked over rather than to apologise or help you up. I would also advise against standing too near the doors when you are in the train as the locals also have the practice of forcing their way in (by backing into a crowded train) and you could find in a very very tight spot. You will have to pay 2 sets of fare if you interchange between JR and the Metro on a journey, and as such you may want to see if you can get to the same destination using one system rather than both. Many of the main JR stations is a mall in itself, and you can shop and dine without even leaving the station or surfacing to ground level.

JR Rail Pass and the clean efficient and fast paced Tokyo Metro. I do not see a category for the JR Rail Pass, so let me start by saying that if you are going to be in Japan for 3, 4 or more days, this is the best investment you can make. It pays for itself just using it back and forth to the airport. It also allows you to travel on the local JR lines the encircle the city and the high speed bullet trains, the Shinkansen lines. The cost is 28,300 Yen which you can calculate to your currency, but approximately $290. I used it just one way back to the airport (I used the bus into the city). I also used the Shinkansen high speed bullet train to Kyoto, Nikko and part way to see Mt. Fuji. The cost of the Shinkansen train to Kyoto was equal to the total cost of the rail pass, so I repeat it is a great bargain to get the JR Rail pass. This pass must be purchased in your home countries. It is NOT sold in Japan. If you are in a big city, there will be many agencies selling the pass. Do not pay a fee above the 28,300 Yen. Agencies get commissions from JR. It can be purchasd online and by mail. I also used it for many local trains around the city. All of these trips, we just flashed our pass at the attendant and went right thru. No need to buy individual tickets and navigate thru ticket gates. That is a great time saver and stress reducer. This is just one of the transportation systems that make up the entire Tokyo Metro System, which is huge. There are many different companies that operate many different subway and train lines. The Tokyo Metro is actually one of the subway lines that operates in the city. It has 9 lines including the Ginza line, the Marunouchi line, and 7 others. Then there is the Toei system, which operates 6 lines, most notably the Oedo line, plus 5 more. There are also other independent lines, like the Yurikamone line, and Odakyu line and others. This is an extensive system and you should get yourself a good train map, because if you travel around the city, more than likely you will need to switch between lines. With the JR Rail Pass you can utilize their lines when it is convenient, and possibly part of your travels and then you will have to switch to another line, and the ticket will be much less than if you went the whole route without JR. Find out what other lines you need to take and you can buy a one day Tokyo Metro card to supplement your JR Rail Pass. The directions in the stations and outside are clear and in English and arrows will lead you in the right direction. The Shinjuku station is huge, if you are in that area, you will use it often. Try to find landmarks in the station to help guide you. We traveled to Tokyo station from Shinjuku many times, and after the first time knew exactly what path to take. Also in cities other than Tokyo, you can only buy tickets from a machine. What you do is look at the board. Determine your station and the station you are going to. It will give you a price and you insert that into the machine, and a ticket will come out. The ticket is based on the distance you are traveling, and not where you are going exactly. In my reviews of Kyoto, Nikko and Mt. Fuji, I discussed which Shinkansen trains to use, as they have many different lines, Kodama, Hikari, etc. I told myself, since this was my second time in Tokyo, that I would not get lost using the Shinjuku station, however I did on a number of occasions as it is so huge. Also remember your exits as Tokyo and Shinjuku stations have upwards of 10 exits. You will encounter a majority of businessmen and school children using the trains and they being experts versus us tourists, move quickly thru the stations and up the escalators and the platforms so be aware of your surroundings, but over all it is a very safe, clean and efficient system and a real joy and pleasant to use. Stations like Shinjuku and Tokyo and most others have news stands, bakeries, coffee shops and other stores selling just about everything you can imagine, so if you have time waiting for your train, you will not be bored.

Great system, very robust, pleasant to use. Completely different system than what you see in New York. Like entire Tokyo, very clean. Not too many trash bins though so plan how to dispose your stuff carefully. Very complex underground system of passages and connecting walkways. Many levels underground. Can feel overwhelming at first due to size, though it is full of guiding signs along the way. Look for the English words among the Japanese kanji. As you walk through it trying to switch from one line to another you will have to pass through many gates, meaning you will be asked to insert your ticket quite often. Pricing depends on the distance traveled and also on the subway company used. Seems like getting a daily pass for 1,000 yen makes life easier as it offers great flexibility to switch lines at ease without worry that you have used your "point A to point B" ticket and now cannot cross another gate without getting another ticket.You most likely will not encounter any shadowy characters there as the system feels very, very safe. Across the entire system you will see arrows telling you on which side to proceed, either left or right. Seems like the prevailing directive is to stick to the left side,at least on the escalators it looks like the rule. If there are two of you and you like to stand side by side on the escalator, don't do that. The right side of you is intended to be left for the passers by who do not feel like standing and they prefer to continue walking on the escalator. Overall, the system is very robust, probably overwhelming to some in the beginning, but it is a very efficient way to move around, well kept and safe.

Great city transportation system. Our guide told us how to use it and armed with the subway map we gave it a shot. Buying your ticket can be a challenge but you can press the English button which helps. If confused, simply ask the turnstile attendant and they were always willing in all the cites we visited to help you out. Be sure and take your ticket when it pops up as you enter as you will need it to get out at your destination. My wife forgot the first time and we had to get the attendant who helped us by opening up the turnstile and taking her ticket out. Always know what number station you get off as that makes it easy to get on the correct subway in the correct direction. We had a free day in tokyo so we each bought an all day about ten bucks and we rode all day with no issues.

Looks harder than it is :). When you first look at the plan over the automat you'll think "how can I find where I want to go when everything is written Japanese?" But theres a list of every station, which is written in English. Next to the station you want to drive, you can find the price for this trip.And when you are planning to drive around a lot, you should buy a day-pass for 1000¥

Gets you everywhere!. It was easy to go to anywhere using the subway. in some stations you feel you are in a shopping mall! there is the dialy pass for unlimited trips that you can purchase. 7USD or the 16USD per day depends on the routes you are willing to use, highly recommended to take the 16USD if u have 3+ laces to see in one day

Convenient. Tip: we got a deal in Narita airport, Suica plus N'EX.If you return the Suica to a JA station they give you the Y500 deposit back.It's the most convenient and efficient way to travel in Tokyo. But it can be confusing and expensive. The most annoying thing about it is when you change lines and they charge you. And to leave you always have to pass your ticket. We spent more or less $5/ each/ day.In the airport we used our Suica card to buy some coffee and cakes.

Efficient & Brilliant. By far the easiest and most simple to use system to navigate Tokyo, all coded by colours and numbers so anyone of any language can understand it, really quite remarkable. Trains were never late and always on time. Also both Japanese and American English announcements on all trains so theres literally no room for confusion. Their transportation network to and from the airport are also brilliant there is absolutely no need to get taxis anywhere! Get a suica card to make it even more easier to travel quickly, and also can get a drink with or pay in shops like family mart its brilliant! If you dont want it can give it back and get your 500Y back at the end of your trip, or keep it like i did as a souvenir!

Brilliant Transport System. The Metro makes me sad. Every time I come to Tokyo I can't believe my home town of Sydney can not come close to the Japanese system. It may look crowded and chaotic but it works seamlessly. Don't be intimidated by it.....get a Suica card and get moving around. Trains run every few minutes, you can recharge your Suica at the station (press the English button) and even buy your food and drinks on the card.  The food and shopping available is varied and fabulous, and the latest renovations at Tokyo Station look great. Sydney, eat your heart out!

A unique experience and a fast way to move around. By far this is the best way to reach any destination in Tokyo, and is very different from any other metro in the world. It is a large network of trains and large stations (some looks like underground cities) that interconnect in many points. Take some time to understand how it is organized. Do not be intimidated by the apparent complicated maps, once you understand the logics (the concierge can help you with this) it can be as easy as using the map of bus and tube of London. Also the Stations' guards are very helpful and used to help foreigners. Some stations are huge with many shops and exits. Look for the right exit from the stations before you go out.

Simply the best. I have used the rail/subway systems in many big cities in the world, and I consider this my favorite. It is very clean, highly efficient, and very user friendly. The staff are very helpful and patient since I could not speak any Japanese except "please, hello and thank you". Almost all the signs in the train stations, and the trains are also in English so I could travel around Tokyo all alone, with a lot of ease. The announcements are in Japanese and English too. The directions in the metro stations are very good and specific since they use platform numbers. If you follow the exits correctly, it will lead you to the exact place you are going. Be very careful to follow the correct exit. I once used the wrong one and found myself in the other side of the Shibuya station. Since I could not speak Japanese, it took a little while to find my destination. There are guard rails on the platforms, and their gates open when the train comes into the station. Other big cities should emulate this.The cost is reasonable and buying tickets was easy too. If I had any problems, the wonderful residents of Tokyo were very willing to assist, and even take me to the correct platform. Since cabs are not cheap, this is a great choice for travelling around Tokyo.

Enjoy the real Tokyo in rush hour. Makes London look like a relaxing afternoon stroll in the park!!!!! Mental, overly complex system but its cheap and it gets you around, get a passmo card or similar for ease and best value

I ride everyday. Gets me where I want to go at a reasonable price. Not so great in typhoons, but better than the above-ground trains, but fortunately we don't have typhoons every day. Really, it is the best, fastest and easiest way to get around Tokyo and into the 'burbs. Don't fear the "crowding". It's norman and if you ride off-peak, you will be disappointed you didn't see anyone being pushed into the train by a man or women in white gloves.

Superb rail / subway system.. 1st trip to Tokyo ? Seen the Metro rail / subway map from goggle ? Confused ? Not to worry , once you are in Tokyo , get yourself a 'common 1 day ticket for the rail n subway ' and you will be ok .Follow the sign boards carefully , follow the respective colors . ABC>>>>123>>>> you will be ok. 1 day ticket will cost you 1,000yen but its worth it ( about usd10) if you are on the wrong train , get out the next station and backtrace you step , you can use the ticket in n out a thousand times ( by midnight of course ) All stations are very clean , information booth at every main/ large station , very helpful staff and many security personnels around to help you. Cannot speak Japanese.......no problem , use sign language , main thing show them the map n where you want to go.You do not need a tour guide in Tokyo , get off a main station , go to the exit ........some 'attraction ' will be around the town .All exits are numbered , so remember them ( incase you are lost again ! ) Rush hour ?? 7am to 9am ........5pm to 7pm , well...... I was in Tokyo for 6 days n use the trains / sub during these times........slightly crowded but no such thing as pushing or missing the train . Shopping arcades and restaurants, coffee corners at most large station . As my fellow reviewer said ....' its an attraction '

Complex...but simple to use...very clean,great value ,safe and efficient. Title sais it all. Fantastic network covering all the areas of Tokyo run with meticulous timing at an affordable and safe environment. I wish Melbourne had something this good!

Impressive. Chances are that you will visit this "attraction" anyway while in Tokyo.Amazingly efficient, and while it is crowded it is very peaceful (people know where to stand and how to behave, they are not hostile like in American undergrounds).It is amazing to watch the staff constantly observing their watches and pushing the trains to the second.

An attraction of it's own!. The Tokyo train system is an attraction of it's own and well worth using. The stations and their many levels are cities unto themselves which must be experienced to enrich your Tokyo travel experience.I used the rail system exclusively (except Narita transfers) during a 10 day stay in Tokyo. Single woman traveling alone - felt absolutely safe at all times. I am a native Chicagoan - the Tokyo rail system is hands down the safest (personal and belongings) I have experienced.VITAL - a Metro Map, a PASMO card, Hyperdia.com, station landmarks, know your exit number and allow plenty of travel time!I wore my map out during my stay - keep it handy at all times!! They can be printed online or picked up at the stations, hotels, etc. I planned out most of my excursions and printed directions out for myself - this was really helpful. Towards the end of the trip, I stared winging it as I became more familiar. Pay particular attention to the Letter and Number designation of each stop. If nothing else, knowing you have to go from "M04 to M16" can help immensely. All the trains I rode were bilingual and had user-friendly graphics announcing stops and transfers.PASMO card - accepted by Metro and JR lines. Not on rail line in Kamakura. Not sure about others. Got this info from an ex-pat I met on the Great Tokyo Cycling Tour. Get a Pasmo card from a kiosk (press the English button) and keep it loaded. It frees you from calculating fares and those tiny little paper tickets. You need your ticket going in and out. The fare is calculated and deducted from your card. There is a 500 yen refundable deposit to purchase the PASMO card. The deposit and any unused credit can be refunded at the end of your stay in Tokyo. There is a 210 yen fee for the refund but well worth it...that is $2. I refunded my card on at the Odakyu Ticket office - as you enter the office, it is the line to the far left. The PASMO card can also be used on the busses (used mine in Yokohama) as well as in shops with the PASMO logo.Hyperdia.com - you can go online and enter your itinerary and it will generate several options with stations and times as well as transfer stations. I used Hyperdia before and during my trip. TIP - if the travel time is about the same between options, choose the one with the least number of transfers. I found Hyperdia to a superior travel planning tool - much better than most I've used in the States and Europe.Station Landmarks - make note of landmarks in your home station to help orient you - my base was Shinjuku Station which is unbelievably HUGE.
