It helped a lot to note some of the shops, etc. along my path...a shoe store, a set of lockers with a huge picture of Labrador puppies and an iPad sign were mine. I was always relieved when I found the shoe store on my way out :-)Know your exit number. All the stations have multiple exits (A1, West Gate, etc) that are labeled HOWEVER, not all streets have names or street signs. Most guidebooks and pamphlets have the station exit number listed in the attraction info - noting your exit number will reduce your wandering around time trying to get out. Just because the attraction has a street name, doesn't mean you will see signage when you pop out on the street. I personally found it easier to find my way underground and pop out in the correct place, vs. popping out and wandering above ground.Allow PLENTY OF TRAVEL time. Whatever you think you need, double it. As many have posted, the transfers between lines can be FAR apart. Take your time and follow the signs. If you are traveling during rush hour - especially if you are going against the flow - step out of the way to read the signs. Tokyo commuters are like any others in the world...on a mission to get to/from work - try to stay out of the way!! Enjoy the Tokyo Metro and rail lines!! It is fast, uber-efficient and a great way to learn about Tokyo!!!

Can be very confusing, slightly disjointed, but very efficient. The Tokyo mass transit system essentially consists of lines operated by 3 separate companies, the Tokyo Metro, the Toei, and JR.The downside to this is changing from one company's lines to another costs both time and money. There are interchange stations, but sometimes walking from one line to another can be hundreds of metres away, and means exiting and buying another ticket. Going from Station A to Station B can cost twice as much if you take one company's lines as opposed to another.It also means that there are no standardised maps; often maps issued by one company looks completely different to that issued by another; for example the JR lines are invariably coloured as black and white chequered on many maps, whereas its lines are also colour coded. Also stations however, have names clearly labelled in English words, and some trains even have announcements in English. Trains are fast and clean and efficient, and most stations have toilet facilities and locker storage. Many however, have lots and lots of stairs to climb, and wheelchair access may only be at one end of the platform/ station.All three company lines now operate under the same stored value card- in fact, two, which work exactly the same. The Suica or Pasmo card, which I would recommend for anyone taking public transport in Tokyo. It is a touchless card, and stores value in it, the amount being automatically deducted at the turnstiles, meaning you don't have to work out how much to pay before each journey.Large stations, especially those with JR lines, are worth visiting themselves. Varied and cheap eateries everywhere, bakeries, and other retail outlets are to be found. The Guinness World of Records lists Shinjuku station as the most visited station in the world, and I wouldn't be surprised if many visit just to shop! Shinjuku station, and Shibuya station, for example have department stores located within them, and have a fantastic food mall at the basement, definitely worth visiting for the culinary experience alone.A trip tends to cost from 130 yen to around 300 yen for a trip right across Tokyo. Cheaper than the London Underground!

Confusing but can easily be learned. The Tokyo Railway system is a fast, clean and efficient means of transport going around Tokyo. It can be confusing at first, especially during rush hour when the stations can get very crowded, but one can easily learn the system after a few days of using it as a mode of transport. Some tips that helped us during our trip:- There are several railway companies operating within and outside of Tokyo. Each has its own trains, lines and ticketing machines, but many lines intersect or stop at the same stations around Tokyo.- The major companies to remember within Tokyo are the Metro (2 kinds: Tokyo Metro and Toei Metro group) and the JR Railway. Each have their own maps, so it will be very handy to either download both maps onto your mobile phone/gadget or just ask for a copy from each company at their booths.- Ticketing machines have an English language option but do not display the names of the stations for you to choose from, unlike in other cities like Hongkong or Seoul. Only the fares are displayed and you have to determine how much your fare is by checking the large signboards above the machines. The signboards show either the names of all the stations available for that company ONLY or their map with the corresponding fares per station. Not all signboards have an English translation (especially for JR Railways) so in such cases, it would be best to just go to an agent near the turnstiles and show them the station you need to go to on your map. Then ask them how much you need to pay. - Some might think it would be easier to just stick to one company when traveling from one area to another, but some of the routes take longer; so changing from one company to another to find a shorter and faster route can also be done. - When transferring to a different railway company, however, a new ticket needs to be purchased at the station where you need to change lines/companies.- In case you paid the wrong amount for your ticket, there are fare adjustment machines at the stations where you can adjust your fare and get a new ticket.- Again, it's always easier to just go to a railway agent and ask for the best route to a certain place, and how much you need to pay for. Don't worry... They are very polite, helpful and can speak English (most of the time).

Tokyo subway is a real marvel. One of the most extensive and easy-to-use underground transportation networks in the world. The highlights are bilingual labelling in Japanese and English almost everywhere, very intuitive ticketing machines, perfectly designed information displays inside the metro cars themselves, great wealth of information on the platform about the exits and the local sights (and there might be A LOT of exits from each station, like Shinjuku-eki that has more than 50!), and very friendly and helpful staff that will help you out when in trouble (especially if you're not Japanese :))The only thing that caused us trouble on a couple of occasions is 2 metro companies (Tokyo Metro and To:ei) that operate different lines - watch out for their corporate logos! And if you get it wrong, you can always get a very cheap transfer ticket from one company's lines to the other.

Underground Cities. I echo the previous reviews re: cleanliness, timeliness, & staff helpfulness. Wonderful system!Price: We always reflect how trains cost us more than our hotels & food combined. We learned we could actually just walk a bit above ground to get to the next station.Safety: In the busier stations, there's 4-ft. high barriers on the edge of platforms w/electronic gates. There's usually an 'eki-in' station worker nearby too.Etiquette: Along w/silenced phones & gadgets, there's posters of the metro rules. Many platforms are marked showing where to line up.Signage: Must have map in English (ask @ turnstiles office) but it is helpful to have a map in Japanese too b/c you can match the languages if needed. Tokyo Metro & most any stations use romaji (ABCs) to spell out their names. Also, inside the trains are electronic billboards that display which station you're arriving at next. Verbal announcements are often bilingual too.Platforms: This is the trickiest part for me. Sometimes I can't figure out whether I'm coming or going...so I just ask ANYone 'Does this train stop at ------- ?' Don't know how but my teen sons who don't speak or read Japanese always figure out which platform very quickly.Storage: Many stations have lockers. I think about 500-en/24 hours. Some overnite some not.Kids: Fun activity is bring a little notebook. At each station find its official ink stamp. Free!Etc: I could spend my whole day underground with all the stores! Very very well planned.Etc: Listen for the chirping birds. At first I thought they were real. A de-stresser. Great idea!Etc: The websites/guides for main attractions tell which station is nearest. We even used a metro app that was extremely helpful!Etc: In the metro area, remember to stay left on escalators, stairs & long walkways when there's lots of people. That's the usual rule. Often there's arrows showing where to walk.One reviewer gave a fascinating account of getting around w/wheelchair. It is hard if you can't find an elevator or escalator--not just for a wheelchair but with luggage too.

Wonderful way for transport. I was stuck in Tokyo for a day because I couldn't get on the plane - initially I was worried about getting around because I hadn't made any plans and I didn't have access to cash! But my anxieties were quickly quelled. Every service person in Tokyo is so knowledgeable and helpful and nice!Taking the train here is a cinch - there is an information counter --sometimes agents are stationed right at the ticketing counter as well. Just go up to them and fire your questions away. They speak good English. You can also get a map from them if need be. Tell them where you want to go and they will immediately give you an answer: the exact fare you need, which line to take, which platform to be at... Voila you're on your merry way! The trains also reach on time. I'm terrible at moving around but even I managed to get from Haneda Airport to Tokyo to Ginza to Tsukiji to Harajuku - all this with only USD 16 in my pocket! There are also a few counters where you can purchase tickets with credit cards so if you're out of cash it's good to stop by those counters and get all your round trip tickets. What is interesting to me is that you're not allowed to speak on the phone while on the train. So it was a very quiet, relaxing ride all the time.

Expensive, outdated ticketing system, and often confusing if you can't read Japanese. Perhaps this review is slightly biased due to the fact that I visited Tokyo after 3 weeks in Seoul, but I must say that I was very surprised by how expensive and confusing the Tokyo metro system is relative to their Korean neighbors. I cannot read Japanese, and I often found that the signs which you use to determine the fare you should pay for your ticket were very difficult if not impossible to understand at many station stops. This is further complicated by the fact that the metro system consists of multiple companies whose ticket systems are isolated and not transferable. I HIGHLY recommend keeping a printout of the entire metro system in your pocket with you at all times...it saved me more times than I can count!Many times I would realize I had paid the wrong amount, so when I went to exit the station by putting my ticket into the exit lane, the gates would close and lock me in. Sometimes there was a station worker nearby that would help me to understand the fare difference I needed to pay to exit, but other times there was no one around. Also the little tickets that you get can be easily lost. Aside from the confusion, the cost was also very high to use the Tokyo Metro system, though I'm sure it was cheaper than using a taxi. However, in my two days sightseeing, I spent over $75 on myself alone for nothing more than trips on the metro lines. The costs must have been ridiculous for the families with multiple children that I saw using the metro frequently.In summary, the Tokyo metro is one of the better choices from a selection of bad options when it comes to getting around Tokyo. Prepare yourself for high prices, confusing route options with minimal English translations, multiple train operators that do not honor the other lines' tickets, and by all means keep a subway system map with you at all times.

Efficient but confusing. I went to the information area everytime I needed a ticket so I did not have to worry about figuring out the signs telling you how much it would be to each stop, which is where most foreigners have issues. Very timely and gets you anywhere you want to go, just be sure not to change lines!

Clean and fast though confusing.. Ive travelled on a number of metro systems throughout Asia as well as Europe and this is by far the most confusing. The sheer number of lines and the need to buy specific transfer tickets makes it difficult. It is not always easy to transfer between the different lines and in the stations tje maps are often only in Japanese so be sure to pick up a paper English map.Having said that they are clean, fast and arrive very regularly. Plus the update your ticket machines are an excellent idea.

It's easy to catch on to and easier to use once you do. I was fortunate to have someone with me that speaks Japanese and could explain things to me, but I had time on my own and was able to figure it out easily. Plus, if I ever had any questions there were workers there that could help me. I never worried about getting lost.

Clean, efficient, fast but sometimes confiusing. Tokyo's metro system is very functionnal; plus it's clean and you can ask assistance everywhere since there are plenty of agents at every stations.For a single ride trip, the station you're boarding is shown on a big screen and you have to check the station you'll exit and pay the price diaplayed accordingly. If you're changing the line you have to check at a "fare adjustment monitor" if you have to adjust your ticket to change or exit the new station.Sometimes it is a little bit confusing since all the lines of the subway system belong to different companies (mainly 2: JR & Tokyo metro). So sometimes you have to purchase new tickets to reach a station since you're switching companies lines..wasn't really clear to me.

Don't miss the Metro, even if you don't need it. Tokyo Metro is the cleanest and easiest-to-use transit system I have ever encountered. Hints for non-Japanese-speakers:Above the ticket machines there is a chart showing the fare to reach every other station. Find your fare, then buy a ticket for that amount. If you mess up, find the Fare Adjustment machine at your destination.Near the exits you will find street maps posted. Use these to locate the exit number closest to your destination. These maps are invaluable as some stations have more than a dozen exits to the street.Get an English-language map before you go. The Japanese maps don't include the station numbers.If you ever need a restroom in Tokyo, find a Metro station. There are also vendors and newsstands everywhere.Have no fear. This is an easy system to navigate.

Easy to use, reasonably priced. Once you realise that there are two companies and that you must buy the right ticket for the right line, its a piece of cake. I really liked the numbering of the stations - really easy to remember - and the diagrams showing how many stops there were. All names are in English so there's no mystery.

Better than the London Tube!. It was our first visit to Japan and if we can understand the Tokyo metro as easily as we did, anyone can! It was frequent, on time and well organised. Staff were also very helpful when we needed directions.

Use the Metro to get around. We visited Tokyo for the first time in November 2012 - this was daunting as we are only English speakers so we were concerned about getting around on public transport. How wrong we were to be concerned! The spaghetti style maps of the Tokyo Metro system look confusing but in reality they are very simple to understand. Each Metro (subway) line is colour coded and each station has a reference number M7, C10, Z04 etc... Using the free hardcopy maps at most stations or internet maps you can easily figure out where you want to go and what line you need to use to get there - changing stations is easy and the lines are well signed. The only trick when buying a ticket is to remember to put your money in first and then select the fare amount not the other way around. Locals say to try and avoid the Metro in peak hours but we had no troubles. This is a great way to get around the city above.

Tokyo Metro Maps. I love the Tokyo Metro system - super punctual, super clean - BUT, you need two maps to navigate the system. There are two different companies with different networks of lines and they don't show each other's networks The JR map only shows the JR network. The Tokyo metro map shows the Tokyo Metro network and the airport lines. I looked online but could never find one consolidated map showing both JR and Tokyo Metro. You can use the Tokyo Metro trip planner to figure which of their lines to take to get to your destination, but be aware that there may be shorter ways to get there using a combination of both JR and Tokyo metro lines.

Excellent Subways. This is one of the best subway systems I've ever used. Easy to get around and use. Stations are kept clean and signs are every where in English, very helpful. I always take the Metro when in Tokyo. The above ground JR trains (ex. Yamanote line) are horrible in comparison and always extremely over crowded. Stick w/the Metro and you can't go wrong.

The best and the cutest metro.. Despite having very many people, it's all very organized and clean. A little distressing in the summer, but then gets used. There are some very cute songs for each station. To know Tokyo, you have to experience!

Best underground system. The Tokyo metro is probably the best I have ever been on. It it wonderful clean, trains run exactly on time, info is ample, coverage is great and it is very easy to use for non Japanese speakers. We were able to do all our travel on the Tokyo underground. Just buy a day pass for about US$ 10 and you are off. All signs are in English, there is contineous station info on the train in English and by giving each line a coulour and stations a number getting around is a breeze and thus you do not need to take a city tour. Exploring Tokyo on your own and at your own paste is so much more fun.And the Tokyo Metro is the perfect tool for that.

First class metro. The Tokyo Metro is one of the very best in the world. The trains are clean, fast, and precisely on time. Stations are large, clean, modern and easy to navigate. All stops have signs in English and Japanese, and announcements onboard the trains are made in English and Japanese as well. The route maps are well laid out and easy to understand and navigate. Even for a first time visitor who speaks no Japanese, you can expect to easily navigate the Tokyo Metro. Added bonus, many of the stations have some cool stuff in addition to trains, such as food courts, shops, and even tourist attractions. Prices are low at around $1.50 per ride (or less if you buy a day or week pass, etc) and you can find bathroom facilities and vending machines for drinks and snacks at virtually every station. Tokyo Metro is by far the best way to get around the city, don't miss it.

On the Tokyo subway with a wheelchair companion. My wife walks with the aid of crutches due to a decades-old spinal injury. We took along a foldable wheelchair for the later parts of the day when she got too tired to walk.We first attempted to navigate our way through the Tokyo subway by climbing down some steps at Shinjuku-Gyoenmae station on a Sunday morning. Upon reaching the ticketing area the ticket collector was most helpful and personally showed us to the platform. She asked if my wife needed to use the wheelchair but as it was early in the day she insisted that it was not required. The politeness was above the standard one could expect from public transport anywhere in the world. I supposed that since it was a Sunday perhaps she had fewer responsibilities to attend than on other days. We got to Meiji Jingumae station without too much difficulty and spent the day wandering around Harajuku and Omotaesando. The latter is often described as the Champs Elyssee of Tokyo. By late afternoon my wife started usin g the wheelchair. We then wandered to Yoyogi Park and boarded a subway at Harajuku station. After purchasing the tickets the person at the ticketing gate noticed my wife on her wheelchair and got out of his office to attend to us. He asked where we intended to go ;and led us to the elevators which were in an alcove behind the ticket barriers. Another official met us at this point. I noticed she had an aluminium board underneath her left arm. I wondered if it was some sort of ramp. She went down with us onto a basement level and took us to the platform. And “yes” she unfolded a ramp just in front of the train to enable me to push my wife’s wheelchair onto the train without breaking stride. It was like being a visiting head of state. The gap from the train to the platform is only about 5 cm (2 inches) ;and on subway lines the normal trick is to reverse the wheelchair and push the bigger rear wheel onto the carriage first but of course with the ramp you can push the wheelchair passenger on to the train using the smaller front wheels. On board the train my wife joked that it would be really impressive if there was a ramp waiting for us at Shinjuku station. I rolled my eyes and thought to myself: Well you can live in hope. Lo and behold when we go to Shinjuku station there was a subway official waiting and he unfolded another ramp to allow me to push the wheelchair front wheel first. The official led us one of the station offices and said that someone would come to show us the way to which to catch the train back to Shinjuku-gyoenmae. He even apologised for the wait and explained that they were changing shifts at this time. After about 10 minutes another official came and led us to the platform for the Oedo Line and again he produced a ramp to help us get onto the train and at our destination there was an official waiting (we now realised that they were informed of which carriage and door we were on by walkie-talkie) with the ramp ready at the door of the train where we alighted. This wasn’t the only time we got this amazing level of service. On Wednesday we took a train from Shibuya station to get to Shinjuku-sanchome. Shibuya is quite an old station. There are escalators going up but none leading down. My wife had to use the aid of a banister with one hand and a crutch on the other to get down one step at a time while I carried the wheelchair down the stairs. There were two flights of steps to negotiate. When we got to the ticketing area a security guard noticed us and took the initiative to contact the station staff. Again we were led from one point to another by subway officials and again they had the aluminium ramp on hand (this time it had a Velcro fastening). When the train got to Shinjuku station the doors opened and we could see a uniformed subway official with hat on unfolding a ramp to enable us to get off and resume our shopping expedition at the food hall of the Isetan department store. It was like Victorian clockwork. And the cost of our subway tickets? Yen 160 (about US$2.00). Only in Japan.

Most Cost-effective and Efficient Way to see Tokyo. I have used the Metro system dozens of times and have found it to be the best of its kind in the world. The cost is far more reasonable compared to other modes of transporation such as taxis. It is also very easy to figure out. Most of the signage in the majority of the stations is also in English with some exceptions. The station personnel are generally very helpful if you have questions. Some have better English skills than others but we have always been able to ultimately communicate. The coverage is fabulous as you can get most anywhere in the core area of Tokyo you need to go. There are also ample connections to the local trains for those areas out of reach of the Metro or for those routes that may be faster to get to by train. The facilities are clean and there are ample amenities such as vending available, especially in the larger stations. But the most striking feature of the Metro is the on-time performance which is superior to any other system I have used, including those in Europe. The one drawback is that it is indeed utilized by the local population and it can get very crowded. Avoid riding during the morning rush hour unless you want to get to know the people around you very intimately.

Convenient and easy to use even if you don't speak jap. Easy to get around, no problem finding our way at all. Was initially concerned about travelling on our way in Tokyo with no knowledge of Japanese but it's lovely helpful citizens and wonderful train network made it easy for us. We love Tokyo for its people and trains. Everyone here is so disciplined - they don't really use mobile phones on trains and speak softly if they do. Very disciplined too. No complains or fanning oneself even if no air con on trains :)) very well mannered pple :)

Easy and cheap way around Tokyo. Well, the picture here is of a Shinkansen high-speed train, not the Metro. The Metro has many trains and many lines, and you can get a day-pass. Cheap, quick, clean, safe, efficient. Excellent for going from place to place if you do not want to see sights in between.

What an easy way of city transport. The Metro in Toyko is a very easy, fast, reasonably cheep and ontime transport system to use while in Toyko for a few days. You don't need any Japanese to work it out and if you get lost you ask one of the many thousand rail officers. If the person you ask has no English understanding they will go out of the way to get you somebody who does speak English.The system is all worked out, as in England or France, with the various lines which have their own colour and the stations are all numbered in english numbers. You can get a free metro station map which has the lines and stations written in English and Japanese.You can buy individual tickets, but if you plan to use the metro for a few days then you should buy a PASMO card (which has 1000 yen worth of metro travel on it) from any ticket dispenser which is much better trip value for multi trips. You pay a small amount for getting the card which you get back when you cash it is at the large stations) If you need to top the card money you just put the card in the machine and press the english version of instructions and follow the prompts. Again if you have problems see one of the many rail people who are very helpfull.Overall the system is better than the metro in England, France and Spain. Give it a go as it is easy to work out which station you need and with all the good guide books (especially The Lonely Planet Japan guide) telling you which stations to get out at for the numerous attractions in Tokyo you will find it a breeze
